Sessions Paper.
SAMUEL, MAYOR.
SECOND SESSION, HELD DECEMBER 15TH, 1902.
MINUTES OF EVIDENCE,
TAKEN IN SHORT-HAND BY
MESSRS. BARNETT AND BUCKLER.
Short-hand Writers to the Court,
ROLLS CHAMBERS, No. 89, CHANCERY LANE.
LONDON:
STEVENS AND SONS, LIMITED, 119, CHANCERY LANE.
Law Booksellers and Publishers.
THE
WHOLE PROCEEDINGS
On the King's Commission of
OYER AND TERMINER AND GAOL DELIVERY
FOR
The City of London,
AND GAOL DELIVERY FOR THE
COUNTY OF MIDDLESEX AND THE PARTS OF THE COUNTIES OF ESSEX, KENT, AND SURREY WITHIN THE JURISDICTION
OF THE
CENTRAL CRIMINAL COURT,
Held on Monday, December 15th, 1902, and following days,

Before the Right Hon.
SIR MARCUS SAMUEL , Knt., LORD MAYOR of the City of London; the Hon. Sir
CHARLES JOHN DARLING , one of the Justices of His Majesty's High Court; Sir
JOHN WHITTAKER ELLIS , Bart., Sir
DAVID EVANS , K.C.M.G., Lieut.-Colonel Sir
HORATIO DAVIES , K.C.M.G., M.P., Aldermen of the said City; Sir
FORREST FULTON , Knt., K.C., Recorder of the said City;
JOHN POUND , Esq.,
FREDERICK PRAT ALLISTON , Esq., and
THOMAS BOOR CROSBY , M.D., other of the Aldermen of the said City;
ALBERT FREDERICK BOSANQUET , Esq., K.C., Common Sergeant of the said City;
LUMLEY SMITH , Esq., K.C., Judge of the City of London Court, and
JAMES ALEXANDER RENTOUL , Esq., K.C., M.P., LL.D., Deputy Judge of the City of London Court, His Majesty's Justices of Oyer and Terminer, and General Gaol delivery holden for the said City and Judges of the Central Criminal Court.

A star (*) denotes that prisoners have been previously in custodyâ€”two stars (**) that they have been more than once in custodyâ€”a dagger (â€ ) that they are known to be the associates of bad charactersâ€”the figures after the name in the indictment denote the prisoner's age.
LONDON AND MIDDLESEX CASES.

66.
JOHN DAVIS (21),
EDWARD HETTY (23),
ALBERT JONES (24), and
ISAAC ZUCKERMAN (19),
PLEADED GUILTY to
breaking and entering the warehouse of
Arthur and Cook, Limited, and stealing fifteen blouses, three pieces of silk, and Â£1 16s., their property, Davis having been convicted of felony at the Thames Police Court as George Williams on March 14th, 1902, Jones at Worship Street Police Court on October 10th, 1902, Zuckerman at the Thames Police Court on July 3rd, 1901, and Hetty at this Court on October 21st, 1901, as Patrick Hopkins. Three previous convictions were proved against Davis, seven against Hetty, and four against Zuckerman. DAVIS and HETTY,
Six years' penal ser
vitude each;
JONES,
Twelve months' hard labour;
ZUCKERMAN,
Eighteen months' hard labour. â€”

(67).
HENRY GILBY
, to breaking and entering

Judgment respited.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]â€”

(68).
WILLIAM BEVAN
, to forging an endorsement on an order for the payment of Â£30 15s.
Also to stealing a sheet of paper, an envelope, and an order for the payment of Â£30 15s., the property of
Thomas Bentley Westacott.
Also to forging and uttering an endorsement on an order for the payment of Â£4 11s. 8d.
Also to stealing two sheets of paper, two envelopes, and two orders for the payment of Â£4 11s. 8d. and Â£1 10s., the property of
Thomas Bentley Westacott,
Also to forging and uttering an endorsement on an order for the payment of Â£4 11s. 8d., with intent to defraud, having been convicted of felony at the Guildhall, Westminster, on January 5th, 1901. Four other convictions were proved against him.
Five years' penal servitude.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

69.
CHARLES HOFFMANN and
JEAN CONSAUVE ,
Stealing an order for the payment of Â£92â€”is. 6d., to which Consauve
PLEADED GUILTY
. (See next case.)

70.
CHARLES HOFFMANN and
JEAN CONSAUVE were again indicted for
forging and uttering an endorsement on an order for the payment of Â£92 4s. 6d., with intent to defraud.

CONSAUVE
PLEADED GUILTY .

p.hi: Prosecuted, and the evidence was interpreted when necessary.

div1.p: JEAN MENEZ . I live at 28, Mortimer Market, St. Pancrasâ€”in August I possessed 100 three per cent. Panama Bondsâ€”they were held for me by M. Guyon, of Paris, for 1,500 francsâ€”I came to England about June 25thâ€”amongst other people, I met the prisoners shortly after my arrivalâ€”I had a valise and a parcelâ€”I had these elector's tickets (Produced) in my luggageâ€”the two signatures "Menez," at the bottom are in my writingâ€”in August I went to Mitcham to work as a masonâ€”I met with an accident thereâ€”I came back to London and went to 25, Frith Streetâ€”while there I saw Consauve, and he told me that Hoffmann wanted to see meâ€”I went to see him at his houseâ€”he expressed his satisfaction at seeing me again. I was going to the hospital, and I gave my valise to Consauve, and paid him 6d. for the trouble of looking after it for meâ€”the documents were in it then with this other document (Produced)â€”I was in the hospital eighteen days, and afterwards I went to a convalescent home at Brightonâ€”I went to the hospital on September 9th, and went straight to Brighton when 1 came out, but I changed my clothes at Hoffmann's before I went to Brightonâ€”he came to see me two or three times in the hospitalâ€”I was at Brighton for three weeks, and about the middle of October I went back to Mortimer Marketâ€”I there found a letter from M. Guyon, dated September 6thâ€”I never gave anybody authority to sell my Panama Bonds nor did I intend to sell themâ€”after I got the letter of the 6th I saw both prisonersâ€”I told them that my name had been falsified and my bonds had been sold without my authority, and that I had a suspicion of them. Hoffmann said, "I am an honest man; I have not done anything," and he suggested that I should go back to France, and that he would find the money to enable me to goâ€”I made up my mind to stop in Englandâ€”if I had known that my bonds had been stolen I should have gone to Franceâ€”I obtained my luggage, and opened my valise in the prisoners presence and two other Frenchmenâ€”I said to the prisoners, "You have not stolen anything"â€”all my papers were thereâ€”neither of these letters dated September 11th and 16th were signed by me or by my authorityâ€”tin's cheque is not endorsed by meâ€”I never saw it till I was at the police court the other dayâ€”I afterwards went to the police.

GEORGE GUYON . I live at 6, Boulevard St. Bastaville, Paris, and am a bankerâ€”I know Menezâ€”I held his 100 Panama three percent. Bonds up to the middle of September against a loan of 1,500 francsâ€”about September 11th I got this letter from London, dated September 11th: "M. Guyon, I am writing you to ask you to be kind enough to sell the whole of my bonds to the best possible advantage and as soon as

possible; I have just had the offer of a little business which will add mate
rially to my income. I have succeeded in persuading this person to let me have the business at my own price, and I must strike the iron while it is hot. Please don't lengthen the transaction by a lot of correspondence, but act us if it was for yourself; I shall be satisfied, but act promptly. Immediately I receive in full, I will acknowledge same by registered letter. Awaiting a reply by return of post, yours, &c, Menez, 76, Whitfield, Street, Tottenham Court Road, London"â€”upon that I sold the bonds and sent the balance on September 15thâ€”I have no London agents, sol went to Messrs. Jorden, Cohen, and Co., in Paris, and they gave me this cheque on Parr's Bank in London for Â£92 4s. 6d. (Produced)â€”I crossed it and sent it to 76, Whitfield Street in a registered letterâ€”on September 17th I got this letter, dated September 16th: "I beg to acknowledge receipt of your favour of the 15th inst. I have received your cheque for Â£94 2s. 6d., for which I thank you. I have some difficulty in getting the money as the cheque is crossed, but it is only a question of a few hours, and I think I shall be able to get it to-morrow morning. I am writing to my children at the same time as to you to ask them to send me back the receipt for the deeds which I left with them. Immediately I receive it I will return it to you. Believe me, sir, yours sincerely, Menez"â€”later in October I got some letters from M. Menezâ€”I believed those two letters came from the M. Menez who had deposited the bonds with me.

ARTHUR DANIEL MATHEWS . I am a postman, of Sidmouth Street Grays Inn Roadâ€”On September 16th I delivered a registered letter from Paris at 76, Whitfield Streetâ€”I cannot remember to whom I delivered it.
ARTHUR DAVID . I am an engineer, of 76, Whitfield Street, Tottenham Court Roadâ€”I was there from September 9th until some time in Octoberâ€”I saw Hoffmann there about September 12th.

ROLAND MERRY . I am a clerk at Parr's Bank, 77, Lombard Streetâ€”I remember the prisoners coming there on September 16th, between 1 and 2â€”this cheque was tendered to Mr. Jarrett, the cashierâ€”he spoke to me and I spoke to the prisoners in French, and explained to them that as it was a crossed cheque we could not pay it across the counter, or in fact pay it at all, as it would have to come through another bankerâ€”they seemed rather upset about it and asked me whether we could not do somethingâ€”I asked them if they had any friends in London who had a banking account and who could change it for them, and they said "No"â€”I asked them if they were staying at an hotel and if the landlord could pay it for themâ€”they said "No"â€”I then said if they would pay for a telegram to Paris and we could get instructions from Paris, we could pay it although it was crossed; that is the custom of bankersâ€”that was doneâ€”they left and came back about 3.30, but the reply had not then come from Parisâ€”they called at 10 a.m. next dayâ€”the reply had come from Paris the afternoon beforeâ€”the cheque was then in order for paymentâ€”I asked them how they would like to receive the moneyâ€”they said, "In gold;" I said, "Would you not like some notes?"â€”they said, "No, all in gold," and they had it all in goldâ€”when the cheque was brought in on the 16th it was already endorsedâ€”

they both helped themselves from the pile of money on the counterâ€”I have compared the endorsement with the two lettersâ€”I should say de
cidedly that all three signatures are in the same writing.
Cross-examined by Hoffmann. The cheque was endorsed before I saw it; it may have been endorsed in the bank.

GEORGE PARKINSON JARRETT . I am chief cashier at Parr's Bank, Lom
bard Streetâ€”I saw the two prisoners come in on September 16thâ€”I cannot remember seeing the cheque endorsedâ€”when it came into my hands it was already endorsedâ€”I referred the men to Mr. Merry, as I do not speak Frenchâ€”on the 17th we cashed the chequeâ€”to the best of my recollection Hoffmann took up the money.

ALBERT DRAPER (Detective Sergeant.) On November 26th I was in Old Compton Streetâ€”I saw the prisoners thereâ€”I told them, in French, who I was, and said I should take them to the police station for obtaining a cheque for Â£92 4s. 6d., and forging an endorsement to it; Hoffmann said, "I did not take anything, I accompanied my friend Consauve to the bank; he obtained the money and signed for it. I did nothing, nor signed for it"â€”we went to the station, where I showed them the chequeâ€”Consauve, in Hoffmann's hearing, said, "Yes, that is the cheque, and the endorse
ment on it is mine; I and my friend Hoffmann were in Charlotte Street one day, I don't know the date, and a young man came to us and asked us if we would do him a service; he then took us to a bank in the City, but before going into the bank he took us into a public-house and gave us something to drink. He then produced a cheque and a letter which bore the signature Menez, also a sheet of white paper and told me to copy the signature Menez on the paper. This I did several times. He then told us to go to the bank and ask for the money, and if they wished it to sign the name Menez on the back of the cheque. He came outside the public-house; at the bank they were not willing to pay, and said we must go the next day; we told the man"; the next day we saw him again; we went to the bank and the stranger remained outside; I endorsed the cheque on the back on the counter, and they gave us the money in gold as the man had directed us; I went outside and gave the gold to the man; the man gave me Â£1, and as Hoffmann owed me 2s. I kept the Â£1."â€”I took that state
ment down in writing.
Hoffmann's statement before the Magistrate. "I am innocent; I am sorry I went into the bank."
Hoffmann's Defence. "I have nothing to say; I wait for the decision of the jury: I am innocent."

HOFFMANN,
GUILTY â€ â€”
Twelve months hard labour;
CONSAUVE, who received a good character,
Nine months in the second division.

(75.)

, to stealing a watch chain, the property of

(76.)
THOMAS VICTOR PARKER and
EDITH JANE ASHLEY
, to obtaining Â£6 5s. and other sums from

also to forging and uttering a paper writing purporting to be signed by Henry Lendener; PARKER
also to stealing Â£4 4s., Â£6 5s., Â£24, Â£1 15s., Â£10, Â£7, and Â£50, the monies of

Five years' penal servitude;
ASHLEY,
Five days' imprisonment.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

77.
ERNEST HENRY BISHOP (43), and
SARAH ANN BISHOP (38)
, For the manslaughter of
Florence Adelaide Bishop. Mr. Hutton, for the prosecution, offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

78.
ERNEST HENRY BISHOP and
SARAH ANN BISHOP were again indicted for
unlawfully and wilfully neglecting
Rose,
Lily, and
Florence Bishop, children under sixteen years of age, in a manner likely to cause them unnecessary suffering and injury to their health, to which SARAH ANN BISHOP"
PLEADED GUILTY .
Six months in the second division.
MR. HUTTON, for the prosecution, offered no evidence against ERNEST HENRY BISHOP
NOT GUILTY .

79.
GEORGE KNEE (42)
, Feloniously wounding
Elizabeth Knee with intent to murder her.

ELIZABETH KNEE . I am the prisoner's wifeâ€”we were separated about two months ago under an order of the Court on account of his persistent crueltyâ€”I was living with my two childrenâ€”on December 1st, about 9 p.m., I was visiting some friendsâ€”I returned home and found the prisoner in the kitchen with the two little girlsâ€”he asked me if I did not think it was time I went back to him; I said no, but if he liked to be a teetotaler and show me he would be good to me I would take him back in six monthsâ€”he wanted to come back there and thenâ€”I put my two little girls to bedâ€”

he wanted to sit and talk to meâ€”I did not feel able to do so, and all at once he jumped up and took this table knife (Produced) out of the table drawer in the kitchen, and cut my throatâ€”I had a struggle with him and he cut my arms and my hands: I have the marks nowâ€”I screamed, and my lodger from upstairs came down; she ran to open the front door and then help cameâ€”I got the knife away from the prisoner and flung it down by the doorâ€”when he found that he could not do any more with it he jumped on my stomach and backâ€”I had felt the knife at my back, but I had my clothes on so it did not cut meâ€”when the prisoner first started at me he said he would do for meâ€”the police came and took him awayâ€”he was soberâ€”he has said he would do for me ever so many times.
By the JURY. The knife was bent as it now is in the course of the struggleâ€”it was quite straight when he took it out.

Cross-examined by the prisoner. You had been in my house before December 1stâ€”I did not ask you to stop and have a cup of tea with meâ€”Lily brought you in on the Sunday eveningâ€”you did not have supper with me then, I would not speak to youâ€”I did not toast any muffins for youâ€”when I came back on December 1st you asked me to come back to you and I said I could not trust youâ€”I did not say that you had been the cause of our child's death.
The prisoner. "Her saying that was the cause of my doing what I did; I lost my temper, and I got the knife and went and stabbed her."

HARRY BROWN . I am a physician and surgeon, of 308, Lily Road, Fulhamâ€”on December 1st I was called to the prosecutrix's houseâ€”she had a cut on the upper part of her right arm about 3 in long and in deep, also two cuts not very severe on the left side of her neck, and one behind the ear; that was more of a bruise than a cutâ€”there were a lot of scratches and abrasions on her hands and faceâ€”two of the fingers of her left hand were badly cutâ€”this sort of knife could have caused the woundsâ€”it is very blunt, considerable force must have been used to inflict the injuries.

WILLIAM KEEN (1 T.R.). I was summoned on December 1st to the prose
cutrix's houseâ€”I saw the prisoner there and arrested himâ€”he said, "I will go quietly; I was coming down to the station"â€”this knife was handed to me by one of the witnessesâ€”there were slight stains of blood on itâ€”the prisoner was quite sober.

The Prisoner's defence. I had great provocation; she caused me to do it. I did not go to the house with any intention of hurting the woman until she said I had been the cause of the child's death; I done it in my temper; I have been to the house several times before and nothing had hap
pened.

GUILTY . Twelve previous convictions were proved against him, and the police stated that he was a violent man and had treated his wife with great cruelty.
Fifteen years' penal servitude.

80.
WILLIAM RICHARDSON
was charged on the Coroner's inqui
sition only, with the manslaughter of
Benjamin Richardson.

p.hi: for the prosecution offered no evidence.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

81.
GEORGE LOCK (31) and
GEORGE WILLIAMS (20),
PLEADED GUILTY to
stealing twelve shirts, the property of
E. F. Vowles and Co. Limited, Lock having been convicted at Clerkenwell on May 18th, 1897, in the name of George Warren.
Four other convictions were proved against Lock and three against Williams.
Twelve months' hard labour each.

82.
LEWIS LAZARUS ,
Demanding money with menaces from
Abraham Ganzman.

ABRAHAM GANZMAN (Interpreted.) I keep a restaurant at 72, Cromer Street, Gray's Inn Roadâ€”on November 11th the prisoner came to the back entrance, and my waiter told me that he wanted to see meâ€”he was a stranger to meâ€”I went into the kitchen with him; he said, "I have been told by some friends that you keep a gambling place, and I am in a postion to do you something good, so that you should not have any damage."â€”I refused to pay him money, and he went awayâ€”the following Sunday a messenger came from the prisoner that I should meet him at Portland Road Stationâ€”I did not goâ€”on Monday the same messenger came with a man named Semelâ€”he wanted me to go out, but I refused, and told him to come insideâ€”he then said, "I am going to protect you, but if it is impossible for you to pay me Â£10 at once you can pay me Â£2 per week; you can afford it because you have, got two places;"I said, "I am not going to pay you; I do not require your protection; I am not doing any
thing wrong here"â€”he then said that he was a detective, took some papers out of his pocket, and said that everything was ready to give me into custody, and that he had done such things on previous occasionsâ€”I understood at once that he could not be a sworn detective, and I accom
panied him to the police station and gave him in chargeâ€”he then said that he was a tailorâ€”I said, "You told me you were a detective"â€”Semel and another man walked behind us to the station.

Cross-examined by the prisoner. I do not know youâ€”I saw you at my house for the first timeâ€”I do keep a restaurant in the East Endâ€”you did not use to come thereâ€”I did not come to your-place three months ago with Max Lewis, I do not know himâ€”he is not a partner of mineâ€”you did not tell me you were a detective on the first occasionâ€”you said you were a friend of mine, and would protect meâ€”I did not hear Max Lewis say that you had made him pay Â£50 for keeping a gambling club, and that he did not care if you made him pay another Â£100.

By the COURT. I know Max Lewis, he keeps a restaurant in the neigh
bourhoodâ€”he was fined Â£50 for keeping a gambling houseâ€”I do not know that the prisoner gave information to the police that Max Lewis was keeping a gambling clubâ€”I am a stranger to Max Lewis, because I am his rival in business.

By the prisoner. I did not say to Max Lewis, "All right, you keep quiet, I will take your part," nor strike you in the chest with my fistâ€”I did not tell the policeman that you represented yourself to be a detective

because I could not make myself understood, but I tried to make him understand that he should arrest us both until I found an interpreterâ€”I have not paid Â£5 to a witness to give evidence against you, nor have I collected Â£40 for the expenses of this trial: it will not cost so much as that, and I had no need to collect that sumâ€”I did not send a man to you to ask you not to give information against me for keeping a gambling and disorderly houseâ€”I have never kept a gambling house, neither have I been convicted.

SIMON SEMEL . I live at 8, Phoenix Street, Somers Town, and am a boot-makerâ€”on November Kith the prisoner came to my house and asked me to take a message to Ganzman to come to Portland Road Stationâ€”he came again on the 17th and asked me why the prosecutor did not meet himâ€”I said the prosecutor said he was very busy and could not leave his placeâ€”the prisoner then asked me to go and tell the prosecutor to come out and see himâ€”I told him I could not ran about taking messages for him, and he said he would pay me a day's wages, as he was a detectiveâ€”I then went with him to the prosecutor's shop, and told the prosecutor to come out and see the prisonerâ€”the prosecutor said he could not come outâ€”the prisoner then said, "Tell him I am a detective and must not show my face inside where there are so many people"â€”the prosecutor then came out and saw the prisoner at the side door, and the prisoner said to him, "Are you going to give me the Â£10?" If you cannot afford to give me Â£10 give me Â£2 a week, as you have two restaurants"â€”the prosecutor said, "I have done nothing to give you money for"â€”the prisoner said. "You know I am a detective; I can protect you, and you can do what you like"â€”they both walked to the railway station, Gray's Inn Road, and I saw the prisoner pull out some papers from his pocketâ€”he said to the prosecutor, "I have got you down in the papers, and if you will not give me the money I will put you away"â€”further up they were talking together and came up to a policeman, and the prosecutor said, "Arrest me with the prisoner, and I will go to the station and explain what I mean"â€”we all went to the station together.

Cross-examined. I have known you three yearsâ€”you never said what my day's wages were to beâ€”you said, "A detective must not show his face when there are too many people about"â€”I do not know what sort of people there would be in the prosecutor's place who would be frightened of a detective going inâ€”I do not know what papers you producedâ€”I have not received Â£5 for giving evidence, nor five farthingsâ€”I do not keep a brothelâ€”I was convicted six years ago of selling a ship's card to America; it was not genuine, and I had three monthsâ€”it is not true that if anyone wants a witness I am willing to become one so long as I get paid.

Re-examined. Since the prisoner was arrested he has been to my shop to see meâ€”I told him I did not want to see him any moreâ€”he said, "Simon, I want you to be kind and do me no harm. I want you as a witness, so do not go against me, and do not say anything against me"â€”I said I did not want himâ€”I do not keep a brothel, I work hard for my living as a boot maker.
ALEXANDER MACKAY (Police Sergeant 4 E.R.) I received a warrant for the prisoner's arrest on November 18thâ€”I found him at 97, Williams

Street, Regent's Parkâ€”I told him he would be arrested for falsely repre
senting himself to be a police constableâ€”he was also given into custody on this charge, and I issued a subpoena for the sergeant who was there and the constable who arrested him to come to this Court and give evidence to-dayâ€”the present charge was not properly gone into until the day after his arrest, but I understand the constable is not here, as he is suffering from enteric feverâ€”in answer to the charge the prisoner said, "That is what they charge me for, is it?"â€”the Magistrate dropped that charge and proceeded with this charge.
Cross-examined. Max Lewis was with me when I arrested youâ€”you did say something about their wanting to have their revengeâ€”I found no papers on you.

The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate. "I have witnesses to prove everything. Last Monday afternoon I was standing at the corner of Euston Road waiting for a 'bus, and the prosecutor and Max Lewis and several others came up. The prosecutor struck me and I went to a policeman for protection. The prosecutor said to the policeman, That man wants money of me.' Max Lewis said, 'You make me pay Â£50 fine; I do not care, I can afford to spend another Â£100, I will put you away.' I went to Bow Street Police Station to complain, and in the meantime the prosecutor took out a warrant against me for falsely pretending to be a police constable because I had informed against him, and when I find out anything wrong I will inform again. I do not make a living by informing. I am a tailor by trade. The Inspector was at my place several times."

The "prisoner, in his defence on oath, said that nearly three months ago he gave information against Max Lewis for keeping a gambling club, who was fined Â£50, and since then he had been threatened several times by the prosecutor, Max Lewis, and others.

ABRAHAM BLAVOTSKI . I saw the prosecutor standing at the corner of King's Crossâ€”I asked him what he was doingâ€”he said he was waiting for a 'bus to go homeâ€”I then went away about ten yards and saw two or three people come up to him and strike him on the chest and take him to the constable.

Cross-examined. I did not see him with Ganzman and Semelâ€”I did not hear what was saidâ€”I did not go with the prisoner to ask the prosecutor not to give evidenceâ€”I do not think the prisoner was struck for the purposeâ€”they got hold of him to take him to the policeman.

WILLIAM PUGSLEY (Police Inspector E.) I first saw the prisoner in July, when he came to me and complained of having been swindled in a gambling club, and said that the prosecutor and Max Lewis had offered him money not to make complaints against themâ€”I took a statement from him and applied for a warrant to raid the club, and the prisoner gave evidence in that caseâ€”after that I had to protect him for some timeâ€”I know that the prosecutor keeps a reputed gambling house, and I have had several complaints about itâ€”I know nothing about Semel except what I have heard in connection with this case.
Cross-examined. I have accepted evidence from the prisoner in cases,

and have paid him for itâ€”I am not hoping that the prosecutor will get convicted, but if I can get evidence I shall certainly proceed against himâ€”I have had complaintsâ€”the prisoner has not had instructions to get evidenceâ€”I do use him to obtain evidence with regard to gambling clubsâ€”it is not his business, he is a working tailorâ€”I have seen him workingâ€”lie has once been a witness, and on other occasions he has given me information, and I have paid him for itâ€”as far as I know, he has not been convicted.

(Police Sergeant 32 E.) On the first occasion there was no charge made of demanding moneyâ€”it was in consequence of some subsequent information that the prisoner had represented himself to be a detective, that the warrant was grantedâ€”if there had been a charge of demanding money by menaces on the first occasion I should have detained him, but no such charge was made.
Cross-examined. I do not know Semelâ€”he was not at the police station.
NOT GUILTY .

83.
GOTTFRIED JORDAN (50) and
JOHN CAMERON (52)
, Stealing a sable tie, the property of
Harrod's, Limited.

CECILIA MAYHEW . I am an assistant in the fur department of Harrod's Storesâ€”on November 18th, about 1.30 p.m., I was in the fur departmentâ€”Miss Wright was at the umbrella counter next to meâ€”she helps me to sell the fursâ€”I saw the prisoner Jordan speak to herâ€”the prisoner Cameron was standing a little way off near the stand where the sable ties areâ€”I said to Cameron. "Arc you being served?"â€”he said in an undertone and indistinctly, "Yes"â€”he had a sable tie in his hand value Â£48, the only one we had at that priceâ€”Jordan went from the counter where he had been speaking to Miss Wright and stood beside me and Cameronâ€”he said, "That gentleman is with me"â€”I left them and went to pack my parcelsâ€”a minute or two afterwards Jordan followed Miss Wright to the next counterâ€”Cameron had goneâ€”Jordan remained about two minutes after
wards and leftâ€”about an hour afterwards Mr. Smith went to serve a customer and we both looked for the tie but could not find itâ€”I went away from 1.45 to 2.15, no other customer came in before I leftâ€”I identified the prisoners on November 18th or 19th at the police-station from other men, without any doubt.

LETITIA WRIGHT . I am an assistant in the umbrella department at Harrod's Storesâ€”on November 18th I saw Jordan near the fur standâ€”I asked him if I could show him any fursâ€”he said, "I want a martin tie for a lady"â€”I went to where the ties were hanging on bracketsâ€”I took some down and tried one onâ€”he said, "Yes, that is very nice, but that is not quite the style"â€”I went over to the glass counter, where there were some more martin tiesâ€”looking at them Jordan said, "I want a double fur"â€”he had a cold, and it was difficult to hear what he said, I had to

bend quite close to him to know what he wantedâ€”he talked about ties, and said, "That is not a double fur; you know what ladies are if they make up their minds they won't have it"â€”after that he said, "Thank you very much for the trouble you have taken, I will bring the lady to-morrow" and went awayâ€”I saw another man standing near whom I cannot recogniseâ€”I was on duty the next day and the day afterâ€”Jordan did not come back, I did not see him again till he was passing into the dock at Westminster Police Courtâ€”I knew he was the same manâ€”this was on the ground floor.

THOMAS SMITH . I am a salesman in the fur department at Harrod's Storesâ€”on November 18th I relieved Miss Mayhew from 1.45 till 2.15 p.m.â€”during that time no customer came to that counterâ€”about 2.30 a lady cameâ€”I showed her some sable tiesâ€”I looked for one at the price of Â£48 10s., but could not find itâ€”I spoke to Miss Mayhew, and we both looked for itâ€”I had seen it about 1.15 when I went to dinner.

Cross-examined by Cameron. Customers do not pass the fur stand, they pass along the centre of the shop to go out at the doorâ€”no one could have taken the fur without my seeing them, the table is some way off the doorâ€”I was at my counter all the timeâ€”I was not busy at that hour.

EDWARD REANY (Detective Inspector, Harrod's Stores.) Between 1 and 2 p.m. on November 18th I saw Cameron standing close to the fur counterâ€”afterwards when he was charged he said he had never been to Harrod's Stores in his life.

ROBERT FULLER (Detective Officer.) On November 25th I saw the prisoners at Westminster Police Courtâ€”they were wearing frock coatsâ€”I examined Cameron's coatâ€”he had a continuous pocket in the lining of the coat with hooks and eyesâ€”Jordan's coat was the same, except that it had no hooks or eyes, and the lining was ripped open.

p.hi: The prisoners desired that their coats should be examined, and on Jordan's coat the lining was torn at the bottom so that anything would drop through; they both stated that they knew nothing of the theft, and that hundreds of people passed through the department.

div1.p: GUILTY .

p.hi: There were two other indictments far similar, offences against them.

div1.p:
Jordan had been previously convicted. JORDANâ€”
Seven years' penal servitude;
CAMERONâ€”
Three years' penal servitude.

84.
CORNELIUS MARINUS VAN DER VOORDE ,
Being a director of a public company, viz.,
The Union Preserving Company, Limited, fraudulently applying to his own use and benefit Â£16 1s. 3d., and omitting to enter in the ledger of that company Â£16 1s. 3d.
MESSRS. ELLIOTT and WILLIS Prosecuted, MR. MUIR Defended.

hi.rs: The Jury being-unable to agree were discharged without giving a verdict, and the trial was postponed to next Session.

p.hi: Before J. A. Rentoul, Esq., K.C.

div1.p:
85.
JOHN ANDERSON (60)
, Feloniously forging and uttering an order for the payment of Â£86 10s. with intent to defraud.

PAUL GASTAVE WAUER . I am a licensed victuallerâ€”in February, 1901, I kept the Carlton Tavern, Kilburnâ€”I know the prisoner as a customerâ€”on Saturday, February 8th, he came in and produced a cheque drawn by a John Rawlinson upon the Lombard Street branch of Lloyds Rank for Â£86 10s., and asked me to cash itâ€”he said that it had been given him by an architect on account of some cottages he was building at Crickle
woodâ€”I told him I could not cash it, but lent him Â£6 on itâ€”on the Monday we went together to Mr. Rawlinson's office, 65, Chancery Lane, to have the cheque made openâ€”the prisoner went upstairs, but came back and said Mr. Rawlinson was outâ€”we went and had a drink and then returned, after which he said Mr. Rawlinson was out for the day, and would I pay it into my bankâ€”I consented to do so, and paid him another Â£14â€”he gave me a receipt for Â£20â€”I saw him write itâ€”I paid the cheque into my bank, but it was returned marked, "Please state on what account drawn"â€”I then went to Lloyds Bank and also to see Mr. Rawlinson, and in conse
quence of what they told me I communicated with the policeâ€”I applied for a warrant and it was granted.

Cross-examined by the prisoner. You were a regular customer for about three weeksâ€”you used the saloon barâ€”I cannot produce anyone who saw you thereâ€”I have been in the public-house trade for seven yearsâ€”I have never preferred a criminal charge against anyoneâ€”a man was taken to the police station for stealing a dog, but he returned it, and he was not charged.

JOHN RAWLINSON . I am an architect and surveyor of 65, Chancery Laneâ€”I have no account at Lloyds Bankâ€”the cheque produced for Â£86 10s. is not mineâ€”I do not know the prisonerâ€”I have never employed him to build any cottages for me.
Cross-examined. The signature on the cheque is not mineâ€”it is a slight resemblance of mineâ€”I do not know the prosecutor.

BRUCE PRINGLE . I am a clerk at Lloyds Bank, 72, Lombard Streetâ€”the cheque (Produced) was presented at our bank on February 12th, 1901, and returned unpaidâ€”we have no account in the name of John Rawlinsonâ€”the cheque form is one issued by our bank to Captain Martineau.
Cross-examined. The cheque was presented to us through the London and South Western Bank.

FRANCIS MARTINEAU . I live at 72, Warwick Gardens, W., and am a captain in the Militiaâ€”in April, 1899, I desired to let my house and adver
tised it in the Daily Telegraphâ€”the prisoner called and was shown into the smoking roomâ€”I keep my cheque book in a drawer of a writing table in that roomâ€”he was left alone for about five minutesâ€”the next morning I looked at my cheque book and found that seven forms had been ex
tractedâ€”this cheque is one of them, I have the counterfoil belonging to itâ€”I identified the prisoner at Marylebone police courtâ€”I am positive he is the man I saw at my house.

Cross-examined. I only saw you for about five minutes, and it is three and a half years agoâ€”you called about five o'clock or 5.30 p.m.â€”I look at my cheque book nearly every morning as I draw cheques nearly every dayâ€”I said at the police court that you were the man to the best of my

belief, but that was only a form of speech, and by that I meant that you were the manâ€”I was not at home when you first called, but my wife showed you over the houseâ€”I saw you in the dining roomâ€”you were shown into the smoking room first by the servant, previous to my wife seeing youâ€”I had no hesitation in picking you outâ€”I think I could identify any of the other men I saw at the police court.

THOMAS HENRY GURRIN . I carry on business at 59, Holborn Viaductâ€”I have made a study of handwritingâ€”I have given evidence at this and other Courts for eighteen yearsâ€”to the best of my belief this receipt for Â£20 and the cheque for Â£86 10s. were written by the same person.â€”(The prisoner here wrote a receipt.)â€”there are little things in this which lead me to suspect it is the same writing.

CHARLES WALKER (234 E.) On November 10th, about noon, I was on duty outside Gray's Inn Road police station, when the prosecutor spoke to meâ€”in consequence of what he said I followed him and saw him shake hands with the prisoner, who appeared to be reading the advertisements on a hoarding, and heard him say, "Halloa, when are you coming to see me"; the prisoner replied, "One of these days"â€”from what I heard I told the prisoner that I should take him into custody for defrauding the prosecutorâ€”lie made no replyâ€”I took him to Gray's Inn Road police station, and then to Harrow Road station, and handed him over to Detec
tive Hedley.
Cross-examined. At the station you said you did not know the man, and again when you were charged.
Re-examined. I saw the two men shake handsâ€”the prisoner appeared to know the prosecutor then.

PAUL GUSTAVE WAUER (Re-examined.) I applied for the warrant imme
diately after I discovered I had been defraudedâ€”it has been standing for a year and nine monthsâ€”I had known the prisoner for about sixteen months before he came to the Carlton Tavernâ€”I saw him outside the Holborn Town Hall, Theobald's Road.
JOHN HEDLEY (Detective H.) About 1 p.m. on November 10th I saw the prisoner detained at Harrow Road police stationâ€”I read the warrant to him and he said. "I do not know the man."

GUILTY .
Judgment respited.

86.
JOE ROSENBERG (40),
PLEADED GUILTY to
unlawfully taking
Yetta Domashewski, an unmarried girl under sixteen, out of the possession of and against the will of her father.
Nine months' hard labour.

87.
GEORGE SWINEY (49)
, Attempting to steal a gelding, a set of harness, and a hansom cab, the property of
Thomas Brickland; and a whip, waterproof, apron, and rug, the property of
Robert Walter Cook.

ROBERT WALTER COOK , I am a cab driver of 8, Cardigan Street, Shep
perton Roadâ€”on November 30th, about 10 p.m., I drove into Cannon Street Stationâ€”I left my cab for about three minutes to go to the urinalâ€”when I returned I saw the railway constable standing beside the cab and the prisoner on the dickey preparing to drive awayâ€”the constable
asked me if it was not my cab; I said, "Yes"; and the prisoner said it was hisâ€”he eventually got down and I gave him into custodyâ€”I did not leave my cab in his charge.
Cross-examined. You did not speak to meâ€”you did not have a cab in the station yard.

CHARLES RICHARDSON (S.E. and C.R. Constable.) I was on duty in the station yard, Cannon Street, at about, 10 p.m. on November 30thâ€”I saw the prisoner loitering about and ordered him awayâ€”he returned at 10.15, and proceeded to the prosecutor's cab; he took the nose bag off and fastened it to the rear of the cab, and then mounted the dickeyâ€”he put the rug round him and was in the act of driving awayâ€”I knew it was not his cab and stopped him, and asked him what he was doingâ€”he said, "It is my cab, I have a right to be here"â€”the prosecutor then came upâ€”I asked him if the prisoner had a right to be on the cab, he said, "No"; I said, "What are you going to do?"â€”he gave him into custodyâ€”I handed him over to 506 City.
Cross-examined. There were only two cabs in the yard, and the other was occupied by another man.

CHAS. WESTERN (506 City). On November 30th, about 10.30 p.m., the prisoner was given into my custody by Richardsonâ€”he said, "If I was there an hour and a half before, I should have got away with it all right"â€”he had been drinking, but was not drunk.
Prisoner's defence. "My cab was in the station yard, and I mistook the prosecutor's cab for mine."

GUILTY .
Discharged on his own recognisances.

88.
THOMAS BREADMORE (25)
, Unlawfully obtaining two dead pigs by false pretences, from
Edward Hargreaves, with intent to defraud.

EDWARD HARGREAVES . I am in the employ of Charles Pervis and Co., 270, Central Marketsâ€”on November 14th I sold six pigs to Mr. Stone, a customerâ€”they were to be taken by Mr. Tidd, a carrierâ€”he has a number of men in his employâ€”his men took four away, and the prisoner the remaining twoâ€”he came into the shop and said, "On for Stone"â€”I asked him if he was working for Tidd, the carrierâ€”he said, "Yes"â€”Mr. Tidd afterwards applied for the two pigs, and I told him I had sent themâ€”I then communicated with the policeâ€”on the 28th I was with Detective Burgeâ€”I saw the prisonerâ€”as soon as he saw us he ran awayâ€”I followed and caught himâ€”I said, "I want you"; he said, "What for?"I said, "For those two pigs you had out of our shop"; he said, "I was working for the Great Western Railway on that day"â€”I have no doubt that he is the man that came for the pigs.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I know you well as a porter in the marketâ€”on the 28th I did not speak to you in the market; you ran out.

HENRY TIDD . I am a meat carrier, of 9, Victoria Terrace, Upper Tolling
ton Parkâ€”I carry meat for Mr. Stoneâ€”he has no van of his ownâ€”on November 14th I had an order from him for six pigsâ€”I only got fourâ€”I sent for the other two, and they said they had been sentâ€”I know the
prisoner by sightâ€”I have occasionally employed himâ€”I did not employ him on this occasion.
Cross-examined. Mr. Stone's name is not on my van.
PERCY GRIFFITHS . I am employed by Pervis and Co., of 270. Central Marketâ€”I was in the shop on November 14th, when the prisoner came in and asked for two pigs for Mr. Stone.
Cross-examined I have been employed by Messrs. Pervis one year and four months.

ROBERT BURGE (Market Constable.) On November 18th I received information of the robberyâ€”I was on duty on the 28thâ€”I saw the prisoner, and kept him under observationâ€”I then went and fetched Hargreavesâ€”when the prisoner saw us he ran awayâ€”we gave chase, and he was eventually caught and taken into custodyâ€”he was a licensed porter; he was licensed in 1898, but he has not renewed his licence since 1900.
Cross-examined. I never spoke to you in the market.
Prisoner's defence. I was commissioned by Mr. Stone to fetch the pigs.

GUILTY .
Two years' hard labour.

89.
JOHN FINCH (21)
, Robbery with violence, with another person unknown, on
Thomas Strickson, and stealing a watch, his property.

THOMAS STRICKSON . I am a lift attendant, of 10, Malmesbury Roadâ€”on November 16th, about 2.30 p.m., I was in Middlesex Street in a crowd watching a man selling vaseline, when all of a sudden I felt a jerk at my watch chainâ€”I turned round, and the prisoner turned round also, and walked awayâ€”when he saw I was following him he turned round and asked me what I wantedâ€”I told him he had my watchâ€”he said, "No, I have not; search me; fetch a policeman; if you don't go away I'll punch your jaw"â€”I saw a policeman a little way off and said, "Here is one"â€”the prisoner then turned round and ran in the opposite direction, and I saw him pass the watch to another manâ€”I caught hold of the other man, and they both hit me in the faceâ€”the watch is worth about 10s.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. I did not see you take my watch, but I felt it, and you turned round and walked off immediatelyâ€”I saw you hand it to another man.

WILLIAM DARDNELL (2 H.R.) On November 16th, about 3 p.m, I was on duty in Middlesex Streetâ€”I saw the prisoner running, and heard cries of "Stop him"â€”I chased him about fifty yardsâ€”he doubled round some barrows, and was afterwards stopped by two men and handed over to meâ€”the prosecutor then came up and gave him into custody.
GUILTY . He then

PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony at Clerken
well on February 4th, 1902, and another conviction was proved against him.
Three years' penal servitude.

90.
JAMES MARKS (40)
PLEADED GUILTY to
assaulting
Albert Helson, a constable, in the execution of his duty. (See next case).

91.
JAMES MARKS was again indicted
for robbery with violence upon
Robert George Austin, and stealing a watch chain, his property.

ROBERT GEORGE AUSTIN . I live at 14, Almack Road, Claptonâ€”on November 14th, about 4 p.m., I was in the City Road, when I was suddenly knocked down and trampled uponâ€”I am unable to identify any of my assailants, but I identify the prisoner; he stole my chainâ€”two detectives then came to my rescue.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. I cannot say who threw me to the groundâ€”I am positive you are the man who snatched at my chain.

ALBERT HELSON (Detective M.) On November 14th, about 3.45, I was with McDonald in the City Roadâ€”I saw four or five men loitering about, and as the prosecutor came along, the prisoner and two other men knocked him downâ€”when he was on the ground the prisoner knelt upon his chest and took his watch-chainâ€”I seized him, and he struck me on my mouth, cutting my lip, and kicked me several timesâ€”the other men then rescued him and threw me to the groundâ€”I followed him, and he was eventually arrested by another officerâ€”as he was running I saw the chain in his handâ€”just previous to his being stopped he threw it awayâ€”it was found three doors from the garden in which he was arrestedâ€”when charged he said, "If I had known you were a bâ€”y copper I would have kicked your fâ€”g brains out, and don't think you will get off easy, as my pals will do you in if I don't"â€”he did not know me; my division is in Southwark.

Cross-examined. I can swear that you knocked the prosecutor down and took his chainâ€”I was about four or five yards away at the timeâ€”I struck you twice, but not till after your resistanceâ€”McDonald is a col
league of mine.

WILLIAM MCDONALD (Detective M.) On November 14th, about 3.45, I was with Helson in the City Roadâ€”I saw the prosecutor thrown down by the prisoner and two or three other menâ€”there was a crowd of sixteen or twenty altogetherâ€”I seized one man, but I got thrown down, and the men got away.
Cross-examined. You were getting the prosecutor's chain while one of your companions was punching himâ€”I should say it was 200 yards from where the robbery took place to where you were arrested.

LOUIS DENNETT (287 G.) On November 14th I was in Britannia Street, City Roadâ€”I heard whistles blown and saw the prisoner runningâ€”I followed him and caught him in a yard in Bearley Streetâ€”just before I arrested him I saw him throw something awayâ€”he said, "You have got the wrong man this time, guv'nor"â€”at the station he said, "I wish I had known you were a P.C., I would have kicked your fâ€”g brains out."
Cross-examined. I did not look for the chainâ€”the enquiries were taken up by a plain-clothes constable.
GUILTY . The Jury added that they thought the prisoner deserved the cat. He then

PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony at Clerkenwell on December 21st, 1897, and six other convictions were proved against him.
Twenty-five lashes with the cat, and
seven years' penal servitude for the robbery with violence, and
five years' penal servitude for the attack

p.hi: upon the constable, to run concurrently.
commended Helson and McDonald for their courageous conduct.

div1.p:
92.
CHARLES CLARK (30)
PLEADED GUILTY to
feloniously marrying
Elizabeth Harris, his wife being alive.
Eighteen months' hard labour.

93.
STANLEY GOLDING (39) and
ARTHUR THOMAS (16)
, Com
mitting an act of gross indecency with each other.
MR. FULTON Prosecuted, MR. WARBURTON Defended Golding.
NOT GUILTY .

94.
EMMA BYRON (24), otherwise
KITTY BYRON
, For the
wilful murder of
Arthur Reginald Baker.
MR. CHARLES MATHEW and MR. BODKIN Prosecuted; MR. DICKENS, K.C., MR. TRAVERS HUMPHREYS and MR. BOYD Defended.

p.hi: Francis Charles Reed, an assistant in the City Surveyor's Office, produced and proved a flan of Post Office Court, Lombard Street.

div1.p:
ADRIENNE LIARD . I am the landlady of 18, Duke Street, Portland Place; I let lodgingsâ€”the deceased came there by himself about July 21st; he occupied a room on the first floorâ€”at first he paid Â£1 1s. per weekâ€”about a week afterwards, the prisoner came and occupied the room with himâ€”she was not introduced to me, But when he took the room he said he wanted it for himself and his wife, who would be coming in a weekâ€”she was addressed as Mrs. Bakerâ€”in October the room was changed for a less expensive oneâ€”the deceased went out in the morningsâ€”I do not know if he went to business; he did not go out every morningâ€”the prisoner used to stop in the house a little later, and then go outâ€”on the night of Friday, November 7th, there was some noise in their roomâ€”next day I spoke to the prisoner about it, and the same day I gave the deceased notice to quitâ€”on Monday, November 10th, he came to me and had some conversation with me, and later in the morning the prisoner came and said she wished to apologise for the noise they had made in the night; she said, "You have given us notice and we have got to go"; I said, "Yes, you have got to go to
morrow Tuesday, but he will stop another week"â€”the deceased had asked me if he might stop for another week, and I agreed to itâ€”the prisoner said, "Well, next week you will hear something very dreadful"; I said, "What is it," and she said,'"Well, Madam, don't you tell him if I tell you, because he bangs me so," she then said there would be a divorce with him and his wifeâ€”I said, "As you are not his wife, why do you support all the ill-treatment he gives you"; she said, "I love him so"; I said, "Why don't you go to work"; she said, "I lost my character, and I cannot get any work now; he used to come alter me, and I lost the whole of my character"â€”I told her the deceased had spoken to me, and I said to her, "He has just told me you are not his wife, and you are no class," and that she would go next morning to her sister's, and that he would stop another week with meâ€”when I told
her that, she said, "He wants to send me to-morrow to my sister; all I know I see."

Cross-examined. I said before the Coroner that the deceased had been kicking up a row, that is correctâ€”at 7 p.m. on Friday, he was drunk, the prisoner was sober; she showed me her hat which he had torn, and all the bed was nearly on the floor and his stick as wellâ€”I have never seen her intoxicatedâ€”when I went into their room, I asked the deceased why all the things were on the floor; he did not say anything, but the prisoner said, "Oh, we have been playing millinery"â€”he was drunk nearly every dayâ€”the first thing in the morning the servant used to go and fetch brandy for him to drinkâ€”that habit existed practically all the time he was in my houseâ€”when the prisoner said, 'I cannot leave him because I love him," she spoke very earnestlyâ€”when I told her the deceased had said she was no class she said, "I am a brewer's daughter"â€”I said, "Is it possible, what do you live with a brute like him for?"â€”it was than that she said "Because I love him, and I have lost my character, and I cannot get an work"â€”I said, "Why are you always screaming like that"â€”she said, "Well, how can I help it when he comes and strangles me, and puts his hand on me like that; how can I help it"â€”I had not heard her screaming con
stantly, but I had that nightâ€”I asked her why she lived with a brute like that, because he was always knocking her downâ€”as soon as he came home, the quarrelling began, and then you heard a bangâ€”when he was sober, he was a perfect gentleman, but he was very seldom sober.
Re-examined. The deceased was drunk nearly every day from July to Novemberâ€”I have heard noises in their room before November 7th, but not screams.

ISABEL KINGETT . I am servant to Madam Liard, at Duke Streetâ€”I used to go there in the day time and leave about 8 p.m.â€”I have been there since Januaryâ€”on November 10th, the prisoner wanted to speak to Madam Liardâ€”about 11.15 a.m. they had a conversationâ€”I then saw the prisoner coming downstairs,; she said to me, "I have told Madam all about myself and Mr. Baker, and now I will go and interview Mr. Baker"â€”she seemed very excited; I did not see her again that morning.

Cross-examined. I took up their breakfast that morning; they seemed on good terms then, and also on the previous morningâ€”when the prisoner said she was going to interview the deceased there was emotion, in her voiceâ€”she was always sober; the deceased was exactly the opposite, but when he was sober he seemed very fond of her, and she seemed to be very fond of him, although he treated her very badlyâ€”she did not eat her breakfast on the 10th; they had their breakfast taken up to their bedroom.

RAPHAEL LIARD . I am the son of Madam Liard, of Duke Streetâ€”I have been living there for some timeâ€”on November 10th, about 11.45 a.m., I saw the prisoner going out of the house; she was in a hopeless condition, and was crying.

Cross-examined. As she was going out she said. "Oh, my poor Isabel!" she mistook me for the servant; she was always sober, in spite of ill-usage she seemed very fond indeed of the deceased; he was a brute to her, and many times I have seen her on the staircase running away from himâ€”I have
heard her many times say that he was going to kill herâ€”he was drunk nearly every dayâ€”I cannot say if he seemed fond of her when he was sober, because he did not speak much.

JAMES MOORE . I am a cutler and silversmith of 211, Oxford Streetâ€”I was in my shop on Monday, November 10th, about 12.30, when the prisoner came in and wanted to see some knivesâ€”I was about to show her an ordinary pocket knife, when she asked for a long or strong single-bladed knifeâ€”I am not certain which word she usedâ€”I then showed her a long two bladed knife, which had what is called a flush springâ€”I opened the long bladeâ€”I stooped down to look for another description of knife, and when I looked up she was trying to close the blade that I had openedâ€”I said, "Oh, you will not be able to close it, it has a lock"â€”she said, "Oh, I do not know, I have firm grip, see!" and suiting the action to the word she grasped me across the hand; she had a moderately firm grip for a young personâ€”I said, "Of course, you know best, but it is not a lady's knife; is it for your own use?" she said. "Yes; is it nice and sharp?"â€”I showed her another knife; this is it (Produced)â€”a flush spring knife has a spring which does not project as this one doesâ€”a projecting spring once in operation fixes the blade absolutely firm in the hasp of the knife, and can only be released by pressure of the springâ€”I said, "You will be able to manipulate this better, it has a projecting spring"â€”upon my showing her how to open it, she said, "Oh yes"â€”she asked the price of it, I told her 6s.â€”she asked me if I had not got one for about 5s.â€”I said no, and then I said, "I will let you have it for 5s. 6d., and eventually she bought it at that priceâ€”she again asked if it was nice and sharpâ€”I said, "Oh, yes"â€”I think sheâ€”paid me in silverâ€”I asked her if she would have it in paper, and she said, "Oh, no," and put it into her muff which she was carryingâ€”the knife was closed thenâ€”I had closed it before handing it to her; she then; left the shop.
Cross-examined. The police communicated with me on the morning of the 12thâ€”I am in the habit of serving in the shop myselfâ€”I have a moderately large business.

JOSEPH FRAYER . I live at 34, Warner Street, Barnsbury, and am a counter clerk at the Lombard Street Post Officeâ€”on Monday, November 10th, about 1.15 p.m., I was there behind the counterâ€”there are two entrances, one from King William Street, and the other from Lombard Streetâ€”about that time the prisoner came in by the King William Street entranceâ€”I had seen her before, she had been there before to send express messagesâ€”when she came in on November 10th, she said "Good morning" to me, and then went to one of the receptacles at which the public write telegramsâ€”I saw her writing on a telegraph formâ€”she then asked me for an envelopeâ€”I gave her one with an embossed stampâ€”she enclosed what she had written in the envelope and closed it and returned to the desk to address the envelopeâ€”she returned to the counter, and it being Lord Mayor's day I said to her, "Have you seen the Lord Mayor's Show"â€”she said she had no wish to see itâ€”I was called away from my desk and was absent about ten minutesâ€”the prisoner was at first calmâ€”I saw her later on when she called for her replyâ€”she had gone out of the office while I was.

awayâ€”when she came in again she said to me "Have you the reply"â€”as I had not accepted her express letter I referred her to the clerk who took it in my absenceâ€”the prisoner was then rather excitedâ€”when she first came in she seemed hurried.

Cross-examined. I was engaged with ordinary counter clerk's work when the prisoner first came in, but being Lord Mayor's day there was then nobody in the officeâ€”she gave her letter to another clerkâ€”when she came in the second time she was rather excited.

PHILLIP HENRY MORLEY . I am an overseer at the Lombard Street Post Officeâ€”I was there on Monday, November 10th, about 1.15 p.m., when the prisoner came in, and went to a telegraph desk and wrote some
thingâ€”she then handed me this envelope (Produced) addressed "Reg. Baker, Esq., Westralian Market, Stock Exchange"â€”(The message inside was,"Dear Reg., I want you a moment, importantly, Kitty")â€”she asked that it might be sent by express messengerâ€”the charge for that was 3 1/2d., which she paid for with a florin, and received the changeâ€”I handed the envelope to Mr. Chivers, a counter clerk in the officeâ€”I had seen the prisoner in the office several times beforeâ€”she had come there to send express letters in the same way.
Cross-examined. I should say the prisoner was perfectly sober.

ARTHUR STEPHEN CHIVERS . On November 10th I was a counter clerk at the Lombard Street Post Officeâ€”I was handed this envelope with an embossed stamp on it, to have it expressedâ€”I gave it to a messenger boy named Coleman, who went away with itâ€”I saw the prisoner at the office directly after 2 p.m.â€”she asked me if she might remain at the end of the counterâ€”I replied, "Certainly, Miss"â€”she appeared very worried and seemed to be brooding over some troubleâ€”she was leaning on her right elbow, which she rested on the counterâ€”as she was approaching the counter I noticed she had a muff, but when she came up to me it was below the counter, and I could not see it.
Cross-examined. I did not take much notice of the prisonerâ€”I cannot say which hand was in her muff.

WILLIAM ROBERT COLEMAN . I am a telegraph messenger at the Lombard Street Post Officeâ€”on Monday, November 10th, I received from Mr. Chivers an express message to deliverâ€”I took the envelope to the Stock Exchangeâ€”I left the post office about 1.24 p.m.â€”I could not get the letter to the addressee, as there was a considerable crowd it being Lord Mayor's dayâ€”I remained about fifteen minutes trying to deliver the messageâ€”I returned to the post office, where I arrived about 2.5 p.m.â€”I saw the prisoner thereâ€”I said to her, "I could not deliver the message as the gentleman is in the reading room"â€”she said, "Take it back again, and try and deliver it"â€”I went back and was successful in getting to the deceasedâ€”he opened and read the letter and returned with me to the post officeâ€”I think we got there about 2.30, but I did not notice the timeâ€”we both entered the post officeâ€”the prisoner was not in the office thenâ€”the deceased spoke to one of the clerks at the counter about some payment that was demanded for the extra waitingâ€”it was only 2d., I think, and he refused to pay itâ€”the deceased then left the office and immediately afterwards I saw the prisoner in the

office, but I did not see her come inâ€”I went out and spoke to the deceased, and he immediately returned with me to the post officeâ€”the prisoner was still there and I saw them in conversationâ€”I did not see them meet, as I went behind the counterâ€”I could not hear what they were sayingâ€”I saw them move towards the Lombard Street doorâ€”the deceased went first and the prisoner was about a yard behind himâ€”the deceased went out of the doorâ€”there are about three steps leading into the court outside the officeâ€”he went down the stepsâ€”the prisoner paused on the steps and then followed himâ€”I believe they were talking then, but I could not hear what they saidâ€”I saw what I thought was a knife in her handâ€”that was after she had paused and she had begun to go down the stepsâ€”I called out somethingâ€”I do not think the prisoner could hear what I saidâ€”when she got to the bottom of the steps she turned to her right and so went out of my sightâ€”she appeared to go fasterâ€”I did not see what happened nextâ€”I afterwards looked out of the King William Street door, and I saw the deceased lying up against the wall on the opposite side of the courtâ€”he was partly sitting and partly lyingâ€”he looked very whiteâ€”I did not see any bloodâ€”I do not know where the prisoner was.

Cross-examined. When the deceased went out of the post office the last time I do not know if he went out backwardsâ€”the door is a double swing doorâ€”he went down the steps, and I did not see him any moreâ€”I am not sure if the door was closed after the prisoner had gone outâ€”before I saw what I thought was a knife, the prisoner was evidently talking to some
body down at the bottom of the stepsâ€”when I say I saw something which I thought was a knife, I mean that I saw something flashâ€”I do not knowâ€”which hand it was in.
By the COURT. I called out after I saw the knife flashâ€”I am sixteen years old.

JOHN FINN . I am a clerk at the Lombard Street Post Officeâ€”I was there on November 10th, about 1.55 p.m.â€”I saw the prisoner on the top step leading to the post office door in Lombard Streetâ€”she looked through the glass door several timesâ€”after a few minutes' delay she came in and said to me. "When will that boy be back"â€”I went and asked a question and then returned to the prisoner and told her that owing to its being Lord Mayor's day the lad was probably delayed, and could not deliver the messageâ€”she remained in the office about fifteen or twenty minutes altogetherâ€”she seemed to be labouring under some sort of excite
mentâ€”she walked up and down the office and looked at the various notices on the wallsâ€”she leant on the counter at the telegraph end of the officeâ€”she had a muff in her left handâ€”Coleman returned almost as I was speaking to herâ€”he told her that he could not deliver the message, and she said, "Take it back, Mr. Baker will come at once when he knows I am waiting"â€”the boy went away again and the prisoner left the officeâ€”whilst she was away the deceased returnedâ€”I did not see Coleman come inâ€”after a short conversation he left the office by the Lombard Street, or north, doorâ€”almost as he left the prisoner came in by the same door and placed herself with her back to meâ€”I heard Mr. Dunn explain to her that there was 2d. due because Coleman had had to wait more than ten minutesâ€”she

replied, "All right, old boy, I am worth 2d."â€”I saw the deceased then come in by the Lombard Street doorâ€”he made straight for the prisonerâ€”he said something which I did not hear, and she said, "You must pay the 2d., pay it with this," and she put forward her right hand in which she had a florinâ€”she tried to put it into his waistcoat pocketâ€”before she took out the florin the deceased said, "I shall not," he backing towards the Lombard Street door; the prisoner followed him, holding the florin out all the time, and attempting to press it into his waistcoat pocketâ€”they went through the door where there are three stepsâ€”the deceased went down themâ€”the prisoner paused for a moment on the top of the steps and she then seemed to spring from the top steps in the direction of the posting boxes which are immediately outside the door on the right as you pass from the doorâ€”Coleman made an exclamationâ€”I did not go to the door; I remained behind the counter.

Cross-examined. My duty at the time was the sale of stampsâ€”I was about ten feet from the Lombard Street doorâ€”the prisoner leant both of her hands on the counter while she was waitingâ€”I should not like to swear she had both hands on the counter, but that was my impressionâ€”when she was on the steps I noticed she had a muff on her left handâ€”she went out at the same door that the deceased came in by, and he came in again about a minute after she had gone outâ€”my impression was that the deceased did not wish me to hear what he was sayingâ€”I am positive the prisoner tried to force the florin on the deceased with her right handâ€”I could not hear what passed between them when they were on the steps because the glass door was between us.

WILLIAM MARTIN DUNNE . I am a clerk in the Lombard Street Post Officeâ€”I was there shortly after two o'clock on November 10thâ€”I remember Coleman returning with the letter which he could not deliverâ€”the prisoner was in the office then; she told the boy to take the message back, which he didâ€”he returned shortly afterwards with the deceasedâ€”the prisoner had left the office thenâ€”I had some conversation with the deceased with reference to the extra charge created by the delay in delivering the messageâ€”I said to him, "There is 2d. to pay, owing to the delay in the delivery"; he said he would not pay it, it was nothing to do with him, and it was the business of the ladyâ€”he did not pay itâ€”the prisoner came in; I told her there was 2d. to pay; she said, "That is all right, old boy, I am worth 2d."â€”the deceased then came in and said to her, "You owe the post office some money, you had better pay it"â€”she said, "No, you pay it"â€”he said, "No, I will have nothing to do with it."â€”she pressed a silver coin on him and asked him to pay the 2d. with itâ€”he pushed his arm as she went to put it into his waistcoat pocketâ€”she seemed rather to insist upon giving him the coin, and he began to back towards the doorâ€”as he went out I heard her say, "I will go out, too"â€”the next thing I heard was an exclamation by Coleman.
Cross-examined. I did not hear all the conversation between themâ€”he spoke rather sharply; the prisoner was calmâ€”I do not know what passed between them on the steps.

ARTHUR STEWART WIELAND . I am an accountant of 10, Walbrookâ€”about 2.30 p.m. on November 10th, I was posting a letter in Post Office Court, which is outside the Lombard Street Post Officeâ€”this is a correct photograph of the boxesâ€”I saw the deceased standing against the letter
box next to the one in which I was posting my letterâ€”he had his back towards meâ€”I saw the prisoner standing on the post-office steps, pre
sumably they were talking, but my attention was not directed to them until I heard the man say rather loudly, "No, I will not," or "No, I can
not"â€”I heard the prisoner repeat a question rather imploringly, and then he replied in a more pronounced manner and loudly, "No, I will not"â€”the prisoner rushed off the steps towards himâ€”I did not see anything in her hand thenâ€”she had a muff on, I think, her right hand, but I am not sure which handâ€”she appeared to be buffeting him with both hands, first one side and then the other, and in a sort of regardless wayâ€”she used both hands, but I cannot particularise how they were used; she was striking very rapidlyâ€”it appeared to me to be on his headâ€”his back was turned towards her as though retreating, and I should say the blows fell more particularly on the right side of his headâ€”he continued to retreat to more than the middle of the court, and for five or six yardsâ€”the prisoner still continued to attack himâ€”when they reached past the clock I saw some
thing gleam in her handâ€”I then realised for the first time that it was a serious matterâ€”there were two blows very rapidly one after the other with what I thought was a hat pinâ€”I ran forward, but the second blow had fallen before I got up to where she wasâ€”he had turned his face to her, when he saw, I think, for the first time the knife in her handâ€”I think one of the blows fell on his head and the other on his shuolder, but it is difficult to decideâ€”he fell down, and I think the prisoner fell with him, as I found her on the ground when I got up to themâ€”a man named Lockie was holding the prisoner by the wristsâ€”I did not see a weapon lying on the groundâ€”as the deceased fell he was about a yard from the wall opposite the post officeâ€”that would be about as far as he could go in that direction.

Cross-examined. When Lockie was holding the prisoner she was trying to get at the body on the ground and was calling out, "Oh, Reggie, Reggie, let me kiss him!"â€”she seemed in great distressâ€”I only heard the conver
sation they had imperfectly, but I heard her ask him something imploringly, and then he said something angrilyâ€”I think she had got her muff on one of her handsâ€”I do not know definitely which hand, but I think the rightâ€”when she dashed down the step she simply buffeted him with both hands, the muff being in one of them, and she followed him down the court doing thatâ€”at that time I thought she was only doing what a woman in a bit of temper would do, simply hitting him over the head with her muff and hand together; there was no extreme passion shownâ€”my impression then was that she did not intend to hurt him at allâ€”I had my eyes riveted on her all the time; she could not at that time have got the knife from her pocketâ€”I suddenly missed the muff, whether it fell to the ground or not I do not know, but it had gone when I saw the knife in her handâ€”I think the knife was in the same hand that the muff had been inâ€”the
two blows which were administered with what I thought was a hat pin were a matter of a second.
Re-examined. While I was watching what was going on, I did not hear anything said about a knife.

WILLIAM HENRY LOCKIE . I am a labourer of 11, Cory Square, Com
mercial Roadâ€”I was passing along Post Office Court about 2.30 on Monday, November 10thâ€”I had entered at the King William Street end and was going towards Lombard Streetâ€”I was nearly through the court when I heard a cryâ€”I turned round; I saw the prisoner and the deceased near the wall opposite the post officeâ€”the deceased was the nearer to the wall; he had his back to the wall and the prisoner was in front of himâ€”I saw her hand come down twice with a knife in itâ€”one of the blows came down on the left side of the deceased's head and one towards his breastâ€”after the second blow the deceased slid down the wall on to the groundâ€”I ran across and caught hold of the prisoner's left handâ€”I heard the knife drop to the ground after I caught hold of her handâ€”someone picked it up and handed it to a constableâ€”it was a knife similar to this oneâ€”it was open when it was picked upâ€”while I had hold of the prisoner's hand she said, "Let me go to see Reggie, my dear Reggie"â€”I said, "No, you have done enough now"â€”I did not leave go of herâ€”I held her until the police cameâ€”I saw a straw hat on the ground which I thought was a woman's hatâ€”I did not see any hat belonging to the deceasedâ€”I saw a brown muff thereâ€”they were not far from the knife.
Cross-examined. I caught hold of her left hand and the knife was in her rightâ€”when she said, "My Reggie, my Reggie!" she seemed dazed and silly.

WALTER THOMAS HUNT (386 City.) On November 10th I was on duty near to and I was called to Post Office Court, where I saw the body of the deceased lying on the groundâ€”I at once sent for an ambulanceâ€”the prisoner was being held by Lockieâ€”I heard her call out, "Let me kiss my Reggie, let me kiss my husband"â€”a post-office clerk named Russell was in the court, and he handed me this knifeâ€”it was open at the timeâ€”I took the prisoner to the station with the knifeâ€”she did not say anything on the wayâ€”she was very excited, she kept trying to throw her arms about and wrench away from me.
Cross-examined. She was not trying to escape from me, but was in a state of great agitationâ€”she seemed slightly dazed.

EDWARD JOHN RUSSELL . I am a counter clerk at the Lombard Street Post Officeâ€”I was there on November 10th when the deceased and the prisoner were thereâ€”I heard Coleman say somethingâ€”I went out into the court in consequence of what he saidâ€”when I got outside, the deceased was lying on the ground on his right side in a huddled-up position on the far side of the courtâ€”I saw an open knife on the groundâ€”I picked it up and handed it to a constableâ€”before the police came I raised the deceased up, and as I did so a 2s. piece fell to the groundâ€”I noticed two wounds on his head, one over the left temple and the other over his right eyeâ€”there was some mud on himâ€”I did not think then that he was dead, and I endeavoured to restore himâ€”he was quite unconscious, and he never

recovered consciousnessâ€”my belief now is that he was then deadâ€”I noticed a slit in his jacket just above the breast, over the heartâ€”the prisoner was being held by Lockie when I went into the courtâ€”I heard her say, "Let me get to him, let me kiss my Reggie"â€”she was in a very excited condition.

FRANCIS ERNEST BAKER . I am employed on the Stock Exchange, and am a brother of the deceased, who was a member of the Stock Exchangeâ€”I saw him on November 10th about 2.5 p.m.; he was then in perfectly good healthâ€”at his request I gave him a florin.

JOHN MANN (526 City.) On the afternoon of November 10th I took the deceased to St. Bartholomew's Hospitalâ€”I was handed a florin which had been picked up by Russellâ€”I assisted to search the deceased in the hospital mortuaryâ€”I did not find a florin on the bodyâ€”I found a number of documents on him, and amongst them the envelope with the embossed stampâ€”there was no money on him.

FREDERICK FOX (City Police Inspector.) I was on duty when the prisoner was brought in at 2.45 p.m.â€”I subsequently learned that Mr. Baker was dead, and at 5 p.m. I told the prisoner that the man she had stabbed in Post Office Court was dead, and that she would be charged with murdering him by stabbing him several times about the body with a knife; that she need not make any answer to the charge, but whatever answer she made would be taken down in writing and used for or against herâ€”she said, "I killed him willingly, and he deserved it, and the sooner I am killed the better"â€”at 5.40 p.m. I again visited her in the cell, and she said, "In
spector, I wish to say something to you; I bought the knife to hit him but I did not know I was killing him."

Cross-examined. When she was brought to the station she was not in an extremely agitated condition but very excitedâ€”she was very firm and looked at you in a very determined mannerâ€”she did not have to be put to bedâ€”a bed was provided for her at 5 o'clockâ€”in the ordinary course she would not have a bed at all, but I thought this was an exceptional case, and that she could either sit or lie down or go to bed if she thought properâ€”she was not excited or agitated when she made the first statementâ€”I do not remember using the word "agitated" at the Police Courtâ€”I have made a mistake; I did not intend to say that she was not excited; what I meant was that she was not so much excited as when she was brought to the stationâ€”her second statement was, "I bought the knife to hit him, but I did not know I was killing him," not "I bought the knife; I hit him, but I did not know I was killing him"â€”I am quite positive about that statement; I wrote it down at the time.
Re-examined. She was not so firm at 5.40 as she was at 5 o'clock.
MATILDA COOPER . I am matron at Cloak Lane Police Stationâ€”I searched the prisoner and found on her a fur muff, a pawn ticket, 15s. 6d., and a bundle of letters.

JAMES FINLAY ALEXANDER . I am house surgeon at St. Bartholomew's Hospitalâ€”on Monday, November 10th, at 2.45 p.m., the dead body of. Arthur Reginald Baker was brought thereâ€”there were four wounds upon him; one about three inches long on the left side of the head, above and

in front of the ear, going down to the boneâ€”there was another bruised wound on the head above the right eye, which might have been caused by falling on the stone pavement, there was dirt on itâ€”there was a third wound about the third rib on the left side over the breast boneâ€”I probed that; it went down to the breast boneâ€”the fourth wound was over the left shoulder blade about three inches deepâ€”it did not penetrate the chestâ€”those wounds were such as would be caused by the knife produced.

FREREDICK GORDON BROWN , M.R.C.S. I am surgeon to the City Policeâ€”on November 12th I made a post-mortem examination of the body of Arthur Reginald Baker, and saw the four wounds which have been describedâ€”I agree with the last witness that the wound over the right eye was probably caused by a fall on some stone substanceâ€”there was dirt on each side of itâ€”the wound above the left ear was clean cut, and about three inches longâ€”it would not have caused deathâ€”part of the wound in the breast went clean through the breast bone into the aortaâ€”considerable force must have been used, and it was bound to have caused almost instantaneous deathâ€”the person who struck the blow must have been standing immediately in front of the deceasedâ€”he died of that woundâ€”there was also a wound on the right side of the left blade bone, going down towards and separating the muscles of the spineâ€”that blow must have been struck while the deceased was in a stooping or falling positionâ€”the blow on the chest would make him faint directly, and he would die almost immediatelyâ€”his liver was of normal weightâ€”there was no sign of prolonged drinking.

Cross-examined. The deceased's liver was not that of a drunkard, it was of normal weightâ€”the first wound was above the temple bone and the second in front of the chest, which was a fatal one, the third was inflicted as he was falling forward.

GUILTY, with the strongest possible recommendation to mercy by the Jury.
DEATH .

95.
ALFRED BRANSBY WALTER (17)
, Forging and uttering an order for the payment of Â£25 with intent to defraud.

SOLOMON PINCUS KONSKI . I am a furrier, of 34, Handforth Road, Brixtonâ€”the prisoner was lodging thereâ€”he went away on November 11th, and some time after I missed this cheque book (Produced.)â€”a number of the cheques are filled up in some one else's writingâ€”this cheque for Â£25 came out of my book; it is endorsed by a Mr. Cockertonâ€”I kept the cheque book in a locked drawer which had been broken open.

WINIFRED CHAMBERS . I live at 1, Beecham Place, and am book-keeper to Messrs. Joyce and Mathews, butchers, Brompton Roadâ€”on November 13th the prisoner brought this cheque for Â£25, endorsed by Mr. Cockerton, who I knew to be a customer of ours, and I gave him Â£25 in gold for itâ€”I did not know the prisoner; he asked me to oblige Mr. Cockertonâ€”the
cheque was sent to the bank and returned, marked"Cheque taken from a book which has been stolen."
THOMAS BARCLAY COCKERTON . I live at 7, Churton Place, and am a Local Government Board auditorâ€”this cheque for Â£25 is not endorsed by me or by my authorityâ€”I have no knowledge of the prisoner.

EDWARD WILLIAMS (Detective Sergeant B.)
