On November 13th, at 7 p.m, I received the prisoner, who was in custodyâ€”I searched him, and found in his overcoat pocket Â£10 10s. in gold, 19s. 6d. in silver, and 1s. 6d. in bronzeâ€”in a purse in his trousers pocket I found Â£5 in gold, and in a pocket book there were two Â£5 notes, and eight cheques filled up and en
dorsedâ€”he said, "I filled them in, and the endorsement is in my proper writing"â€”four of these cheques had been uttered that day and the day beforeâ€”he had a directory on him containing the names of customersâ€”he also had the key of a bedroom at the Hotel Cecil, where he had been staying that night and the night beforeâ€”there were also bills for clothing paid on the 13th, including one for Â£12 10s.

Cross-examined. The total amount obtained on cheques from Mr. Konski's book is Â£60â€”when he told me he had written out the cheques he did seem to be ashamed of himselfâ€”he refused his name and address or to say anything about himselfâ€”he seemed quite calm and said he did not want his parents to be disgraced.

THOMAS FRANCIS RAVEN , M.R.C.S., L.R.C.P. I practice at Broad
stairsâ€”I have known the prisoner since childhoodâ€”I know his family history, and there is insanity on both sides of the familyâ€”he is the son of Lieut.-Colonel Walter, and had a most excellent homeâ€”when at school he commenced stealing, and obtaining goods by false pretences and shammed illness to get off workâ€”there was no example before him to teach him how to steal or do anything of that sortâ€”he was sent to Dr. Langdon's home at Hampton Wick, and escaped from thereâ€”on March 11th, 1901, I and Dr. Biddell certified him to be of unsound mindâ€”this is the certificate (Produced)â€”he was then sent to Dartford Asylumâ€”on October 23rd, 1901, at Hastings, I again certified him to be insaneâ€”he was then charged at Hastings Quarter Sessions with fraudâ€”he was again sent to Dartford, and subsequently transferred to Haydock Lodge Private Asylum, and escaped from thereâ€”in July last at Sandwich I again certified him as insaneâ€”he was there charged with similar offencesâ€”he was sent back to Haydock Lodgeâ€”I describe him as a moral imbecile of dangerous characterâ€”he is quite incapable of controlling his moral impulsesâ€”he may know what is right, but he does what is criminally wrong without being able to help itâ€”he has threatened to stab his parents, and he may become dangerous at any timeâ€”he has a brother who is an idiot.

ERNEST WILLIAM WHITE , M.R.C.P. I am medical superintendent at Dartford Asylum, and Professor of Psychological Medicine at King's Collegeâ€”on March 11th, 1901, the prisoner was admitted under certificate to our institutionâ€”we have to make returns to the Commissioners of Lunacy, and on March 18th I made the following Return: (Read) "He is insane and suffering from mania, weak-minded, impulsive, dangerous, and

actually suicidal; lacks moral tone, and is mischievous"â€”he got better under our care and was discharged on May 21st, 1901, on condition that his father should send him to sea, under the strong moral control of a skipper in the Merchant Serviceâ€”he was re-admitted to our institution on October 23rd, and I then formed the opinion that an asylum was the best place for himâ€”he was transferred to Haydock Lodge on January 29th, 1902, at the request of his relatives.
Cross-examined. I do not think he can appreciate the seriousness of his acts or the penalties attached thereto.

p.rs: GUILTY, but not responsible for his actions.
p.hi: To be detained during His Majesty's pleasure. There were five other indictments against him.

div1.p:
96.
HERBERT BAMFORD (48),
PLEADED GUILTY to that
he being entrusted as an attorney with Â£100, converted the same to his own use.
Twelve months' hard labour.

97.
CHARLES OWEN BANKS (23) and the said
HERBERT BAM
FORD ,
Conspiring to obtain from
James Toope and
Thomas Henry Tomkins by false pretences. No evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

98.
JONATHAN EASTWELL (48),
GEORGE SMITH (30), and
JAMES KEEGAN (32)
, Unlawfully attempting to break into certain premises. Second count, Being found by night with housebreaking im
plements in their possession.

WILLIAM INGRAM (272 City.) On November 21st, about 12.40 a.m., I was on duty in Fenchurch Street, and saw Keegan standing thereâ€”shortly afterwards I saw Eastwellâ€”they remained in conversation two or three minutesâ€”shortly afterwards Smith came round from the direction of Snow Hill, and they walked towards Blackfriarsâ€”Eastwell followed them on the west side, but crossed over and joined them about fifty yards onâ€”there is a shop with a portico, and there is a gate before you get to the doorâ€”the gate is outside the porchâ€”they stood there some minutes, and Keegan went to make water somewhereâ€”they stood outside the porch; Eastwell was apparently watchingâ€”Smith came backâ€”a constable was coming up and Keegan and Smith went to the porchâ€”the other constable waited while I went across the road to Harp Alley and asked what they were doingâ€”Keegan said, "That is my business"â€”I said, "That will not satisfy me, I shall take you to the station"â€”I went to 23, Farringdon Street and found marks on the gate and door, and the letter-box brokenâ€”I saw the constable pick up this fileâ€”they were taken before the Inspector and charged, and another small file was found in Keegan's pocket.
Cross-examined by Eastwell. You did not ask me the nearest way to Guildhall, or ask me to direct youâ€”I did not fetch you out of a cell, but another man didâ€”nothing was found on you.

Cross-examined by Smith. You and Keegan were walking down Far
ringdon
Street together on the Snow Hill sideâ€”I saw someone go and get a light under the Viaduct.

DICK MOSS (341 City). On December 1st, at 1 a.m., I was on duty at Snow Hill Police Station, when the prisoners were brought in and chargedâ€”I was watching them, and saw Keegan move his right arm and put it behind himâ€”I looked behind the chair where he was seated, but could not see anythingâ€”when he was in the dock I felt on the floor and found this large file (Produced)â€”I also saw the small one produced from his right hand coat pocket when he was searched.

FREDERICK WILKINSON (264 City.) On December 1st, about 1 a.m., I noticed the three prisoners standing outside No. 23, Farringdon Streetâ€”Keegan and Smith went into the dark towards No. 23â€”they came out again and joined Eastwellâ€”Keegan and Smith went back into the dark again and remained some timeâ€”they came out again and joined Eastwell, and they all crossed over the road to Harp Alley, where they were arrested.
Cross-examined by Eastwell. You did not cross over to themâ€”you all three crossed over from 23, Farringdon Street to Harp Alley.
Cross-examined by Smith. You stood outside No. 23, Farringdon Street, close to the kerb.
Cross-examined by Keegan. When you were detained you said you were not there at the time.

WILLIAM PENFOLD (41 City.) On December 1st, about 1 a.m., I watched the prisoners' movementsâ€”Eastwell was on the right-hand side of Far
ringdon Street, facing No. 23â€”the other two men were on the foot
way outside No. 23â€”Eastwell crossed the road and joined the others and they walked a few yards towards Blackfriars Bridge, and then they crossed back to Harp Alleyâ€”I was exposed to view and concluded that Eastwell had given the others information, and I instructed the other officers to prevent them getting awayâ€”I examined the premises at No. 23, and found the tin letter box had been torn off the gate, and there were recent marks on it of someone having put a foot thereâ€”I found four marks on the door corresponding with the large end of the large file producedâ€”I asked the prisoners what they were waiting about for, Keegan said he had a perfect right to be in the streets if he likedâ€”I again asked him what he was doing and he said, "That is my business"â€”I then asked Eastwell what his occupation was, he said he was a waterside labourer out of work, and had come to look for a jobâ€”I said "Where have you been to look for a job?"Keegan said, "I do not see why my friend should answer your questions; if you want to know anything, take us down to Bridewell"â€”Smith said, "I am a printer, and live at Clerkenwell; that is all you are going to get out of me, governor"â€”they were all taken to Snow Hill Station.

Cross-examined by Smith., I gave evidence about the letter box on the second hearing before the Magistrateâ€”there was only evidence of arrest taken on the first hearingâ€”you were all charged about twenty minutes after you were brought inâ€”the Inspector in charge of the district was not at the station, and we had to send for him, and that caused the delay.
JOHN JACOB ELLIS . I am a tailor, of 23, Farringdon Streetâ€”on the

Saturday previous to this occurrence I left the premises safe and well locked upâ€”the front door, gate, and letter box were perfectly safeâ€”on the Monday morning following, my younger brother met me coming along and informed me of the occurrence, and I saw four or five marks on the door, and the letter box was off the gate.
Cross-examined by Keegan. I cannot vouch for anythingâ€”no doubt somebody did itâ€”who it was I do not know.

p.hi: Smith, in his defence, said that it was not possible to make marks on the door and wrench off the letter box in a few minutes under the observation of the police, and that if the police saw them get over the gate why were they not arrested then?
Keegan's defence: If the police saw us in the gateway why were we not arrested then?

div1.p: GUILTY .

99.
SAMUEL HENRY WHITING (17), and
GEORGE HILLMAN (17)
Wilful and corrupt perjury.

WHITING
PLEADED GUILTY . (See page 4.)

RICHARD JAMES . I am a tobacconist at 42, Peacock Street, Newington Buttsâ€”I have been employed at Wishart's, Panton Street, Haymarket, for 4 1/2 to 5 yearsâ€”I have lived at 42, Peacock Street two or three years with my parents, and brothers and sistersâ€”it is a tenementâ€”on Saturday, October 25th, I left to go to see the illuminations about 7.30, with two friends, Harry Clarke and Richard Jinksâ€”they remained in my company till about 10.30, when we got separated in Leicester Squareâ€”we stood speaking to Mr. Enright, who keeps the stage door of the Empire Theatre, before we were separatedâ€”Enright joined me about 11.20â€”we went down to Parliament Street and I left him at the corner of Bridge Street at about 12.15â€”I was quite soberâ€”about 12.15 I started to go home from Westminster Bridge along the Westminster Bridge Roadâ€”at the corner of Kennington Road and the Lambeth Road, five or six fellows came from the Lambeth Road, caught hold $$$ my arm and took me along the Lambeth Roadâ€”they said if I made a noise they would murder meâ€”I was too terrified to make any noiseâ€”they took my overcoat off, they set me down on the steps of the Lambeth Baths, cut the laces and took my boots offâ€”they took a signet ring from my finger, and my watch and chain from my waistcoat pocketâ€”in my overcoat was my tobacco and pipe, and in my trousers pocket some moneyâ€”they went towards the Lambeth Roadâ€”I called after themâ€”the next morning I made a complaintâ€”I afterwards gave evidence against Abrahams at this Courtâ€”Hillman gave evidence for the defenceâ€”I think I heard part of itâ€”it is not true that I took off my coat at a coffee stall and put it on
the side or wheel of the stall, nor that my watch was in my overcoat pocket, nor that I tried to take off my boots and fell, nor that I was drunkâ€”I had two coats on.

FRANCIS WILLIAM POLLARD . I am an officer of this Courtâ€”I produce the bill of indictment found by the grand jury on November 17th, against Ernest Alfred Abrahams for robbery, and receiving stolen goodsâ€”Abrahams was tried on that indictment before the Recorder on November 17th and 18th, convicted, and sentencedâ€”this is a copy of the indictment, marked A.

ALFRED EDWARD FITZGERALD DALTON . I am clerk to Messrs. Barnett and Buckler, the official shorthand writers to this Courtâ€”on November 17th and 18th I took down in shorthand the whole of the evidence in the charge against Ernest Alfred Abrahams for and against the prisonerâ€”the prisoner was sworn and gave evidenceâ€”among others he called the prisoner George Hillmanâ€”this is the transcript, marked D, of my note of that evidenceâ€”he was sworn on the 17th and recalled on the 18th. (The prisoner Hillman's evidence, given at the trial on November 17th and 18th was then read. See page 4.)

HENRY CLARKE . I have lived at 65, Brook Street, Kennington Road, about a year, with my motherâ€”I have been employed by Humphreys and Grigg, military tailors, Haymarket, for six yearsâ€”on October 25th, about 7.30 p.m., I called upon Richard James, 42, Peacock Street, and went with him and Jinks round to see the illuminationsâ€”I parted from them about 12.30 a.m., in Leicester Squareâ€”the whole time James was perfectly sober.

WILLIAM ENRIGHT . I live at 40, Turner's Buildings, Erasmus Street, Westminster, and am a packer at the Army Stores, Grosvenor Road, Pimlico, in the day time, and am employed at the Empire Theatre stage entrance in the eveningâ€”I am an old soldierâ€”I saw Richard James on the evening of October 25th at the stage door of the Empire about 8.50â€”he was quite soberâ€”about 11.20 p.m. James came and complained that he had lost his friendsâ€”he waited till about 11.40â€”we went to the Princess Head, where I purchased a small brandy for my wife, and he had a lemon and bitter, we walked on to Guest's, and then through Whitehall to the bottom of Parliament Street, where we stood talking outside the London and North Western Railway Company's offices till 12.15, when I left him opposite the Parliament Housesâ€”he was quite sober.

JOSEPH CROSS . I live at 21, Warwick Street, Blackfriars Roadâ€”I keep two coffee stallsâ€”on October 25th and 26th, the night of the illuminations, I had one opposite the Lambeth Bathsâ€”I was attending to it from 10 p.m. till 1 a.m.â€”I attended this Court last month to see whether I knew Jamesâ€”he was not at my coffee stall that nightâ€”no drunken man hung his coat on the stall, or on the wheel of the stall, that is an impossibility, because he would have knocked the goods down; nor did any drunken man take off his bootsâ€”I saw Abrahams when he was convicted, but I did not know himâ€”I never saw him at my stallâ€”I saw no man that night at my stall who was drunk.
Cross-examined by Whiting. I have only one shelf and one counterâ€”I
do not keep pastry at the back of the counter I keep the cups on the counter.

ROBERT JOSLIN . I live at 8, Charlotte Street, Blackfriars Roadâ€”I help Joseph Cross in keeping his coffee stallâ€”I was with him at the coffee stall opposite the Lambeth Baths on October 25th and 20th, the night after the South London Processionâ€”ray light shone on the first door and not the second door from the stall in the Kennington Roadâ€”I never saw James thereâ€”no drunken man hung his coat on the ledge of the stall nor on the wheel that night nor fell down drunk.
Cross-examined. It would not have interfered with the pastry, it would have interfered with the cupsâ€”there would be room to hang a coat where there is no pastry.
Re-examined. There was no coat put there that nightâ€”I was there with Cross from 9.30 p.m. till 4 a.m.
HENRY HILLMAN . The prisoner Hillman is my brotherâ€”I was called as a "witness against Abrahams last month.

ALFRED LONG (Detective Sergeant L.) James complained at Kennington Lane Police Station on October 26thâ€”on November 3rd I arrested Abra
hamsâ€”the coat he was then wearing was identified by James as stolen from him on the night of October 26thâ€”Abrahams was afterwards charged, brought up here and convictedâ€”Sergeant Beard arrested Hillman and Whiting.

JOHN BEARD (Police Sergeant L.) On December 4th I arrested Hillman at 31, Broad Street, Lambethâ€”I told him I was a police officer, and that he would be charged with another lad who was arrested on the charge of perjury in a case at this Courtâ€”he said, "I say now 'what I said before, what I said is the truth; if it is not, I hope I may not see my mother and father alive again"â€”I took him to the police station, where the warrant was read to himâ€”he was subsequently chargedâ€”he made no reply.

HILLMAN.,
GUILTY. Recommended to mercy by the jury, thinking he had not realised the gravity of his action.
Four months' hard labour;
WHITING, who
PLEADED GUILTY. received a good character.
Seven days' hard labour.

p.hi: Before J. A. Rentoul Esq., K.C.

div1.p:
100.
HENRY DODD and
HARRY BIRTWISTLE ,
Committing an act of gross indecency.
MR. GREENFIELD Prosecuted, MR. HUTTON. Defended Dodd.
NOT GUILTY .

101.
MARY KINGSTON (36),
WILLIAM WALKER (21),
SARAH ANN WRIGHT (22), and
GEORGE WEBB (23)
, Robbery with violence, with another person unknown, upon
George Walker, and stealing from him two watches, a chain, and Â£5, his property.
MR. METHUEN Prosecuted, MR. FOWKE Defended Kingston.
GEORGE WALKER . I am a saddler of Barrow-in-Furnessâ€”on November 11th, about noon, I was in a public house close to Euston Railway Stationâ€”

Kingston and Wright asked me to stand them a drinkâ€”I did soâ€”we then went out of that house into another across the roadâ€”I stood them some more drink and also some lunchâ€”they then asked me to go home with them and have a cup of teaâ€”I consented, and they took me to No. 6, Clarendon Streetâ€”Wright invited me upstairs into a bedroomâ€”I asked for a cup of tea, but Kingston brought me a glass of what she said was stout, and said, "Have a drink, young man, it will do you good before you have a cup of tea"â€”I now know it to be a mixture of stout and snuffâ€”I had two drinks and almost immediately fell asleepâ€”the next I remember is Walker hitting me on my jaw, saying, "What are you doing here, you had better clear out"â€”I then discovered that I had been robbed of two watches, a chain, a belt, and six sovereigns which were in a purseâ€”I said to Walker, "I have been robbed; you and I had better go downstairs together; you are in the swim"â€”I seized him, but after struggling for about ten minutes he got awayâ€”I saw Kingston outside and gave her into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. FOWKE. I have served with the colours in South Africa and in Indiaâ€”I did not see a third woman at the houseâ€”I had had three or four drinks, but I was not drunkâ€”after I drank the black liquid Kingston kept popping in and out of the roomâ€”I cannot say who took my watches, chain, and money.
Cross-examined by Walker. I was not awake sitting on the bed when you came into the roomâ€”the punch you gave me woke me upâ€”when you slipped away from me you left your hat and scarf in my hands.
Cross-examined by Wright. You were not fully dressed lying across the foot of the bedâ€”you undressed and we went to bed togetherâ€”I had the drink before you undressed.
Cross-examined by Webb. I never saw you.

RICHARD KINGSTON . I am the son of Mary Kingston, and live at 6, Clarendon Streetâ€”I was at home about 1 p.m. on November 11th when Miss Wright and a Mrs. Webb came in with the prosecutorâ€”my mother was not with themâ€”Mrs. Webb asked me to get her a quarter of snuff and half a pint of stoutâ€”I went, and when I returned she was waiting for me on the stairs, and I saw her mix the two together on the stairsâ€”she then took it into the room where the prosecutor and Miss Wright wereâ€”I do not know what became of it afterwards, but Mrs. Webb told me that she had given it to the soldier to drinkâ€”I do not know Walker, Wright, or Webbâ€”I know Mrs. Webb.
Cross-examined by MR. FOWKE. It is untrue to say that my mother mixed the stuffâ€”she was not there; she was at the Jubilee public houseâ€”she came in about a quarter of an hour afterwards.
Cross-examined by Walker. I let you in.
Cross-examined by Webb. I have never seen you before.

ALICE SARGENT . I am the landlady of No. 6, Clarendon Streetâ€”Kingston has been a lodger of mine for seven monthsâ€”on November 11th I saw Mrs. Webb, Miss Wright, and the prosecutor come into the houseâ€”I saw Mrs. Kingston go in and out two or three times.
Cross-examined by MR. FOWKE. The prosecutor did not come into the
house with Mrs. Kingstonâ€”I did not see her bring in any drinkâ€”the people were in my house about an hour or an hour and a half.
Cross-examined by Webb. I have never seen you before.
Re-examined. I did not know that Mrs. Kingston let her room for immoral purposesâ€”she has two roomsâ€”she has brought strange women in at different times.

HERBERT HARMER . I am thirteen years old and go to schoolâ€”on Novem
ber 11th, about 4 o'clock, I saw Walker and the prosecutor struggling in the street for about ten minutesâ€”I saw Walker strike the soldier on the jawâ€”Walker then ran away leaving his hat and scarf in the soldier's hands.
Cross-examined by Walker. You were struggling when I first saw you I did not see you speaking to the prosecutor.
Cross-examined by Wright. I have never seen you before.
Cross-examined by Webb. I have never seen you before.

ARTHUR HALL (631 Y.) On November 11th, about 4 o'clock, the prose
cutor gave Kingston into my custody and said, "I have been robbed, and this is one of the women"â€”Kingston replied, "I have not got it, but good luck to her for getting away; I shall not tell you, I know all about it"â€”when charged she said, "It was never taken at 6, Clarendon Street, but in the street; the gentleman had a gold watch and chain on in my place and he had it on when he went out; go to 12, Lancing Street and fetch Mrs. Webb, she will tell you"â€”she had been drinking, but was not drunkâ€”enquiries have been made about Mrs. Webb, but at present they have been unsuccessfulâ€”the next night at 11 o'clock I arrested Wrightâ€”Webb was presentâ€”I told her I was a police officer, and should arrest her for being concerned with a man and woman in custody in stealing Â£6 in gold and a gold watch and chain and a gun-metal watchâ€”she replied, "I know I done wrong in going to the house with him and the other woman; I got into bed with him, and he had some stout to drink that sent him of to sleep; I had none of the money or stuff."
Cross-examined by MR. FOWKE. The prosecutor was not sober when he gave Kingston into my custody, but he understood what he was doing.

FREDERICK WATTS (489 Y.) On November 11th, about 8 p.m. I saw Walker outside the Exmouth public house, Exmouth Streetâ€”I told him I was a police officer and should arrest him for being concerned with others in custody and others not in custody in stealing from a man a purse and other articles and money in Clarendon Streetâ€”he replied, "I know nothing about it"â€”when charged at the station he said, "I do not know nothing at all about it: have you got my handkerchief and cap? I was called to the house to turn him out."

WILLIAM BARBER (135 Y.) On November 13th, about 12.20, Webb came to me and said."I may as well tell you I pawned the oxidised watch at Saunder's in Fitzroy Square for 5s., which I received from Mrs. Webb, who was with my wife which came from the soldier: I was not there, I do not know anything about it"â€”afterwards he said, "You have pinched my wife and I am done"â€”I understood him to refer to Wright as his wife.
"Cross-examined by Webb. You did not use the word "missus."

HERBERT ATTWOOD . I am in the employ of Mr. Jay, a pawnbroker of 73, Charlotte Street, Fitzroy Squareâ€”I produce a gun-metal watch pledged with us for 5s. in the name of Wellsâ€”I cannot recognise the man who pledged it.

GEORGE JONES (549 Y.) On November 11th I went to 6, Clarendon Street to search, and found a coat and some Army papers on the bed and a purse under the bedâ€”they have been identified by the prosecutorâ€”the following morning I went to the house again and found in the same room these two glasses (Produced) which contained a mixture of snuff and stout.
Cross-examined by Mr. Fowke. I know it to be snuff and stout by the smell.

By the COURT. Its effect is to send anyone to sleepâ€”I have had experi
ence of that in the course of my duties as a police officer.

A written statement by Webb before the Magistrate was here put in stating that he met Wright and Mrs. Webb in Charlotte Street, and Mrs. Webb handed him a gun-metal watch and asked him to pawn it, which he did for 5s. and handed it to her; that he did not know of the robbery until the following evening, when Wright was arrested; that he then went to the station voluntarily and told the police that he had pawned it and sur
rendered himself.

p.hi: Kingston, in her defence on oath, said that Mrs. Webb asked her if she could take two friends into her rooms to have a wash, as they were going to a music-hall; that she consented, and followed about a quarter of an hour afterwards; that she did not see the prosecutor and Wright in bed together, and did not give the prosecutor anything to drink; and that she had nothing whatever to do with the robbery.

div1.p: Walker, in his defence on oath, said that he was at work at the Exmouth Arms when Mrs. Webb offered him 5s. if he would turn a man out of Mrs. Kingston's room, that he went and when he got there the prosecutor accused him of robbing him.

p.hi: Wright, in her defence on oath, said that she was with Mrs. Webb when the prosecutor asked them to have a drink; that he then asked them to go to a music-hall; that they agreed; that Mrs. Webb then saw Mrs. Kingston in another bar of the public house, and asked her if they could go into her rooms and have a wash; that all three went; that the prosecutor sent Mrs. Webb out for some beer; that Mrs. Webb brought it, and that she drank out of the same glass as the prosecutor and immediately felt queer and vomited; that she did not go to bed with the prosecutor, but was lying across the foot of the bed; and that she had nothing whatever to do with the robbery.

div1.p: Webb, in his defence on oath, said that he was in Charlotte Street when Mrs. Webb asked him to pawn a watch for 5s.; that he did so, and handed the money to her; that he did not live with Wright as man and wife, but only knew her by knowing her parents.

KINGSTON and WRIGHT,
GUILTY of robbery;
WALKER,
GUILTY of robbery with violence : WEBB,
GUILTY, as an accessory.
WEBB then
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony at the Marylebone Police Court on August 13th, 1898. Four previous convictions of assault were proved

against Walker. KINGSTON,
Six months' imprisonment ; WALKER,
Twenty-five lashes with the cat and
twelve months' hard labour;
WRIGHT,
Six months' imprisonment;
WEBB,
Twelve months' hard labour.

102.
WILLIAM COOMBE (55)
, Feloniously wounding
Marie Laing, with intent to murder her.

MARIE LAING . I now live at 8, Bangor Street, Kensingtonâ€”I lived with the prisoner from the end of last January till October 8thâ€”a week before that a man named Webley came to stop with usâ€”the prisoner is a cat's-meat vendorâ€”he had a small roundâ€”I also used to work and pay for the things in the houseâ€”I partly kept himâ€”if he gave me a shilling he wanted it backâ€”he worked till the end of Julyâ€”from July 9th I kept him by my prostitutionâ€”I had not been a prostitute before that, but he complained of my having no money, and I had to do somethingâ€”on the afternoon of October 8th I was with the prisoner, a woman named Budden and Webley in my roomâ€”I told Coombe that he would have to leave me, as I did not intend to keep him any longerâ€”I offered him 5s. to get a start with, and offered to pay a week's lodgings for himâ€”he said, "What's the use of 5s. to me? If you give me a quid I can do something with that"â€”I said that I could not give him a quid because I had not one for myselfâ€”he said I could not turn an old man like him in the street, and that before I could leave him he would do me and my two children' tooâ€”between 6 and 7 p.m. I went out with Buddenâ€”I came back at 10 p.m., but went out again at one o'clock because I had no money, and came back a little after threeâ€”Budden was lying on the bed in her roomâ€”I told the prisoner that Webley had told me that he, Coombe, was going to do meâ€”I saw the end of the poker sticking out under the bedâ€”I asked the prisoner what that was for, and said, "You are going to do me with the poker, are you?"â€”he said he would knock my brains out if I did not go to bed, but if I did not do anything before the morning he would go to bed, and he did lie on the bedâ€”I did not go to bedâ€”about 7.45 I heard the landlord's son come into the next roomâ€”the prisoner appeared to be asleep on the bedâ€”I went into that room and said to Budden, "As you are paying your rent now, I think I will pay mine"â€”I did not notice that the prisoner had followed me till he said, "That is the woman who has got no money"â€”I had said that I had no moneyâ€”I went back and lit the fire, and then into the passage for water for the kettleâ€”the prisoner said. "You are going for the police, are you?"â€”I said, "No, I am not, I am going to make the tea"â€”I put the kettle on the fire, and then went to the bed to take the baby up when he struck me twice with this poker on the side of the head and twice on my left armâ€”I said, "Do not beat me any more, I won't do anything"â€”he caught my hair and dragged me on to the floor, took a razor out of his pocket and started cutting me on the back of my neckâ€”I screamed outâ€”the landlord knocked at the door and came in

and took the prisoner away from meâ€”I had taken off my coat and put this jacket on because it was coldâ€”here is the gash he made in the collar, and here is the cross cut that he made with the razor in the back of my neck and left hand.

Cross-examined by the prisoner. You took the poker from under the mattressâ€”I was not fighting Annie Buddenâ€”we were drinking teaâ€”I never asked you for 10d.â€”always when I came in you said, "How much money have you got?" and this time I said, "No money"â€”I never struck you with the pokerâ€”I did not come home drunkâ€”I did not throw a cup and saucer at youâ€”because I would not get up and make you a cup of tea you started making a noise, and that is the way the window was brokenâ€”I have had too much of that kind of life, and I have advertised for workâ€”Webley did not bruise meâ€”you did not take my part against Webley, you are too much of a cadâ€”you were living on meâ€”a cabman's wife asked if you were my father, no one asked if you were my husbandâ€”no woman wanted me to summon her husband for knocking me aboutâ€”Webley told me to be careful, as you said you would do me in and my children tooâ€”I said, "You won't do that," and you said "Won't I?"â€”you said you had done five years for your own wife, and you would laugh at doing so for meâ€”you called me a dirty rotten wâ€”I did not take my clothes off, but lay on the bed till 7.30 a.m.â€”I did not put the poker under my skirtâ€”I did not speak to you when I came in at one o'clockâ€”I did not say "You will have to fâ€”g well go now,"I said, "You will have to go to-day!"â€”I did not threaten you with the pokerâ€”you struck me three times with itâ€”the policeman picked it upâ€”I did not fall on the fireplaceâ€”with my head on the grateâ€”you dragged me from the bed across the side of the table, and my back hair got singedâ€”you bolted the door, but the; landlord pushed it open and got between us.

CHARLES HOFFMAN . I am the landlord of 5, Kenley Streetâ€”the prisoner and Annie Laing occupied the front roomâ€”about 8 a.m. on October 8th I heard a woman screamingâ€”I knocked at the door and asked what was the matterâ€”Laing halloed out, "Come in, Mr. Hoffman, he is murdering me"â€”I went insideâ€”Laing was face downwards and Coombe was hacking at her neck with a razor, which I took awayâ€”I held the prisoner against the wall till Laing got outâ€”I conveyed Laing to the next house and called my wife to assistâ€”when I came back the prisoner started runningâ€”I ran after himâ€”he cut his throat with a razor going alongâ€”I was assisted by a friend from a coffee shopâ€”we put him on a coal wagon that was passing and conveyed him to the doctorâ€”I took the razor out of the prisoner's hand and gave it to a policeman.

ROBERT ALEXANDER JUDSON . I am a medical practitioner of 11. Port
land Roadâ€”on October 8th I examined Laingâ€”she had several incised wounds about her head and face one on the right side of the back of her neck was an inch and a half long, two on her throat, one on the right side two inches long and one or the left an inch longâ€”she also had three bruises on her left arm and a cut on the back of her left handâ€”they were not self-inflicted.
EDWARD POLLARD (Police Inspector X.) I attended at the West London

Hospital on November 1stâ€”I told the prisoner I was a police officer, and should arrest him for causing greivous bodily harm to Marie Laing by beating her across the head and shoulders with a poker, attempting to murder her by cutting her throat with a razor, and for attempting to commit suicide by cutting his throatâ€”he said "All right"â€”I conveyed him in a cab to the police station, and when the charge was read over he said, "I did not beat her with the poker, she did it herself. I did not attempt to murder her, but I did attempt to murder myself."

p.hi:
The prisoner in his defence stated that Laing had provoked him and threatened him, after he had protected her and her two children, by attempt
ing to turn him out for Webley; that she hid the poker in her skirt and struck him with it, and that he saved her from the fire.

div1.p: MARIE LAING (Re-examined). I never struck him with the poker, he was not the man to let me.
GUILTY . He then

PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony at this Court on October 17th, 1892.
Fire years' penal servitude.

p.hi: For other cases tried this day see Essex and Surrey cases.

div1.p:
103.
HENRY SAMUELS and
JOSEPH SAMUELS
PLEADED GUILTY to
conspiring with
David Samuels and
Rosa Samuels and others, to set fire to divers houses and shops, of which they should be the occupiers, with intent to defraud such fire insurance companies as should grant them policies of insurance: HENRY SAMUELS also
PLEADED GUILTY to
wilful and corrupt perjury upon the hearing of an arbitration.
Two years' hard labour on each indictment, to run concurrently.
JOSEPH SAMUELSâ€”
Two years' hard labour.

104.
JAMES DUGGAN (39)
, Robbery with violence on
John Alfred French, and stealing a purse and Â£1 3s. 6d., his property.

JOHN ALFRED FRENCH . I am a cellarman, of 17, Lockyer's Street, Clapton Parkâ€”on Saturday, November 29th, I was outside King's Cross Station, of the Great Northern Railway, engaging a cab on the rank for myselfâ€”I was suddenly gripped by both my arms and felt a knee in my back, some
body holding my throat and neck, and at the same time I felt hands down my trousers pocketsâ€”as soon as I was released I saw my eldest brother chasing two or three menâ€”I lost 24s. which I had loose, and a purseâ€”my youngest brother said, "Keep your eye on him," meaning the prisoner, who was thereâ€”I saw the prisoner immediately after he left me, when he went towards the cab from behind me and then into a urinalâ€”my brother fetched a constable, and the prisoner was arrested as he was leaving the urinalâ€”I charged himâ€”I could not swear he took my purse;
I saw him come from behind meâ€”there was a crowd, but they cleared offâ€”the prisoner was searched at the police stationâ€”Â£1 was found in his mouthâ€”the purse has not been found.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. I was soberâ€”the cabman was engaged.

ARTHUR FRENCH . I am a labourer, of 3, Walton Road, Kentish Townâ€”I was with my brother when he was speaking to a cabmanâ€”two men came up in front of him and held his armsâ€”the prisoner came behind himâ€”one of them went to his waistcoat pocketâ€”the prisoner put his hand in his right hand trousers pocketâ€”I told my brother to keep his eye on this manâ€”as soon as the prisoner heard what I said he went into the urinal in front of the cab horse's headâ€”I went with my brother and charged him.

Cross-examined by the prisoner. I was perfectly soberâ€”my brother charged you at the station with robbery and assault, I supposeâ€”I could not hold your hand to see what you had in it, but I kept my eyes on you when you went into the urinalâ€”my brother said that he had lost his money and purse from his pocket.

FREDERICK FRENCH . I am a labourer, of 1, Carlton Street, Kentish Townâ€”I was with my two brothers when one was robbed as he was talking to a cabmanâ€”five men came up with a rushâ€”one or two came round my brother, got hold of his arms and held himâ€”I rushed for the men who were holding him, but they slipped away and went up York Roadâ€”I cannot swear to the prisoner, it was done so quickâ€”I pursued the two men who were in front of my brother but I was tripped up by another one who came behind meâ€”I had got down Caledonian Street when a man came behind me and put his shoulder against me and threw me in the street.
Cross-examined. I was soberâ€”the inspector at the station stopped me from speaking.

SAMUEL MIDDLETON (420 Y.) I was on duty about 6.20 on Saturday, November 29thâ€”Frederick French spoke to me, and I saw the prisoner runningâ€”I was only five yards offâ€”he ran into the urinal, and I ran to the opposite end, and as he was coming out I caught him in my armsâ€”he had only time to run through itâ€”the prosecutor and Frederick French came up and charged himâ€”he said he knew nothing about itâ€”I took him to the stationâ€”he was searchedâ€”on him was found a 6d. and 5 1/2 d.â€”when he was put back in the cells I found in his mouth two two-shilling pieces and a half-crown-the total found on him was 7s. 5 1/2d.
Cross-examined. You did not stay in the urinal long enough to make waterâ€”you were not doing your trousers upâ€”you were charged with stealing money out of the prosecutor's pocket.

p.hi: The prisoner, in his defence on oath, said that he knew nothing about this matter till the prosecutor asked him far his purse.

div1.p: GUILTY . He then

PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction at Clerkenwell on November 6th, 1900, and five other convictions were proved against him, and he was stated to be a desperate man and companion of thieves.
Seven years' penal servitude.

105.
CHARLES MAJOR SMITH (42)
, Obtaining credit for Â£50 and Â£35 from
Fred Belcher and Â£21 from
Frederick George Charles Ford without informing them that he was an undischarged bankrupt; and obtaining by false pretences from
William Arthur Adams a cheque for Â£100; and other sums from other persons with intent to defraud; and being entrusted with Â£3 by
Frederick George Charles Ford for a special purpose, did fraudulently convert the same to his own use.

p.hi: MR. CHARLES MATHEWS, MR. A. GILL

div1.p:
GEORGE INGLIS BOYLE . I am a messenger in the Bankruptcy Courtâ€”I pro
duce the file of the bankruptcy of Charles Major Smithâ€”the adjudication was on August 2nd, 1900â€”according to the debtor's statement of affairs the liabilities were Â£2,855 2s. 10d. and the assets nilâ€”he has never been dis
charged from that bankruptcyâ€”he is described as an accountant of 55 Victoria Street, Westminsterâ€”his private address is given as 31, George Street, Hanover Square.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. There are unsecured liabilities to the amount of Â£1.444 12s. 1d., and contingent liabilities to the amount of Â£1,410 10s. 9d.

JOHN CLARENCE LYELL . I am an electrical engineer, and carry on busi
ness as J. C. Lyell and Co. at 55, Victoria Street, Westminsterâ€”in the autumn of 1899 the prisoner took two offices from me on the first floor of 53, Victoria Street, in the name of C. M. Smith and Co., at a rent of Â£40 a year, but in January, 1900, he gave those up and took two offices at 55, Victoria Street, at a rent of Â£80 a yearâ€”the March rent was paid in advance, but in June, 1900, I had to distrain for it and again in Septemberâ€”it was paid out on each occasionâ€”in September I gave him six months' notice to leave, but on March 24th, the day before the rent became due, he removed all his goods and furnitureâ€”he did not let me know that he was going, and I have never received the rentâ€”I understood him to be an accountantâ€”there were a number of names upon a tablet in the passage, but there was no name of Drummond and Co.â€”I did not see anyone there in authority except him.

Cross-examined. I first made your acquaintance in the autumn of 1899, when you and Mr. Clemenson came to me with reference to taking the offices at No. 53â€”I saw Clemenson several times, but I had no business transactions with himâ€”I do not remember ever meeting a Mr. Edwardsâ€”I may have distrained for the rent the same day as it fell due, but it was to protect myself because of the bankruptcy noticeâ€”after your bankruptcy the National Prudential Insurance Company took over the tenancy of the offices and it was agreed to extend the tenancy till June provided I had a satisfactory reference from the National Prudential Companyâ€”I wrote to them upon the subject but I never received an answerâ€”you left on March 24thâ€”the office doors were not padlocked on the 25th not for several days afterâ€”you did not put up any notice as to your change of addressâ€”when I discovered where you had gone I issued a writ against you for the Â£40 rentâ€”leave was given you to defend the action and it was subsequently heard

before Mr. Justice Wrightâ€”I do not remember whether the Judge non
suited meâ€”in October I saw a notice in the paper referring to your address, and I gave information to the police.

GEOGRE RUSSELL SEWELL . I am manager of Jones, Lang and Co. Estate Agents of 27, Chancery Laneâ€”in March, 1901, they had the letting of some of the buildingâ€”on March 15th I received an application from Messrs. Drummond and Co., of 55, Victoria Street, offering Â£72 a year for rooms 25, 20. and 27, Lonsdale Chambers, Chancery Laneâ€”they gave three refer
ences, which proved satisfactory, and an agreement for three years was subsequently given to themâ€”I called each quarter for the rentâ€”the cheques I received were signed "Drummond and Co."â€”the first cheque was dishonouredâ€”we wrote to Drummond and Co. in consequence and received instructions from them to present it againâ€”we did so and it was duly honouredâ€”the September rent was paidâ€”the cheque for the Christ
mas rent was dishonouredâ€”we distrained and were paid outâ€”we also had to issue a distress for the March, June, and September rents before we were paidâ€”I believed exhibit 20 to be a genuine reference.

Cross-examined. After your arrest I went to the offices with the policeâ€”I then found this agreement (Produced) lying upon the tableâ€”we have distrained for the rent since your arrest and have been paid outâ€”the furniture has been removed to avoid payment of the Christmas rentâ€”a person giving the name of Drummond first inspected the offices, and having approved of them we received the letter of March 15th from Drum
mond and Co.â€”we then sent them a draft agreement, and Mr. Drummond brought it to us already signed by the Company, and we handed him the original signed by the landlordâ€”he paid the costsâ€”I have never seen him since.

FRED BELCHER . I live at 42a, Mersham Road, Thornton Heathâ€”I was introduced to the defendant by Mr. Seabrook about three years agoâ€”he then had offices in Victoria Street and was carrying on business as C. M. Smith and Co.â€”I saw other names up but not the name of Drum-mond and Co.â€”I heard the name of Drummond mentioned about March. 1901, but I did not see himâ€”in January, 1901, I had a conversa
tion with Smithâ€”I told him my mother wanted to invest a little moneyâ€”he introduced me to a firm of solicitors, but they took such a long time over it that he eventually did it himselfâ€”I gave him Â£50, and he gave me a promissory note for Â£55 on January 15th payable one month after dateâ€”about a fortnight afterwards he gave me some debentures in Hill and Co.â€”I have since recovered Â£5 on them at the City Court from a Mr. Powell to whom the business was soldâ€”the promissory note was never paidâ€”when I parted with the money I knew he had been bankrupt, but I thought he had got his dischargeâ€”in June, 1901, I found out that he was undischargedâ€”on the same day I handed him another Â£35, for which he gave me a promissory note for Â£41 payable three months after dateâ€”he told me he was making an advance to Messrs Barber and Co., and that my Â£35 was included in the loanâ€”that Â£35 has never been repaidâ€”I have also advanced him small sums amounting to 36s. 6d.â€”I have never been in his employmentâ€”I remember him telling me in November, 1901, that

Drummond and Co. had been turned into a limited companyâ€”I was a director of the Company, and also one of the signatoriesâ€”my qualification as a director was twenty sharesâ€”I believe they were issued but never deliveredâ€”I had no remuneration as a directorâ€”the inducement held out to me was that I was to have a very good situation in another company that the prisoner was formingâ€”I never got the situationâ€”exhibit 11 is a minute of a meeting of the directors held on November 19thâ€”it is not true that that was the only meeting held by the directorsâ€”part of it is in Mr. Seabrook's writingâ€”he was in the employ of the company at the timeâ€”I sometimes signed cheques for the company and sometimes Seabrook didâ€”before I signed one I always had instructions from Smith to do soâ€”I sometimes signed cheques in blankâ€”exhibit 13 is the ledger of Drummond and Co.â€”some of the early entries are in Seabrook's writing, but most of them are mineâ€”down to May 16th there were payments out to the Pension Tea Co. to the amount of Â£105 and receipts from the Pension Tea Co. to the extent of Â£18 15s.â€”the capital account of the Company on February 28th, 1901, was Â£7â€”Smith's salary as secretary of the company was Â£3 a weekâ€”I went to Chancery Lane nearly every evening till Juneâ€”I only went once or twice after June.

Cross-examined. I was frequently at Victoria Street during 1900 and up to the time when you removed in March, 1901â€”in July, 1900, I knew about your bankruptcy in connection with Grenier Gervaisâ€”you told me it was due to a mistake on the part of the solicitors and not due to your own liabilitiesâ€”you also told me that you had arranged with Mr. Edwards, of the National Prudential, to take over your businessâ€”I do not know whether your initials were dropped and the business carried on as Smith and Co.â€”when I gave you the Â£85 I knew that your liabilities were about Â£3,000 and that you had not paid any part of themâ€”I knew Mr. Clemen
son and his partner Mr. Hill, at 55, Victoria Streetâ€”I saw Mr. Hill there constantlyâ€”he seemed to be in authorityâ€”I also saw him at Chancery Laneâ€”he seemed to be in occupation of the offices thereâ€”I know his writingâ€”there are entries by him in the cash bookâ€”the signature to exhibit 19 is hisâ€”I had nothing to do with Drummond and Co. before it became a limited companyâ€”I saw a Mr. Middlemiss at Chancery Lane when Mr. Hill leftâ€”he owned the furniture at Chancery Laneâ€”when he left he sold it to Mr. Brown, who is a director of Henry Drummond and Co.â€”I did not give you the Â£85 for your personal useâ€”I understood it was to be lent to a Mr. Box and Messrs. Barberâ€”I am perfectly satisfied that the money was lentâ€”I do not know whether it has been recoveredâ€”Mr. Brown found the money for the formation of Drummond and Co., and paid for its registrationâ€”I know you paid about Â£150 into itâ€”I believe it was Mr. Brown who asked me to become a directorâ€”Mr. Brown and I signed the order to the bank as to how the cheques were to be signedâ€”you never asked me to draw cheques for your own personal useâ€”the whole of the moneys received and paid by the company are shown in the cash book, which was kept by meâ€”for my services I was to have Â£100 in cash and an appointment in the Traders' and Consumers' Provident Association when it was floatedâ€”I know that that association had been arranged to

be financed to a very considerable extentâ€”Messrs. Bennett and Charts were to advance Â£2,000â€”after the formation of the company there were frequent meetings of directorsâ€”it was your duty as secretary to draft the minutes and other things that were to be attended to, and they were subsequently copied out and signed at the next meeting and kept in a drawer in the officeâ€”the minutes produced are only draftsâ€”a share register was kept, and I believe kept properlyâ€”I do not remember a meeting of the seven signatories after the registration of the company, but I remember a meet
ing of fourâ€”at that meeting the directors were appointed and Mr. Sea brook was elected chairmanâ€”your salary was Â£3 a week, but after June, 1902, it was to be increased to Â£500 a yearâ€”I have never seen anything irregular in the conduct of the company since I have been connected with itâ€”I know by keeping the cash book that all the money paid to the com
pany has been used by themâ€”your name was not up at the offices in Chancery Laneâ€”I believe a balance sheet of Henry Drummond and Co. has been prepared, I had nothing to do with the preparation of itâ€”the company is still carrying on its business and flourishingâ€”I have no idea as to its present financial condition.

Re-examined. I remember the defendant telling me about his bank
ruptcy, but as far as appearance went, I did not notice any difference in January, 1901, to his position before the bankruptcyâ€”when I gave him the money I was perfectly content to rely upon his promissory notesâ€”until I was shown exhibit 19 I did not know that Hill had been using the name of Drummondâ€”there were no signed minutes except the one pro
duced; there were several rough draftsâ€”I have no knowledge of the nego
tiations between the company and Bennett and Charts, except what the defendant and Mr. Brown had told meâ€”I do not think Drummond and Co. have had any banking account since Julyâ€”on June 13, when Mr. Adams' Â£100 was paid into the company's account, the account was overdrawn to the extent of ninepence.

LEONARD JAMES BULL . I am a clerk living at 3a, Talbot Road, Forest Gateâ€”in March last I answered an advertisement in the Daily Telegraph for an assistant secretaryâ€”I received a letter from Smith as secretary to Messrs. Drummond and Co., asking me to call upon him at 27, Chancery Laneâ€”I called and Smith told me that in order to take up the position I should have to take some shares in the companyâ€”I took fifty sharesâ€”he told me they were paying 10 per cent., and that the interest would be paid yearlyâ€”I was to get a weekly salary of 45s. with an increase in three months, rising up to Â£3 in nine monthsâ€”Smith told me that he held between 500 and 600 sharesâ€”I believed his statements to be correct, and upon March 17th I went to the company's offices to commence my dutiesâ€”upon the 18th I paid Smith Â£25 in cash, and gave him a cheque for Â£25 a day or two afterâ€”I was only at Chancery Lane two days when I was sent to Stratford to try and find a suitable depot for the Pension Tea Companyâ€”I had very little to do during the two days I was at Chancery Laneâ€”Smith had a number of callersâ€”I only remained about ten days in the employ of the company when I spoke to Smith about terminating my agreement and asked him for the return of my moneyâ€”he told me

that as I had entered into an agreement there would be a little difficulty, but eventually I got a cheque for Â£25 and another cheque post-dated a month for Â£23â€”I agreed to allow him Â£2 for expenses in transferring the sharesâ€”I presented the cheque for Â£23 at the bank, but it was returned marked, "Refer to drawers"â€”it has never been paidâ€”I received two weeks' salary of 45s.â€”I saw nobody in control at the offices of Drummond and Co. except Smithâ€”Brown came in several times during the dayâ€”his offices, the Pension Tea Co., were on the opposite side of the wayâ€”I never saw anyone of the name of Drummond.

Cross-examined. You often spoke to me of seeing Mr. Drummondâ€”when I first saw you at Chancery Lane you told me that you were secretary of the company, and that the company was doing such a big business that you wanted an assistantâ€”before I parted with my money and took up my appointement I made a few inquiries about the company, and they were satisfactoryâ€”I know that a Mr. Johnson answered the same advertise
ment as I didâ€”I found out afterwards that you were advertising again for an assistant secretary when I had already taken up the position, and in consequence I asked to have my agreement cancelledâ€”you objected and said that you had no power to cancel it, but must see Mr. Drummond and the other directors about itâ€”I eventually got Â£25 returnedâ€”I know that twenty-five of my shares were transferred to Mr. Johnsonâ€”I did not know that he was going to take up the remaining twenty-five at the end of a month, and that that was the reason my cheque was post-dated a monthâ€”when the cheque was dishonoured I put the matter into the hands of my solicitorsâ€”before I went to them I saw you about it and you had not got the moneyâ€”I know a writ was issued against you, but I do not know that the costs were Â£7â€”I was approached by the police to come and give evidence.
Re-examined. The reason I wanted my agreement terminated was because I found that he was negotiating with Johnson for the very position that I had paid Â£50 to hold.

HARRY JOHNSON . I am an engineer's clerk of 101, Fore Street, Ipswichâ€”on February 25th, last my attention was attracted to an adver
tisement in the Daily Telegraphâ€”I answered it, and called upon Henry Drummond and Co. some time in Marchâ€”I saw the prisoner, and he told me that the appointment was in connection with a friendly society called the National Thrift, that the capital was to be Â£1,000,000, that its business was in connection with the sale of tea, and that if I took the appointment he should want a deposit as a guarantee of good faithâ€”I agreed to deposit Â£25 and received a certificate signed by Belcher and Smith of twenty-five preference shares, each carrying an accumulative preference dividend at the rate of 10 per cent per annumâ€”I believed the statements made to me by Smith with regard to the companyâ€”I began my duties on April 7th at a salary of Â£2 a week, at 27, Chancery Laneâ€”I had very little to doâ€”I stayed till about the middle of Mayâ€”my salary was paid, but not regularlyâ€”I never saw anyone named Drummond nor anyone in authority except Smithâ€”I never got my Â£25 repaid to me, and I eventually
sent the certificate and other papers to a firm of solicitors and left the matter in their hands.

Cross-examined. I never saw any Mr. Drummondâ€”I did not know whether such a man existedâ€”I looked upon you as the representative of the companyâ€”all I had to do was to prepare six or eight sets of rules for friendly societiesâ€”I do not know that anything you told me was untrueâ€”the Pension Tea Society had not been registered when I leftâ€”I paid the Â£25 to you, but I do not know what became of it afterwardsâ€”I went back to Ipswich when I left youâ€”when I left and found that I could not get my Â£25 back I agreed to leave it with the companyâ€”later on I received a letter from Bull asking me to communicate with his solicitors in Londonâ€”in consequence I left my share certificate with themâ€”I was asked by the police to give evidence.

Re-examined. I did not ask any questions as to the bankers or the financial position of the companyâ€”I have had no dividend' on my shares yetâ€”several people called at the offices while I was there, but I did not know what business they came onâ€”I never bought or sold any tea.

FRANCIS HENRY SEABROOK . I am a clerk of 88, St. Stephen's Avenue, Shepherd's Bushâ€”I was in the prisoner's service when he was trading as C. M. Smith, at 55, Victoria Street, and afterwards as C. M. Smith and Co.â€”I know his writingâ€”I should say that exhibit 20 is his writingâ€”I did not know anyone of the name of Drummond as a sub-tenant of hisâ€”I have lived at 15, Speenham Road, Brixtonâ€”Miss Smith was living there thenâ€”she is a sister of the defendantâ€”in November, 1901, I went into his service at 27, Chancery Lane; for two monthsâ€”a Mr. Drummond was frequently spoken of by Smith, but I never saw himâ€”I am one of the original signatories to Henry Drummond and Co., Limited, and also a directorâ€”I had twenty-five shares given me as a qualificationâ€”I never got the scrip, but I understood it was issued, and that Mr. Smith had Itâ€”I could have had it by asking, but I never asked; I was quite content to leave it with himâ€”I never had any remuneration as a directorâ€”I only attended one meeting of directors, that was soon after the company was formedâ€”at that meeting I acted as chairmanâ€”only Mr. Belcher, Mr. Smith, and myself were presentâ€”no reporters were present.

Cross-examined. I first met you at your sister's house at Brixtonâ€”it was in the early part of 1899 that I first entered your service at 53, Victoria Streetâ€”I saw a Mr. Clemenson thereâ€”he was in joint occupation with youâ€”he was known also by the name of Ballantineâ€”I do not know that that name was assumed because of some money he inheritedâ€”I know his initials are W. H. D., but I do not know what the letters stand forâ€”I did not know that he had been connected with a firm of Drummond and Co. in Argyle Street, Regent Streetâ€”soon after the war broke out in 1900 he went out to South Africa, and his partner, Mr. Hill, took his placeâ€”Mr. Hill came about the time I leftâ€”I called at the office occasionally afterwards, and sometimes saw Mr. Hill thereâ€”I have seen a Mr. Dearing and a Mr. Davis at Victoria Streetâ€”Mr. Dearing is some relation of Mr. Hillâ€”I remember you becoming bankrupt, and that a Mr. Edwards, the proprietor of the National Prudential Insurance Company took over your

business and carried it on in the name of Smith and Co.â€”you then acted as managerâ€”your cash book shows that from July, 1899, to July, 1901,. about Â£8,000 was received by you in businessâ€”I should say your earnings were Â£400 or Â£500 a yearâ€”I know you lost Â£1,200 in connection with Greinier Gervais, and that the business was afterwards purchased by Messrs. Swan and Edgarâ€”I think you were the heaviest creditor with 750 de
benturesâ€”I first went to Chancery Lane about the middle of October, before the formation of the companyâ€”I was there when the company was formedâ€”I was one of the first signatoriesâ€”Messrs. Brown, Smith, Belcher, Davis, Elliott and Collins were the othersâ€”I have been the secretary of one limited companyâ€”I think all the requirements in connection with the legal-registration of Henry Drummond and Co., Limited, were com
plied withâ€”I remember seeing a Mr. Middlemiss thereâ€”he had his name on the doorâ€”I think he owned all the furniture in the officesâ€”I do not know if he held the leaseâ€”I remember you making advances to Messrs Barber and Co.â€”I was in their employ subsequently to being with youâ€”I know that the money has been repaidâ€”Â£100 of it has been paid to the solicitors acting for Barber and Co.â€”twenty-five shares were allotted to me as a director, but they were never issuedâ€”it was agreed that 500 were to be allotted to you in consideration of services renderedâ€”I remember the Pension Tea Society being started while I was at Chancery Laneâ€”that business was to buy and sell teaâ€”I had nothing to do with itâ€”Drum
mond and Co. was a perfectly bona fide company when I left in Januaryâ€”I have had nothing to do with it sinceâ€”during the three and a half years I have known you I have not seen anything that was not perfectly straightforward.

Re-examined. When Smith acquired the business of Madame Gervais he undertook the assets and the liabilities of the business and then turned it into a company and raised money on the debenturesâ€”some of the liabili
ties of Madame Gervais were paid, but some were notâ€”I do not know whether Mr. Belcher received any of the money repaid by Messrs. Barber and Co. to Messrs. Huxham and Rawlinsonâ€”the National Prudential Insurance Company in Victoria Street has nothing to do with the great Prudential Insurance Company.

ALBERT EDWARD HOLE . I am a clerk in the office of the Registrar of Joint Stock Companies, at Somerset Houseâ€”I produce the registered file of Henry Drummond and Co., Limitedâ€”the company was registered on November 15th, 1901â€”I also produce the registered copy of the memo
randum and articles of association of the companyâ€”it was established to carry on amongst other things the business of transfer agents, auctioneers, house and land and general financial agentsâ€”on March 10th, 1902, a register of directors was filedâ€”Charles Major Smith is described as the secretaryâ€”no agreement has been filed showing the acquisition by the company of any propertyâ€”no auditor or manager has been appointedâ€”there is no list of shareholdersâ€”on March 10th, 1902, there were 157 Â£1 shares issued in all.
Cross-examined. I am acquainted with the requirements of the Act of Parliament relating to Joint Stock Companiesâ€”we should not register

a company unless all the requirements of the Act were complied withâ€”by the memorandum the directors have power to issue shares to any persons for services rendered in connection with the formationâ€”an auditor may be appointed by the articles of association, but it is not compulsoryâ€”when a list of directors is filed no manager need be appointedâ€”no deben
tures have been registered by Drummond and Co.

WILLIAM ARTHUR ADAMS . I am a grocer's assistant of 116, High Street, West Norwoodâ€”in May last I answered an advertisement in the Daily Telegraph for a partnershipâ€”on the 28th I called at the offices of Henry Drummond and Co., and saw the defendantâ€”he told me he was secretary of the company, at a salary of Â£600 a year; that they were doing a very big business, and that they wanted somebody to do the extension work, and that they had 800 membersâ€”I saw him several times after May 28thâ€”he told me I should have to invest Â£150 in the company, and on June 11th I gave him a cheque for Â£100â€”it is endorsed "For Drummond and Co. Limited, C. M. Smith, Secretary"â€”in return for the cheque he gave me a certificate for 100 fully-paid preference shares of Â£1 each, carrying a dividend at the rate of 10 per cent., signed by Mr. Belcher and himselfâ€”I entered upon my duties on June 16th, at Sloughâ€”I stayed there eleven weeks, during which time I received from Smith two cheques, one for Â£3 and one for Â£5, both of which were dishonouredâ€”I wrote to him about them, and in consequence of his answer I paid the Â£5 cheque into my bank again, and it was again dishonouredâ€”I was to get a salary of Â£3 a week, but I never received anythingâ€”I wrote several times for it, but he always made excuses, none of which" turned out to be trueâ€”I was in his employ for seventeen weeks altogether, eleven weeks at Slough and six weeks at Chancery Laneâ€”scarcely any business was done at Sloughâ€”I only took Â£4 4s. 6d. in the eleven weeksâ€”the business was to sell teaâ€”the whole of the net profits of the Pension Tea Society were to be paid to and funded with the British National Thrift Friendly Societyâ€”I was never told who were the Committee of Management, or the trustees, or the treasurer or the secretary of the National Thrift Societyâ€”the Pension Tea Society was afterwards changed to the Pension Trading Societyâ€”I paid expenses at Slough amounting to Â£9â€”I kept the Â£4 4s. 6d. I had taken over the counter, and I received Â£3 from Smith, so that I am out of pocket altogether Â£153.

Cross-examined. I received two letters from you before I saw youâ€”the first was signed "C.M. Smith," and I could not find youâ€”the second letter bore the company's stampâ€”when I saw you we did not discuss the partnership, but you went straight to the Pension Tea Societyâ€”you said that it was to run on similar lines to Nelson's, which you had put on a footingâ€”I knew Nelson's to be a good businessâ€”Brown was not introduced to me as a director of the company, but as being connected with the working of the Pension Tea Societyâ€”I understood I was paying in Â£100 to the company as a guarantee of good faithâ€”I paid the money to youâ€”Brown was presentâ€”I made no enquiries about the business before I paid the money, I was perfectly satisfied with what you told meâ€”you told meâ€”that Mr. Brown had put Â£150 into the businessâ€”you did

not tell me that you had any money in itâ€”the Pension Tea Company's office was a little room on the top floor of 84, 85, and 86, Chancery Laneâ€”while at Slough I was not working under Mr. Brownâ€”I took directions from him, but I thought he took them from youâ€”when I returned to Chancery Lane I was employed with issuing policies in the British National Thrift Societyâ€”on September 11th the Company owed me Â£39, but I did not then owe them Â£50â€”I was not to find the other Â£50 until three months after 11th August, the date of the agreementâ€”you told me that Â£2,000 had been promised by Messrs. Bennett and Chart for the extension of the Pension Tea business, and you took me to see the solicitors, but they said they could not do anything till the head of the firm came back at the end of the weekâ€”you did tell me that when this money or a portion of it came in my salary would be paidâ€”I lent you Â£10, for which I have your I O U nowâ€”later on I found out that instead of 800 members there were only twenty-oneâ€”I was present when you were arrested at Chancery Lane at the company's officesâ€”I have never made any applica
tion for the return of my capitalâ€”I was bound under my agreement for a year.

Re-examined. Mr. Brown was present at one of the interviews I had with the defendantâ€”he heard everything that passed and he verified the defendant's statementsâ€”I first knew that Mr. Brown was a director of Drummond and Co. when I received the articles of association some time in September.

ALBERT TAYLOR . I am a clerk in the employ of the London and South Western Bank, Fleet Street branchâ€”I produce a certified copy of the account of Henry Drummond and Co.â€”it was opened on November 27th, 1901, with the payment in of Â£100â€”the last entry is July 1st, 1902â€”there was then an overdraft of Â£1 8s. 4d.â€”on March 19th there is a pay
ment in of Â£25, and another payment in of Â£25 on the 20thâ€”on the 21st Â£35 was drawn against those two amountsâ€”on April 1st there is a pay
ment in of Â£25, and on April 2nd a payment out to Bull of Â£25â€”on June 12th there is a payment in of Â£100â€”before that was paid in there was an over
draft of 9d.â€”on the following day there is a cheque drawn to self for Â£50, and two days later a payment out to Brown of Â£10â€”the total payments into the Bank from January 1st, 1902, to June 30th, 1902, including the payment of Â£100 and three payments of Â£25 each, is Â£377 17s. 4d.

Cross-examined. The total payments in from November 27th, 1901, to June 30th, 1902, is Â£508 7s. 4d.â€”the Pension Tea Society's account was under the control of Mr. W. A. Brown or Mr. G. M. Smith, either could signâ€”the total payments into that account between November 28th, 1901 and July 3rd, 1902, is Â£475 16s. 11d.â€”Drummond and Co.'s cheques were to be signed by one director and the secretary.
Re-examined. On July 10th the Pension Tea Society's account had 4s. 2d. to its credit, and a cheque was drawn on July 30th for 4s. 2d., closing the account.

FREDERICK GEORGE CHARLES FORD . I am a clerk living at Plumsteadâ€”in the early part of June I saw an advertisement in the Daily Telegraph for an assistant secretary to a friendly societyâ€”I wrote and received a

reply from C. M. Smith, asking me to call at 27, Chancery Laneâ€”I called and saw the defendantâ€”he showed me a copy of the rules of the British National Thrift Society, and told me that I should have to handle large sums of money in connection with the society, and he should require a guarantee of Â£500â€”I agreedâ€”the Law Guarantee Society was mentioned, and he asked me whether I should take it out myself or whether he should do so for meâ€”he told me he could get it at a cheaper rate, and I gave him Â£3 to cover the expenses on July 7thâ€”my salary was to be Â£3 a weekâ€”I entered on my duties at 27, Chancery Lane on August 25thâ€”all I did was to fill in policies appertaining to the Pension Tea Societyâ€”I stayed in the employ about seven weeks, but never received any salaryâ€”on October 8th, the day before the offices were closed, Smith called upon me at Brixton and told me that Brown had the money of the company, and that after Adams had been settled with I should get my money in fullâ€”the next day I spoke to Mr. Brown about it, and the day after I lodged an information with the police at Bow Street.

Cross-examined. The financial condition of the society was never explained to meâ€”my salary was Â£3 a week, not Â£2â€”I was to be paid monthlyâ€”at the end of the month I did not make an application for Â£8â€”I did not see anyone named Drummondâ€”I never heard you personally assume the name of Drummondâ€”with regard to the Â£3 I gave you, you distinctly suggested going to the Law Guarantee Societyâ€”I do not recollect telling you that Mr. Adams was in communication with Bow Streetâ€”I have not been employed by the police.

Re-examined. I have never been in communication with any society in reference to a policy of guaranteeâ€”after I had been to Bow Street I tried to trace the defendant, but I was not employed by the police; I was a fortnight altogether doing so.

LOUIS WILLIAM BENNETT . I am in the employ of the Law Guarantee Society, of 49, Chancery Laneâ€”no guarantee policy has been taken out with that Society by Mr. Smith or Drummond and Co., Ltd., in respect of Mr. Fordâ€”I have not seen any proposal form, nor has any money been received by the Societyâ€”we have had some communication with the firm in con
nection with other peopleâ€”Smith is not in a position to obtain guarantee policies from the Society at a cheaper rate than any other person.

Cross-examined. I have been to see Drummond and Co. once or twiceâ€”the last time was in connection with a Mr. Fountainâ€”I am not aware that he was in the employ of the Pension Tea Societyâ€”before we issue a policy we require to be furnished with a printed prospectus of the Societyâ€”there might be a saving in the cost of the premium if several persons were included in one guarantee policyâ€”I do not think we gave you a quotation of 10s.

WILLIAM STEPHENS (Detective-Sergeant E.) On October 21st I searched the offices of Drummond and Co., 27, Chancery Lane, and found Exhibits 7, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 22 and 23, and a register of members of Henry Drummond and Co., Ltd., and a share certificate book.
Cross-examined. There is no lettering upon the share register book
to identify it as Henry Drummond and Co.'s, but I think it bears the Company's stamp inside.

ALBERT HAWKINS (Detective-Sergeant E.) On October 21st I went to 2 7, Chancery Laneâ€”I saw the prisoner in the offices of Henry Drummond and Co.â€”I told him I was a police officer and held a warrant for his arrest for obtaining Â£100 by false pretences from a Mr. Adamsâ€”he said that Mr. Adams was not the only one that had put money into the business, and that he had had no more to do with it than Mr. Brown.

WILLIAM ALFRED BROWN . For a good many years previous to 1901 I was in business as a retail grocerâ€”I first met Smith in 1901, and we discussed the formation of a company to run, among other things, the Pension Tea Societyâ€”Henry Drummond and Co., Ltd., was then formedâ€”I became one of the signatories and one of the directorsâ€”I knew Mr. Seabrook and Mr. Belcher as directorsâ€”as soon as the Company was registered I paid Â£150 into its account, and I have since put in another Â£200â€”some of my friends have also put in about Â£100 between themâ€”I have assisted the Company on and off right from the startâ€”Smith held the position of secretaryâ€”several meetings of directors were held and minutes drawn upâ€”I do not recollect any arrangement by which Smith got 50 per cent of the receipts from the general commission business apart from his salaryâ€”I do not think he was drawing Â£600 a year from Drummond and Co.â€”I remember the transactions in connection with Bull, Johnson, and Adamsâ€”their moneys were received by the Company and applied for the carrying on of the businessâ€”I do not think any of it reached Smithâ€”in June, 1902, the Pension Tea business was in a flourishing conditionâ€”the members were about 800â€”in October, the business had practically doubled itself, the number of members was between 1,500 and 1,600â€”the business is now at a standstill owing to these proceedingsâ€”I had nothing to do with the signing of cheques for Drummond and Coâ€”Mr. Belcher used to keep the cash book, and I saw it occasionallyâ€”when I went to Chancery Lane, Mr. Middlemiss was occupying the offices with Smithâ€”Middlemiss continued in occupation till Marchâ€”when he left I bought the furniture and the lease of the rooms from himâ€”I do not know how he got itâ€”I understood Drummond and Co., Ltd., had taken it from Jones, Lang and Co.â€”after the formation of the Company most of the time was occupied in framing rules of different friendly societiesâ€”it was arranged to finance the societies before they were really registeredâ€”amongst the societies formed were the Pension Trading Society, the Traders' and Consumers' Provident Association, and the British National Thrift Societyâ€”in the formation of these societies Drummond and Co. were acting practically as agents of eminent financial peopleâ€”no false representations were made to Mr. Adams or Mr. Bull about the businessâ€”at the time Mr. Adams paid in his Â£100 I had arranged to invest some more money in the Companyâ€”it was the rule that the agents should pay their salary out of their takingsâ€”very few agents took less than Â£3 a weekâ€”all Mr. Adams' orders were executedâ€”the British National

Thrift Society was formed to take the profits of the Pension Tea Societyâ€”the profits from 1,600 customers would be about Â£20 a weekâ€”the British National Thrift was a properly registered friendly societyâ€”Ford was in the Company's employ at a salary of Â£2 a weekâ€”we had twelve or fourteen agents, and arrangements had been made to guarantee them through the Law Guarantee Society, who were waiting for the names of the trustees and the prospectus, which we did not get till October 3rdâ€”I do not know anything about the Â£3 that Mr. Ford paid Smithâ€”about October 10th Smith sent in his resignation to Drummond and Co., and it was at my request that he remained onâ€”at the time of his arrest certain matters were nearly completed, and within a day or two Drummond and Co. would have got Â£250â€”Smith's salary in connection with the Traders' and Consumers' Provident Association was to be Â£8 a weekâ€”that associa
tion was formed to take over the goodwill of the British National Thriftâ€”I do not know the price that was to be paidâ€”there is no ground for suggest
ing that the business of Henry Drummond and Co. was not a bona fide oneâ€”it was a properly registered companyâ€”if it goes down I shall lose Â£400 or Â£500â€”at the time of Smith's arrest it was perfectly solventâ€”the Pension Tea Society is still carrying on business in a small way.

Cross-examined. The date of Smith's resignation might have been the same day that the offices were closed; I do not knowâ€”I do not know when Mr. Ford laid his information at Bow Streetâ€”when Smith resigned he went away; I do not know whereâ€”I think Henry Drummond and Co. held the lease of the offices in Chancery Lane before Mr. Middlemissâ€”I met Smith at 27, Chancery Lane, as the result of an advertisementâ€”at the time I did not know anything about Henry Drummond and Co.â€”Smith told me he had taken over Drummond's businessâ€”there are no entries in the cash book after June, 1902â€”I did not know the account was overdrawn in Juneâ€”I knew it was very low, and I had arranged to put some more money in, only Mr. Adams' Â£100 went in insteadâ€”I was present at an interview between Smith and Adams before Adams parted with his moneyâ€”I did not hear Smith say anything that was falseâ€”I do not think he referred to the banking accountâ€”on March 21st, 1902, I drew Â£35 from the account of Drummond and Co., but I repaid it on the 29thâ€”in March only Â£2 was paid into the bankâ€”I had very little to do with Drummond and Co.â€”I had the Pension Tea Society to look afterâ€”I have not made any entry in the books of the Pension Tea Com
pany since May lastâ€”the British National Thrift Society were to be paid 3d. a week in respect of every member in the Pension Tea Societyâ€”20 per cent of that profit would have gone to Drummond and Go. For working expensesâ€”the National Thrift was a genuine societyâ€”I do not' know who the trustees wereâ€”they were mere nonentities for the purposes of registrationâ€”I do not know that anyone was appointed to look after the pensionsâ€”I have no record of the net profits funded with the Societyâ€”the business of the Pension Tea Company indirectly involved life insurances, but the British National Thrift was not formed to get over the difficulty of depositing Â£20,000.

Re-examined. The profits of the British National Thrift during the first twelve months were expended in extending the businessâ€”both the National Thrift and the Pension Tea Societies were placed voluntarily under the supervision of the Board of Trade and had their approval.

rs.hi: of obtaining money by false pretences with intent to defraud.

p.hi:
Four previous convictions were proved against him.
Five years' penal servitude.

div1.p:
106.
ULRICH VON RODEWALD (28),
PLEADED GUILTY to
feloniously killing a mare, the property of
Joseph Williams.
Judg
ment respited â€”And

(107).
GEORGE SWINNERTON (65)
, to indecently assaulting
Henry Collier. He received a good character.
One month in the second division.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

div0.p: OLD COURT.â€”Friday, Saturday, and Monday, December 19th, 20th, And 22nd, 1902.

div1.p:
108.
WILLIAM BARMASH (26), and
SOLOMON BARMASH (46),
PLEADED GUILTY to
forging 400 Â£50 notes, 200 Â£10 notes, and 200 Â£5 notes, purporting to be issued by the Bank of England, with intent to defraud, and
PHILIP BERNSTEIN (36)
, to forging a Â£50 Bank of England note with intent to defraud, Solomon and William Barmash having been convicted of felony at this Court on May 6th, 1893. WILLIAM BAR
MASH,
Ten years' penal servitude;
SOLOMON BARMASH,
Fifteen years' penal servitude;
BERNSTEIN, who received a good character,
Twenty years' penal servitude. (See next case.)

109.
MATHEW ROME (47),
JOE ZUBESKY (27),
SYMON OBOL
NICH (31),
ADOLPH ZIEKEL (50)
, having in their possession three forged Bank of England notes for the payment of Â£50, Â£10, and Â£5, know
ing them to be forged, and without lawful authority or excuse, to which ROME
PLEADED GUILTY .

WILLIAM JAMES FLYNN .
