I am an agent in charge of the United States Secret Service Department, New Yorkâ€”that is a division of the United States Treasury Departmentâ€”on January 22nd, a man giving the name of Jacob Stern was arrested on a charge of attempting to utter Â£155 worth of counterfeit Bank of England notes at the State Bank of New Yorkâ€”there were nine notes, some of the value of Â£50, some Â£10, and some Â£5 (Produced.)â€”the man was subsequently released, as he claimed that he had found the notes and did not know they were counterfeitâ€”we did not believe him, but we could not prove otherwise.
Cross-examined by MR. SIMPSON. I cannot say that I have ever seen the informer Schmidt beforeâ€”I do not think I have.
Cross-examined by MR. DOHERTY. I have heard that Schmidt lived in America for some yearsâ€”I do not know that the American police were looking out for him.

JOHANN SCHMIDT (Not sworn). I am a German, and an engraver by callingâ€”I have been resident in England about four yearsâ€”for three years I have been acquainted with Soloman and William Barmashâ€”I first met them at their house at 25, Broad Lane, Tottenham, and after
wards at a house in Brady Street, where some people named Samuels were livingâ€”at Brady Street the Barmashes and I arranged that I should undertake the manufacture of forged Bank of England notesâ€”I commenced by making some samples to show my skillâ€”I showed the samples to the Barmashes, and I was instructed to proceed with the workâ€”at first I was employed on Â£10 and Â£5 notesâ€”on July 1st, 1901, William Barmash took a house at Southsea, where I went and carried on the same work in refe
rence to the Â£10 and Â£5 notesâ€”later I received instructions to manufac
ture notes of Â£50 face value, which I didâ€”these six notes (Produced) are my manufacture, and also this one for Â£10â€”I believe I made about 400 Â£50 notes in all, but about half of them were spoiled and not deliveredâ€”I made about 200 tens, about fifty of them were spoiledâ€”I endeavoured to bring out about 300 fives, about 100 of them were spoiledâ€”I do not know what were done with the spoiled onesâ€”I have not seen the spoiled onesâ€”I gave them to the Barmashes in good condition, and they spoiled them by keeping them too long in chloride of limeâ€”that was to whiten the paperâ€”the Barmashes supplied me with the paperâ€”I believe they got it from Wiggings, Teape and Co., in Aldgateâ€”it was bond paperâ€”I believe I made the water-mark on forged paper to the extent of about 600 fifties and about 300 each of tens and fives (Â£34.000)â€”I made the paper look like bank note paperâ€”I did not know Philip and Hyman Bernsteinâ€”I had never done this to Bank of England notes beforeâ€”I had forged things before in England, not in Germanyâ€”the whole of the work was finished by January lastâ€”we commenced in 1901â€”I received 30s. a week while I was employed, and I was to receive 7 1/2 per cent on the face value as the notes came backâ€”I do not know where they were to come fromâ€”in January I pressed for money, and I received about Â£40 on percentage from Solomon Barmashâ€”I learnt from him that William Barmash had left this country, and there was some question of money from Solomon Barmash to me for the purpose of bringing William backâ€”I did not accede to his request, and I have never spoken to either of them sinceâ€”we did not exactly quarrelâ€”we had an argumentâ€”in July I saw an advertisement in the newspapers with regard to the forgery of bank notesâ€”I read of the trial at this Court of a number of people charged with uttering a number of forged bank notes.

(Devenport and others, Vol. CXXXVI, page 581.) It was after that trial that I read the advertisementâ€”in September I went to Messrs. Fresh field, the solicitors to the Bank of England, and saw Mr. Edwin Freshfieldâ€”he referred me to the policeâ€”I saw Mr. Edwin Freshfield again, and he again referred me to the police, and some time in September I made a

statement to Detective-Inspector Ottawayâ€”I do not remember the dateâ€”I have known Zubesky about four yearsâ€”he is supposed to be a carpenterâ€”he very seldom worksâ€”he is a Russian Jew, I supposeâ€”he does not come from the same place that I doâ€”I have known Obolnich about four yearsâ€”as far as I know he is a tailor and presserâ€”in September last he was living at 59, Nelson Streetâ€”he is a Russian Jewâ€”when I spoke to Obolnich and Zubesky we spoke in Yiddishâ€”I did not know Ziekel before last September, and I have known Rome about the same timeâ€”I went about with Zubesky last Augustâ€”I made two statements to the police quite close one upon the otherâ€”I cannot give the datesâ€”after that I acted in accordance with their instructionsâ€”about the time I was making statements to the police I went to 59, Nelson Street and saw Obolnichâ€”we talked on general matters first, and finally he asked me if I could supply him with some Bank of England notesâ€”that was just before I went to the policeâ€”he meant forged notes, he knew I was in this sort of lineâ€”I said, "I will see about it"â€”he said if they would be as good as the ones he had handled before, he could buy any amountâ€”he meant some he had had from the Devenport gangâ€”I said, "I will see," and he said he would like to see some samples before he went into itâ€”I told him the amount I could supply him with would be Â£10,000 face valueâ€”then I learnt the amount would be Â£13,000â€”after I had seen the police I saw Obolnich again, when the larger amount was mentionedâ€”I afterwards had a conversation with Zubesky, and he told me that he had learned from a man, who I subsequently learned was Rome, that the Barmashes had a parcel of notes, and they were going to send the man abroad with it to dispose ofâ€”I suggested to Zubesky the idea of getting some samples and trying to sell them here instead of abroadâ€”he was to get them from Rome, and Rome was supposed to get them from the Barmashesâ€”I saw Zubesky again, and he said if I wanted to have the samples I must make an outlay or somebody else must do so to get them from abroad, and that he would require Â£2 13s. for the passageâ€”he had learnt that the notes were abroad from Romeâ€”I saw Zubesky againâ€”I do not remember if it was the next day at the Whitechapel Libraryâ€”I do not know if the police were thereâ€”we went insideâ€”I received Â£3 from the police for the expense of bringing the notes from abroadâ€”I did not give Zubesky the moneyâ€”he said the notes would be over here in a day or twoâ€”I knew the police were keeping me under observation at this timeâ€”one evening about eight o'clock I went with Zubesky to the Lord Nelson, at the corner of Philpot Streetâ€”Nelson Street, where Obolnich lived, is in the neighbour
hoodâ€”I left Zubesky and went to 59, Nelson Streetâ€”Obolnich was not at homeâ€”I went into the street and afterwards saw him in the streetâ€”I said I had some samples for him, and that there was a man waiting at the Lord Nelson with themâ€”he said, "All right, I want to see them at my own house"â€”we went to his house and I left him and went to the Lord Nelson, where I saw Zubeskyâ€”I got samples of a Â£5, a Â£10, and a Â£50 note from himâ€”I showed them to Inspector Davidson, who was not far offâ€”he was away with them for a short timeâ€”he returned to me and I went to Obolnich's house with themâ€”I looked at them myself and recognised them as some of

those I had made for Barmashâ€”I showed them to Obolnichâ€”he said, "All right; I must see a friend of mine, I must see somebody else"â€”he gave them to me back, and we went into the streetâ€”he parted from me and found the man he wantedâ€”he afterwards rejoined me with Ziekelâ€”in the meantime I had given the notes to Zubeskyâ€”then Obolnich, Ziekel Zubesky and myself went to Ziekel's house in Philpot Streetâ€”Zubesky produced the samplesâ€”Ziekel looked at themâ€”I do not think he made any remarkâ€”he gave them back to Zubesky, and then said he wanted to compare them with a genuine noteâ€”Zubesky would not allow him to have themâ€”we met the following day at the Three Nuns Hotel in Aldgate, between 3 and 4 p.m.â€”I then left them, and had some communication with the policeâ€”next day I went to the Three Nunsâ€”I met Zubesky coming away from thereâ€”he said I was a little late and that Ziekel had been there but had not brought the genuine notesâ€”later that day I had an interview with Zubesky, Obolnich and Ziekel at the Clyde public houseâ€”before that I had told Obolnich that the face value of the forged paper was Â£135,000, and at this interview Ziekel offered Â£300 for the Â£135,000â€”Zubesky had told me that at least 7 per cent of the face value was required by the Barmashesâ€”I stated that in the presence of Obolnich and Ziekelâ€”on' the following day I had a meeting with Zubesky and Rome, when it was agreed that Rome should tell the Barmashes that they would get the 7 per cent in order to get the parcel out of their handsâ€”when it was taken out of their hands they were not to be given anythingâ€”it was to be sold to Zubesky and Ziekel for the Â£300â€”that could not be worked because one of the Barmashes wanted to be present at the dealâ€”I remember one day going to the Lord Nelson and Zubesky handing me a sample Â£5 note for me to take to 59, Nelson Street, and show to Obolnichâ€”on my way there I showed it to Inspector Davidsonâ€”he kept it a short time and then returned itâ€”I went to Obolnich's, but did not find him thereâ€”I afterwards saw him in the street with Ziekel and went with them to the Lord Nelsonâ€”I told them I had a Â£5 sample noteâ€”they said it was no good to look at it if I could not show them samples of the Â£10 and Â£50 notesâ€”next day I went and saw Rome and had a conversation with him, in consequence of which I got a sample of Â£50, Â£10 and Â£5 notesâ€”I went to the Lord Nelson with Zubeskyâ€”I left him there and went with the notes to Obolnich'sâ€”I produced the notesâ€”I believe Ziekel was thereâ€”they took the samples in their hands and looked at themâ€”they said they must keep them to compare, and Obolnich retained themâ€”I then went out with Obolnichâ€”I borrowed half a sovereign from Obolnich for Zubeskyâ€”I did not show the notes to the police on that occasionâ€”the notes were supposed to be returned" to me next morning but I did not get them from Obolnich until the second nightâ€”he did not say if he had compared themâ€”I gave them to Zubesky, who was supposed to give them to Rome for the purpose of returning to the Barmashesâ€”the attempted deal with Obolnich and Ziekel went off because one of the Barmashes wanted to be present, and because Rome got a little suspicious about the samples being kept so long.
Cross-examined by MR. DOHERTHY. I was never known as Jacob

Liebermannâ€”when I was in Russia I was known as Schmidtâ€”I was not born in Kovnoâ€”I lived there about five yearsâ€”I left because I wanted to travelâ€”I did not escape from prison thereâ€”I was never charged there with having stabbed a manâ€”I went from there to Americaâ€”I have been here four or five yearsâ€”I have spent about a year doing honest workâ€”I travelled for a tea merchant for three monthsâ€”I received 18s. a week, and I was engaged for three months at a factory in Gray's Inn Roadâ€”I married while I was out of employmentâ€”I thought that was a convenient timeâ€”I borrowed money from a man who is now in prisonâ€”I know a man named Noekâ€”he lent me moneyâ€”I was not connected with these forgeries for nearly twelve months before I met Zubeskyâ€”he had no hand in these forgeries when I was at Southsea and Edmonton with the Barmashesâ€”I will not say he had no knowledge of themâ€”he knew I was engaged in somethingâ€”he was introduced to me as a man who handled forged money in Russiaâ€”he knew I was an engraverâ€”he could not say whether I was honest or dishonestâ€”I have had some experience in connection with the forging of Russian notes and stampsâ€”Zubesky had connection with forgeries of that kindâ€”I do not know if he was charged or notâ€”I have not been charged beforeâ€”I had no money when I saw the advertisement of the reward of Â£1,000 for the discovery of the men who forged the notesâ€”I was determined to get it, but it was conditional upon my securing the conviction of certain menâ€”I did not entrap Zubesky; he entrapped himselfâ€”he had not the forged notes in his possession in Septemberâ€”the other prisoners have seen the notes in his possestionâ€”I got Â£3 from the police to give to Zubesky to get these notes from abroadâ€”I had no means at that time myselfâ€”I put the money in my pocket, because this came forward without it.

Cross-examined by MR. BRAY. I did not mention Obolnich's name when I went to Messrs. Freshfield, or when I went to the police the first timeâ€”I went to Zubesky before I went to Obolnichâ€”I was to get the notes from Zubesky to give to Obolnichâ€”I do not know the first day I went to 59, Nelson Streetâ€”it was in the eveningâ€”I saw the landlord's daughterâ€”Obolnich was supposed to be at workâ€”I did not say what I wanted to see Obolnich forâ€”when Obolnich took the Â£5, Â£10 and Â£50 notes from me we were in his houseâ€”no one else was present the first timeâ€”he examined themâ€”he did not keep themâ€”he did not see the Â£5 note that I offered to show him because he said he did not care to see it unless he had the other two samplesâ€”I do not know why he should not want to see itâ€”I might say they had somebody else behind themâ€”all the notes were the product of my forgeryâ€”Obolnich never offered me any money in respect of the notesâ€”I never saw him in the presence of Romeâ€”Obolnich came to me onceâ€”it must have been 2 1/2 years agoâ€”that was in connection with this matterâ€”I went to himâ€”he asked for my address, but I never gave it to him.

Cross-examined by MR. SIMPSON. I left Kovno between 1888 and 1889 and went to Americaâ€”I did not say I went directâ€”Kovno is in Russiaâ€”I never said I left Germany for Americaâ€”I was fifteen when I went to America; I am thirty nowâ€”I did not go from Kovno to Americaâ€”I did

not return from America to Germany before I came to Englandâ€”I left America for London because I was advised by a friend of mine to come here to start in businessâ€”it was not the same business which I was carrying on in Americaâ€”the business in America was not forgeryâ€”I do not remember what boat I came over inâ€”I might swear I landed in Liverpoolâ€”I might have sworn before the Alderman that I landed in London, but I did so by trainâ€”I did not know Ziekel until I went to find other purchasers for the notesâ€”I saw him about four timesâ€”the first time I saw him was on the night of his seeing these three notesâ€”I do not remember the dateâ€”I suppose it was Septemberâ€”the second time I saw him was in the Clyde public houseâ€”the third time was in the street, and the last time in the Lord Nelson, I believeâ€”I never gave him these notesâ€”I never saw them in his handsâ€”when I told the police that I had given the notes to the prisoners they did not search meâ€”I do not know if they took any steps to see if I had given them upâ€”the whole of my acquaintance with Ziekel lasted about fourteen daysâ€”he offered me Â£300 for the notes, and Obolnich, Zubesky and I agreed we should tell the Barmashes it was Â£600â€”Ziekel did not know anything about that.

Re-examined. The three first notes were given back to Zubesky, because they were not allowed to be retained for comparisonâ€”Rome and Zubesky represented the agents of the sellers in the matterâ€”Obolnich and Ziekel I understood to be the agents for the buyersâ€”Obolnich made me no offer, but he was present when the Â£300 was offered by Ziekelâ€”I never gave the notes into the hands of Ziekel, and I do not think he was present when they were handed to Obolnichâ€”I was convinced Ziekel knew of the negotiations, because when I should have got the notes back I met him in the street, and he said he could not give them to me then because he was hunting someone else up, and I must wait a few hours moreâ€”he was always looking for things in my line.

JOHN DAVIDSON (Chief Inspector, City.) Schmidt was sent to me on September 5th by Messrs. Freshfieldâ€”the first statement I had from him was on September 26thâ€”after that, police observation commenced on the prisoners and on Schmidtâ€”on September 27th I was in High Street, White-chapelâ€”I saw Romeâ€”I had followed him from West Hamâ€”I saw him meet Zubesky outside the Whitechapel Libraryâ€”on September 29th I gave Schmidt Â£3â€”that did not come backâ€”on September 30th I was near the Lord Nelson at 8 p.m.â€”I saw Schmidt with Zubesky go into the Lord Nelsonâ€”Schmidt came outâ€”I spoke to him in Philpot Streetâ€”I then followed him to 59, Nelson Street, which turns out of Philpot Streetâ€”after he had left Obolnich's house he joined Obolnich in the streetâ€”they remained in conversation, and went into Nelson Streetâ€”they retraced their steps and went into the Lord Nelsonâ€”Obolnich came out first and ran across to his houseâ€”then Schmidt came out with Zubeskyâ€”he left him and I followed Schmidt, who handed me what purported to be three Bank of England notesâ€”I know now that they were forgedâ€”I took them to Inspector Dinney, who was close byâ€”we examined themâ€”one was a Â£50 note N/50 02077, one for Â£10 L/50 65040, one for Â£5 J/61 43540

â€”we did not take the date of makingâ€”I returned to Schmidt and handed the notes back to himâ€”I then followed him to Nelson Streetâ€”he knocked at 59, entered, and remained some timeâ€”he came out and joined Zubesky, who had been standing in the streetâ€”they remained in deep conversation and then partedâ€”I then joined Schmidtâ€”on October 1st, about 4 p.m., I was close to the Three Nuns with Inspectors Dinney and Ottaway and Constable Landleyâ€”I saw Zubesky and Ziekel in Aldgate High Streetâ€”Schmidt arrived shortly after they had passed and followed in their directionâ€”on October 4th I was outside the Lord Nelson at 10 p.m.â€”I saw Schmidt and Zubeskyâ€”they went to the Lord Nelson togetherâ€”Schmidt came out and brought me what purported to be a Â£5 Bank of England noteâ€”I took it to Dinney and examined itâ€”the number was J/59 24383, dated September 13th, 1901â€”I gave it back to Schmidt, who went to 59, Nelson Street, knocked at the door and went inâ€”he came out almost immediately, went into Philpot Street, and met Ziekel and Obolnichâ€”they all remained in conversation, and then all crossed the road and joined Zubesky, who was outside the Lord Nelsonâ€”they all went inâ€”when they came out Obolnich and Ziekel went away together and Zubesky and Schmidt togetherâ€”on October 5th Schmidt made a statement to me, in consequence of which, about 7 p.m., I went to the Whitechapel Road with other officersâ€”I saw Schmidt, Zubesky, and Rome together at the corner of Osman Street, close to the libraryâ€”they walked up Osman Street, followed by Landley and Atkinsâ€”about 7.15 I saw Schmidt and Zubesky in Whitechapel Roadâ€”I followed them to 59, Nelson Streetâ€”Schmidt knocked at the door and entered, leaving Zubesky out
sideâ€”he came out shortly and joined Zubeskyâ€”they both stood outside No. 59 for some time, and were joined by Obolnichâ€”they all went into the Lord Nelson, where they remained some time talking and drinkingâ€”when they came out Schmidt and Obolnich left Zubesky, walked down Philpot Street and stopped on the footway in conversationâ€”Schmidt took something from his inside jacket pocket, handed it to Obolnich, who put it into his inside jacket pocketâ€”it was something white, and, from the distance I was standing at, looked like paper, about the size of an enve
lopeâ€”I then saw Obolnich place his hand in the pocket at the back of his trousers and take something out, which he handed to Schmidtâ€”both walked away together and joined Zubesky in Commercial Roadâ€”Obolnich then left Zubesky and Schmidt and went towards Nelson Streetâ€”about 9 p.m. that night I saw Schmidt again, and he made a statement to meâ€”I did not see any notes that dayâ€”on October 6th, at 1 p.m., I saw Schmidt with Ziekel in Commercial Roadâ€”Ziekel left Schmidt and got into a tram going west, followed by Detective Fitzgeraldâ€”I had another conversation with Schmidtâ€”at 2.40 p.m. I saw Schmidt with Romeâ€”they went to the Lord Nelson and remained there some timeâ€”Zubesky arrived, and went in alsoâ€”at 4.30 p.m. I saw Schmidt come out and go to Ziekel's house at 9, Philpot Streetâ€”Ziekel and Schmidt came out and went to Obolnich's houseâ€”I saw them standing in the passage of the house in conversation with another personâ€”I do not know who he wasâ€”shortly after 9 p.m. I saw Schmidt and Zubesky in the Lord Nelsonâ€”Ziekel

entered the same houseâ€”Schmidt came out and in several times going to Philpot Street and Nelson Streetâ€”about that time Rome and Zubesky came out and went to a Jewish restaurant at 2. Bedford Street, Com
mercial Roadâ€”at 10.15 p.m. I saw Zubesky, Schmidt, Ziekel, and Obolnich in Philpot Streetâ€”I followed them to the Lord Nelsonâ€”they remained there some time, came out together, and walked to Nelson Streetâ€”I did not arrest any of these prisoners.

Cross-examined by MR. DOHERTY. These men appeared to know each otherâ€”I do not know if Schmidt treated themâ€”I do not know if he had any money in his pocketâ€”he had to see me from time to timeâ€”I took care he did not concoct anything because I had other people watching himâ€”when he made a statement to me I knew if he was telling the truth or not, because I had him watchedâ€”I do not think he knew he was being watched at firstâ€”he did laterâ€”he knew me, but he did not know the other officersâ€”he told me he had given the Â£3 which I had given him, to Zubesky for the purpose of bringing the notes to the countryâ€”I do not know if he gave it to Zubesky or notâ€”if he says he did not give it to Zubesky he has deceived meâ€”I believed him when he said he had given Zubesky the Â£3â€”I do not admit any smartness on his partâ€”I did not put on an old woman's garb to find out for myself what he didâ€”I was dressed as a costermonger, a seaman, or a coalheaverâ€”I just suited myself to the neighbourhood I was inâ€”when I saw something white passing between Schmidt and Obolnich I was about twenty yards awayâ€”I did not entirely rely on Schmidt's statementsâ€”I never saw notes in Zubesky's possessionâ€”I do not know if he ever saw one of them.

Cross-examined by MR. BRAY. I watched Obolnich very closely from September 30th to October 6thâ€”he was then in honest employment, I believe, somewhere in Finsburyâ€”he is called "Symon the presser"â€”I did not arrest himâ€”I did not inquire how long he had been at 59, Nelson Streetâ€”when I went into the public-house on September 30th I did not go in with Obolnich and Zubeskyâ€”I was not in the same compartmentâ€”I could see into their compartmentâ€”I did not see any
thing passâ€”I could not hear what was saidâ€”I do not know if Obolnich was at work till 8 p.m.â€”he may have been under observa
tion by other officers during the dayâ€”Schmidt said that Obolnich was workingâ€”I should think that the conversations between them went on after Obolnich had finished workâ€”I did not see anything passed on October 4th, I did on the 5thâ€”that was between 8 and 9 p.m.â€”it was quite darkâ€”there were not many people aboutâ€”I saw Obolnich take some
thing out of his hip pocket and give it to Schmidtâ€”I was told afterwards by Schmidt that that was ten shillingsâ€”he told me it was not the con
sideration for the noteâ€”I did not follow Obolnich any further that nightâ€”I cannot say from my own knowledge whether he met Ziekel or notâ€”I never saw him in Rome's company between September 30th and October 5thâ€”Obolnich, Ziekel, and Zubesky were neighboursâ€”I did not attempt to arrest Obolnich on Octoberâ€”5th.
Cross-examined by MR. SIMPSON. I do not know where the Â£50 note has goneâ€”the only information I have about the Â£10 note is Schmidt's word

that he gave it to Malesâ€”I never saw Ziekel in Rome's companyâ€”I have not seen the prisoners together before September 27thâ€”it is not in my districtâ€”whilst I had them under observation I consdered their con
duct suspiciousâ€”I knew Zubesky was going backwards and forwards to the Barmashes, whom we had had under observation for some monthsâ€”we knew of some facts before Schmidt came to the policeâ€”if I had not known what Schmidt was I should not have bothered my head about the prisoners at all when he was with them.
Re-examined. Zubesky lived somewhere in the East End at a lodging-house.

By the COURT. We suspected the Barmashes of being concerned in forgeries of bank notes before Schmidt came to usâ€”my officers followed them and reported that they had met Schmidtâ€”Zubesky was called the Great Pearl Street man and Schmidt was called the Brady Street manâ€”we did not know their addressesâ€”knowing that Schmidt had met the Barmashes, when he came to us I was inclined to investigate and find out what he could tell usâ€”he mentioned certain facts, so I knew at once he knew what he was talking about.
Cross-examined by MR. BRAY. Previous to Schmidt coming to us I had not watched Obolnich.

----DAVIS (City Detective.) Between July 20th and August 15th I saw a man who I now know to be Rome going several times to 25, Broad Lane, Tottenham, which I have since discovered was occupied by the Barmashes.

CHARLES ATKINS (City Detective.) From July 20th to August 15th I kept observation on Zubesky and Schmidtâ€”I saw them together on several occasionsâ€”Zubesky went to 25, Broad Lane, Tottenham, almost dailyâ€”I next kept observation on September 29th, when I was in Whitechapel Road, at 4.30 p.m., I saw Schmidt there with Zubeskyâ€”at 8.5 a.m. on September 30th I saw Zubesky come out of his house, 1, Old Montague Street, and go to Rome's, at 114, Harcourt Road, West Hamâ€”he shortly afterwards came out with Romeâ€”about 11.30 a.m. the same day I saw Zubesky go to Schmidt's house at 17, Brady Streetâ€”he stayed there a short time, and then went awayâ€”on October 1st, at 11.50 a.m., I saw Rome and Zubesky meet at the Whitechapel Library, and about 1.30 p.m. I saw Schmidt and Zubesky go into the London Distillery public-houseâ€”at 4 p.m. I saw Zubesky leave the Whitechapel Library and meet Ziekelâ€”they went to the Essex Tavern, in Aldgate High Streetâ€”Zubesky came out and went to the library againâ€”he met Schmidt outsideâ€”Zubesky said to Schmidt, "You are late"â€”they went to the Princess Alice in Com
mercial Street, and about 5 p.m. to 59, Nelson Streetâ€”Schmidt went in, Zubesky remained outsideâ€”after a short time Schmidt rejoined Zubeskyâ€”they met Obolnich in Church Street and had a conversation thereâ€”they left him and went to the Whitechapel Library and then to Nelson Streetâ€”they met Obolnich again in Philpot Street shortly afterwardsâ€”on October 2nd, at 2 p.m., I saw Schmidt and Zubesky outside the Whitechapel Library,â€”and at 8.10 p.m. I saw Schmidt and Obolnich in the Commercial Roadâ€”on October 3rd, at 4.15 p.m., I saw Zubesky go to 59, Nelson Streetâ€”he

was met at the door by Obolnichâ€”Schmidt shortly after joined them, and they all went to the Seven Starsâ€”on October 4th, at 5.50 p.m., I saw Zubesky leave the Whitechapel Library and meet Rome outsideâ€”he then left him and met Schmidtâ€”they went together to 59, Nelson Streetâ€”Schmidt went in and came out with Obolnichâ€”they joined Zubesky, who was in the street, and all went to the Lord Nelsonâ€”while they were inside I saw Ziekel standing opposite the Lord Nelsonâ€”the three men inside came out and partedâ€”at 8 p.m. Rome and Zubesky met at the Anchor restaurant, 31, Commercial Roadâ€”they came out at 8.15 and parted at the corner of Commercial Streetâ€”Zubesky got on a tram and then Rome went down after him to Tottenhamâ€”they parted at the terminusâ€”Rome went to 25, Broad Lane, at 9.20; Zubesky stayed at the terminusâ€”Rome came out at 10 p.m. and joined Zubesky at the terminusâ€”they walked up Stamford Hill, when I saw Rome take something from his inside coat pocket and hand it to Zubesky, who looked at it and put it into his inside jacket pocketâ€”it looked like a small piece of white paperâ€”they parted on the hillâ€”on October 5th, at 2.25 p.m., I saw Schmidt and Zubesky outside the Whitechapel Libraryâ€”at 6.50 I saw Schmidt, Zubesky, and Rome outside the libraryâ€”at 7.30, Zubesky and Schmidt both went to 59, Nelson Streetâ€”at 8.30 Zubesky, Schmidt and Obolnich came out of 59, and went into the Lord Nelsonâ€”they remained in there some time and came out and partedâ€”I did not see Ziekel then, I saw him later with Obolnich in the Commercial Roadâ€”on October 20th, at 2.15 p.m., I arrested Zubesky in he Whitechapel Libraryâ€”I searched him, amongst other things I found an envelope addressed "Mr. H. Morris, 25, Broad Lane, Tottenham"â€”this piece of paper was inside it (Read.) "I am glad it is all over in good shape and order, will see you soon, Monday"â€”I cannot say whose writing that is in.

Cross-examined by MR. DOHERTY. I have seen Zubesky with Schmidt, Rome, and others on many occasionsâ€”I have never seen anything in his conduct to connect him with these forgeries except on that Saturday when Rome gave him the piece of paper at Tottenhamâ€”I do not know if he is a carpenterâ€”all the time I have been behind him he has done no workâ€”I was behind him for a few weeks onlyâ€”if he told me he was at the Bar
mashes mending furniture I should be surprisedâ€”I do not know what the paper was which Rome took from his pocket and gave to Zubeskyâ€”I was not surprised that Schmidt, Zubesky and the others should be talking in the Lord Nelsonâ€”I was looking out for something suspiciousâ€”it is rather unfortunate I could not speak Yiddishâ€”I should not expect to hear any thing about the forgeriesâ€”I simply went to see what they were doing.

Cross-examined by MR. BRAY. I have not made any enquiries with regard to Obolnich's employmentâ€”I believe he was employed all this timeâ€”I do not know how long he lived at 59, Nelson Streetâ€”I never saw anything pass between him, Schmidt and Zubesky, or heard their conversationâ€”I do not think that Obolnich ever went to Schmidt during my supervision of Schmidtâ€”I think Schmidt always went to Obolnichâ€”I never saw Obolnich in Rome's companyâ€”I never saw anything which would lead me to suspect that Obolnich had ever been in communication
with the Barmashes, except the fact of Zubesky and Rome going down to Tottenham and going back and joining Schmidt, and then going to Obolnich's house.

Cross-examined by MR. SIMPSON. I saw Ziekel meet Zubesky on Octo
ber 1stâ€”they went into the public houseâ€”I saw them on October 4th standing outside the public-houseâ€”I did not see anything suspiciousâ€”between July 20th and October 4th I did not see anything to arouse any suspicion in Ziekel's conduct except in the meetingsâ€”it was Schmidt's presence which made me suspicious.

JOHN OTTAWAY (City Police Inspector). I watched the movements of Schmidt and others after September 27th with other officersâ€”on Octo
ber 22nd at 9.15 a.m. I saw Rome go to 25, Broad Laneâ€”I saw him about 3 p.m. at the Whitechapel Library, when he left Schmidt and Zubeskyâ€”on that day I saw Rome tear a letter card to pieces which I picked up and put togetherâ€”(Read)â€”"Dear friend, very considerably surprised you did not come to my place to-day as arranged. Please be at my place not later than 10 o'clock to-morrow morning; don't fail."â€”it is addressed, "Mr. Rome, 114, Harcourt Road, West Ham, Essex."â€”Post mark, "September 30, London, W.C."â€”that is in William Barmash's writingâ€”Rome threw it into the street as he left 2, Bedford Street, Commercial Road, where Zubesky was then stayingâ€”this letter addressed to H. Morris, 25, Broad Lane, Tottenham, which is a name under which William Bar
mash went from time to time, is in Rome's writingâ€”on October 3rd Rome met William Barmash in Stratford High Streetâ€”on October 4th, between 4 and 5.30 p.m., I saw Rome meet William Barmash in Bishopsgate Churchyardâ€”they walked about together and amongst other places they went to Artillery Passageâ€”as they were walking through the passage their coats were buttonedâ€”I saw their coats unbuttoned, and a movement towards each other as if something was being passedâ€”immediately afterwards I saw Rome go to the Whitechapel Library and meet Zubeskyâ€”they remained there a few minutesâ€”they walked away and parted, and Zubesky returned to the libraryâ€”I arrested Rome and Ziekelâ€”Ziekel made no reply to the chargeâ€”I arrested Obolnichâ€”he said, "I suppose you have someone who has given information, but I know nothing about it"â€”I found this news
paper cutting on himâ€”(This was the report of forgeries on the Bank of England, and stated that some hundreds of Bank of EnglandÂ£5 notes have been put into circulation.)â€”I had Rome under observation on Octo
ber 5thâ€”I saw him go to 25, Broad Laneâ€”some documents and books were found on Rome, in one of them I find the entry, "Sal. Â£2 from Joe Zubesky, 4, Bedford Street, Commercial Road," and "1, Old Montague Street"â€”that was another address of Zubesky'sâ€”I also found the entry 63, Slater Street; that was an address of a man named Salisburyâ€”I also found a document addressed, "Mr. Henry Morris, 25, Broad Lane, Totten
ham"â€”and this telegram, dated October 15th, with the Stratford stamp upon it, "Rome, 114, Harcourt Road, West Ham. See me at once, home; waiting, bring"â€”also a number of envelopes containing letters signed "W.," and some post cardsâ€”the letters are in William Barmash's writing

â€”one dated October 4th from William Barmash,"Dear friend, please excuse me not calling upon you as promised. Please call upon me not later than Wednesday, without fail, yours"â€”there is no initial to that.

Cross-examined by MR. BRAY. Schmidt made his original statement to me; he did not mention Obolnich's name thenâ€”I was not watching Obolnich on October 5thâ€”between September 30th and October 5th I did not see anything pass between Obolnich, or Obolnich and Zubesky, or Obolnich and Ziekelâ€”I never saw him in conversation with Rome or the Barmashesâ€”he was employed at Brice, Palmer and Co.'s for, I think, a few monthsâ€”he has been living at 59, Nelson Street for some years.

Re-examined. When I arrested Obolnich I found on him several small stones that had been taken from rings or pinsâ€”I said, "Where did you get them from?"â€”he explained he dealt in various properties, and bought, as a dealer, things he could raise money on, and these were some of the things he had bought.

WILLIAM FITZGERALD (City Detective). On October 8th, about 9.10 p.m., I saw Schmidt, Zubesky, and Obolnich come into the Clyde public-house, talk together a little time, and then partâ€”about 7.45 that evening I had seen Obolnich and Ziekel together in the Commercial Roadâ€”on October 15th, about 10 p.m., I saw Schmidt, Obolnich and Ziekel together near the Commercial Roadâ€”after meeting Ziekel and Obolnich at the Clyde, I saw Schmidt with other people after that.

Cross-examined by MR. BRAY. I was eight or nine days watching the prisonersâ€”I saw nothing pass between themâ€”I did not hear their con
versation.
Cross-examined by MR. SIMPSON. They only aroused my suspicion by the way they looked about.

ALEXANDER GOODGE . I am an Inspector in the Bank Note Department of the Bank of Englandâ€”the nine notes produced are all forgedâ€”no genuine notes for Â£10 were ever issued by the Bank with the serial No. L/50 65040, nor Â£50 notes with the serial No. L/50 02077â€”a Â£5 note dated October 19th, 1901. with the serial No. J/61 43540 was issued on Octo
ber 14thâ€”that was received back into the Bank on January 28th, 1902, therefore the note of September 30th,. 1902, could not have been genuineâ€”the Â£5 note with the serial No. J/59 24383 of September 13th, 1901, does not tally with any note issued upon that day.
JOHANN SCHMIDT (Re-examined). I last saw the water-marked paper representing the face value of over Â£38,000 in the possession of one of the Barmashes, I cannot say which, at Broad Lane.

p.hi: Zubesky in his defence on oath said that he had no connection with the forgeries; that he never had forged banknotes in his possession; and that he knew Schmidt through being engaged to his sister,' but had no other connection with the prisoners than in business or casually meeting them at public-houses.
Obolnich, in his defence on oath said that he met Schmidt in a restaurant, and that he afterwards came to him about the employment of a tailor's

machinist; that Schmidt never mentioned forged notes, and no trans
action took place between him and any of the prisoners with regard to forged notes, but only with regard to business; and that he did not know Zubesky, although he might have seen him among other men at a public-house.

div1.p: GUILTY .

ZIEKEL then
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony on July 26th, 1900, at this Court. (See next case.)

110.
MATTHEW ROME and
JOE ZUBESKY were again indicted with
ISRAEL SALISBURY (48), and
MORRIS MALES (73)
, For having in their possession without lawful authority or excuse two forged Bank of England notes for Â£50 and Â£10, well knowing them to be forged.
MR. MATHEWS and MR. LEESE Prosecuted; MR. J. P. GRAIN appeared for Rome; MR. DOHERTY for Zubesky and Salisbury; and MR. SIMPSON for Males.

MR. SIMPSON objected to MR. MATHEWS, in his opening speech, men
tioning a statement made by Males to the police on the ground that state
ments made in fear were not admissible; MR. JUSTICE DARLING agreed that statements made under threat or influence were not admissible, but ruled that a statement made in fear alone was admissible; MR. SIMPSON then submitted that it was not admissible because it was not made voluntarily; MR. JUSTICE DARLING ruled that it was admissible, but asked MR. MATHEWS not to mention it in his opening.

JOHANN SCHMIDT . I was employed from June, 1901, to January, 1902, in manufacturing spurious Bank of England notesâ€”as far as I knew I was doing that at the instance of the Barmashes, who lived at 28, Broad Lane, Tottenhamâ€”last September I saw in the newspapers a reward offered by the Bank of Englandâ€”I saw Messrs. Freshfields, and then went to the police, and put myself under their instructionsâ€”I had known Zubesky and Salisbury four and a half yearsâ€”Rome I did not know at firstâ€”I had only heard of Males casuallyâ€”I saw him in the later stagesâ€”the first deal with the notes with Obolnich and Ziekel did not come off, and as a consequence I had to find some fresh buyersâ€”on October 15th I met Rome and Zubesky by appointment in Liverpool Street, and went with them to the Mail Coach in Camomile Streetâ€”Rome handed me a Â£10 and a Â£50 forged Bank of England noteâ€”they were to be given as samples to the new buyersâ€”they were notes which I had madeâ€”this (Produced) is the Â£10 noteâ€”about 3.15 p.m. I took the notes to the Cannon Street Hotel, and saw Inspectors Davidson and other officersâ€”I handed the notes to Inspector Davidsonâ€”I can hardly remember if the Â£50 note had a Bank stamp upon itâ€”about 8.30 p.m. I went to Salisbury's house at 63, Slater Streetâ€”I had been there a good many times beforeâ€”I am a German Jewâ€”I have known Salisbury to be a Russian Jewâ€”I do not know what Males isâ€”when we talked together we spoke in Yiddishâ€”I knew Salisbury as a shoemaker, but I had other dealings with himâ€”I lived in his house for some timeâ€”on October 15th I did not find him at homeâ€”I left word

where he would find meâ€”he came to me, and we both went to his houseâ€”we went upstairs with Males, who also arrivedâ€”I told Salisbury I had the samples which he wanted to show to Malesâ€”they both looked at them and took them into their hands, and Males said, "They are all right"â€”he put them into his pocket, and said, "I will let you know to
morrow at five o'clock; I will give it to you back with an answer"â€”it was agreed that I was to have 5 per cent on the face valueâ€”I suppose the buyers were to pay thatâ€”Males said that he had got a man, who was a receiver, and was quite rich enough to sign a cheque for Â£10,000â€”I left the notes in the possession of Malesâ€”we all three went and had a drinkâ€”we were to meet next day at Salisbury's houseâ€”I went there next dayâ€”they were not thereâ€”I saw Salisbury later and he said it was supposed that the buyer had retained the samplesâ€”he would not give them back unless he saw the man who gave them to him (Salisbury)â€”I did not see Males at all on that dayâ€”I promised to call next day at twelve o'clock, and on the way there I saw Salisbury standing outside the Princess Alice in Commercial Streetâ€”I asked him if Males had been homeâ€”he said he did not know as he had not been down homeâ€”we went to 63, Slater Streetâ€”we did not find Males there, so we parted, and after a time I saw the policeâ€”I afterwards saw Males coming out of a public-house in Commercial Streetâ€”he fold me the same story about the notes being retained by the pur
chaserâ€”I readily consented to see the man, and a meeting was to take place in the White Hart Road, not in a public houseâ€”I went there, but neither Salisbury nor Males kept the appointmentâ€”on October 18th, about 11.30 a.m., I went to 14, Short Street, where Males livedâ€”he was coming out of his house to go to the Synagogue to worshipâ€”he said that as soon as he had done at the Synagogue he would go over to Salisbury, who had the notes in his possessionâ€”I waited until he had done his devo
tions, and when he came out he made straight for Salisbury'sâ€”I followed himâ€”we went to Slater Street, where I saw Salisburyâ€”I demanded the notes I had given to Males, who said he had not got them in his possession, and that Salisbury had themâ€”Salisbury said that as he had not got them out of my hands he could not get them backâ€”I suppose he had got them from Malesâ€”he wanted me to give him some money, and he demanded Â£10 as purchase money to get the notes backâ€”of course I said that was out of the question and that he would not get any moneyâ€”I could not get my notes backâ€”I left the house with Malesâ€”Salisbury and another man followed usâ€”I did not know at that time that one of the notes had been utteredâ€”next day I went to Rome'sâ€”I told him the samples had been retained by a man to whom I had given them, and who wanted moneyâ€”Rome wanted to see the manâ€”until then he did not know anything about himâ€”we went to Salisbury's houseâ€”we saw Salisburyâ€”I introduced him to Rome as the man who had the notes in his possessionâ€”at first Salisbury denied having them but, after speaking to Rome, he changed his mind, and said he would let him have them for Â£3 or Â£4â€”Rome said he would try and get it, and he "charged me with the commission of getting itâ€”I left with Rome, and we went to see Zubesky at the Whitechapel Libraryâ€”we had a row, and Zubesky insisted upon going to Salisbury's place, as he

did not believe what I said, and he and I went back to Salisbury's, who at first did not want to speak to Zubesky at all, then he said, "I do not know anything about these notes; if you want to find out where they are you had better go and see the old man Males"â€”Zubesky and I then went to Short Streetâ€”we found Malesâ€”I said I wanted the samplesâ€”he said he could not help it, they were not in his possessionâ€”I went again to Salis
bury's place with Malesâ€”Zubesky remained outsideâ€”I saw Salisbury in Males's presence, and it was arranged that Salisbury should have a few pounds the following morning to induce him to return the samplesâ€”that was about 12 p.m.â€”the interview was to beat Salisbury's house, not later than 12 o'clock next dayâ€”I did not see Salisbury again that nightâ€”I saw Zubesky, and told him I would get the money for himâ€”I saw the police, and made a communication to themâ€”the appointment next day was not kept, and the police on that day made a number of arrests.

Cross-examined by MR. GRAIN. I think I first saw Rome in October lastâ€”I think I first saw him two weeks beforeâ€”I went to the Mail Coach on October 15thâ€”I had seen him in the street in Aldgate with Zubeskyâ€”I believe it was in the forenoonâ€”I have spoken to him there about bank notes before October 4thâ€”I first communicated with the police in Sep
temberâ€”I never told Rome that I had been in communication with the policeâ€”I did not read the advertisement of the reward to himâ€”I did not tell him the purport of the advertisementâ€”I did not offer him a portion of the reward if he would assist me in recovering the notesâ€”I did not ask him whether he knew the Barmashesâ€”I was told that he was acquainted with themâ€”I never saw Rome at the Barmashes' house while I was thereâ€”I never heard his name mentioned by the Barmashes, Zubesky, or Obolnich up till October.

Cross-examined by MR. DOHERTY. I am a German Jewâ€”I did not mention at the Mansion House that I spent six years in Russia, because I was not askedâ€”I was born in Munichâ€”my father kept a private school thereâ€”I was five years old when I left Germanyâ€”I stayed at Kovno, in Russia, till I was eleven, when I went to Americaâ€”I stayed there ten or eleven yearsâ€”I am thirty nowâ€”I was not guilty of forgery in Americaâ€”when I came to London I went to Brick Laneâ€”I had an acquaintance thereâ€”during the four and a half years I have been in London I have devoted six months to honest work, for which I received 18s. a weekâ€”I did not obtain my two situations by false pretences, they required no referencesâ€”I travelled for the British Tea Companyâ€”I had no money except what I earnedâ€”I borrowed from friendsâ€”all of them are not now in prison as thieves and rogues and card sharpersâ€”they lent me honest moneyâ€”I rendered them some serviceâ€”I do not think it was an honourable serviceâ€”I altered some little things for themâ€”one thing was a letter of credit for Â£1,000â€”I knew I was not doing right according to law, but I had not much scruples about itâ€”I was most naturally afraid of the policeâ€”my conscience did not prick meâ€”I got hardened to itâ€”it is very hard to do the first thingâ€”I think it is dishonourable to betray my associatesâ€”I should not have betrayed the prisoners if they had been real friends of mineâ€”Rome handed the Â£50 and Â£10 notes to meâ€”Zubesky did not have them,

but I saw some notes in his handsâ€”as far as I know from June, 1901, to October 15th, 1902, Salisbury had no idea of the forgeriesâ€”I lodged in the same house as he did when he was at 1, Old Montague Streetâ€”I did not wish to entrap himâ€”he said many times he wished I would give him a chance in some such transaction, and he at the same time said that he could furnish a buyerâ€”I knew he could not buy himself, and he was merely using me as an instrument against the other partiesâ€”no one except Males saw the notes in Salisbury's handsâ€”I looked to Males to procure the purchaser for the notesâ€”Males told me the name of a would-be pur
chaser, but I found it was a hoaxâ€”I never saw the notes again after Males took them away with himâ€”Salisbury never told me he would get a man to purchase the notes.

Cross-examined by MR. SIMPSON. I came from America to Londonâ€”I do not think I said at the Mansion House that I left Germany fifteen years ago, nor did I say that I determined to entrap Salisburyâ€”I had spoken to Males before October 15thâ€”Males told me that the man who could write a cheque for Â£10,000 hired out cabs, and I believe he also had some public housesâ€”I heard also that he was a receiverâ€”except the occasion when I showed the notes to Males, at 63, Slater Street, I have never seen any notes in his handsâ€”I have never seen him with Romeâ€”the police gave me Â£3 to give to Zubesky for the notesâ€”I told them I had used it for that purposeâ€”that was untrue; in a sense it was true, I used the money on Zubesky, and I gave him some money out of itâ€”when I told the police that I had given the notes to Salisbury and Males, they took my word that I had done soâ€”they did not search me to see if I still had them. '

Re-examined. When I first met Rome it was in connection with the forged notes, and to widen out the scheme where we wanted to cheat the othersâ€”I had been to his house once before, the time that I went there in connection with the second dealâ€”I procured some sample notes from Zubesky and Rome, and submitted them to Obolnich and Ziekelâ€”Zubesky told me that Rome knew the Barmashesâ€”Salisbury knew I had been engaged in previous forgeriesâ€”he always complained that I did not give him a chanceâ€”I believe I saw Males three years ago, and I saw him again at Salisbury's a short time before these negotiations startedâ€”Males wasâ€”to find the financier.

JOHN DAVIDSON (Chief Detective-Inspector, City). On October 15th I saw Rome, Zubesky, and Schmidt together in Liverpool Street at 1 p.m.â€”I followed them to the Mail Coachâ€”they all three went in and came out after a short timeâ€”Rome left the others, who went to Osman Street, White-chapel Roadâ€”about 3.45 p.m. I was at the Cannon Street Hotel with other officersâ€”I saw Schmidt there, he showed me what purported to be two Bank of England notes, one for Â£50, numbered N/49 72522, and dated March 6th, 1901, and the other a Â£10 note, L/50 24529 (Produced.)â€”the Â£50 note had "Lloyds Bank, Limited, Holborn Branch," stamped on itâ€”I handed them back to Schmidt, who made a statement to meâ€”at 7.45 p.m. I saw him near Slater Street, and I followed him to No. 63, where Salisbury livedâ€”I do not think Schmidt knew I was following himâ€”he went into Salisbury's houseâ€”he came out with Males and Salisburyâ€”

they went to the Swan in Bethnal Green Roadâ€”they remained there some time and then came out togetherâ€”Schmidt left the others and I followed him, when he made a statement to meâ€”on October 17th, about 12.30 a.m., I was in Commercial Streetâ€”I saw Schmidt and Salisbury in conversationâ€”later on in the same day I saw Males and Salisbury to
getherâ€”I followed them to Parkholm Road, Dalstonâ€”Males went into a house there, Salisbury remained outside watching aboutâ€”I followed Males and Salisbury there once that day, but Males twice that dayâ€”I followed Males on the second occasionâ€”Salisbury and Males left 63, Slater Street together about 8.30 p.m.; they parted at Shoreditch Churchâ€”Salisbury appeared to be giving some directions to Malesâ€”they parted, and Males took a tram to Dalston, and we followed him to the same house that we had followed him to earlier in the dayâ€”he went in and remained there some time; when he came out we followed him by tram to Shoreditch, and then he joined Salisbury again in Slater Streetâ€”they went into the house, they remained together and walked about the neighbourhood till shortly before 10 p.m.

Cross-examined by MR. DOHERTY. I do not know what took place inside Salisbury's house on October 17thâ€”when Schmidt, Males and Salis
bury came out they went into a public houseâ€”I did not follow them into a public houseâ€”I saw nothing suspicious except what I have describedâ€”when Salisbury was outside the house at Dalston he was looking about in a very suspicious wayâ€”I saw no notes passâ€”on the way to Dalston Males got inside a tramâ€”Salisbury went outside and kept looking back at the roadâ€”he changed his seat, and he kept looking on to the knifeboardâ€”he looked particularly at somebody riding a bicycleâ€”at Dalston, Males went on by himself, and Salisbury followed behind, continually looking behind.

Cross-examined by MR. SIMPSON. The presence of Schmidt made me suspiciousâ€”from my own knowledge I never knew that Males ever had the notes, but Schmidt said to me, "I have actually given the note to the man with the white whiskers"â€”he did not know his name, but it was Malesâ€”Schmidt asked me for some money, and explained that it was necessary for Â£2 13s. to be given to Zubesky to be handed to the persons who were to bring the notes to this country, or somewhere out of Londonâ€”I believed he had given the money to Zubeskyâ€”I have heard it said in Court that he did not give it to Zubesky, but Schmidt has never told me soâ€”I have not known Males longâ€”I do not know that he is an itinerant glazier.

CHARLES ATKINS (City Detective). On October 16th I met Salisbury about 4.15 p.m. coming out of 63, Slater Streetâ€”he went to 2, Charlotte Street, where a man named Greenfarg livesâ€”he remained there till about 6 p.m., when he returned to his shopâ€”on the 18th, about 9.40 a.m., I saw him go to 2, Charlotte Streetâ€”he remained there a short time and then returned to 63, Slater Streetâ€”he went back to Charlotte Street about 10.20, and I saw him meet Greenfarg outside No. 2â€”at 11.25 I saw Schmidt and Males together in Bethnal Green Roadâ€”Males went to 63, Slater Street; he came out and joined Schmidt again; they then both went to No. 63, and presently came out again with Salisbury and another manâ€”they appeared to be quarrelling as they were walking down William

Streetâ€”on October 9th I saw Salisbury at 12.20 p.m. go to 2, Charlotte Streetâ€”he left Greenfarg, who stayed there till about 1.5â€”Salisbury went to Slater Streetâ€”on the same day I saw Rome and Schmidt go to 63, Slater Streetâ€”they stayed there till about 2.20â€”when they left, Salisbury came outsideâ€”I saw him speak to his son, who followed Rome and Schmidt down Wheler Street into Commercial Street, and then he went back to his fatherâ€”on August 20th, at 12.10, I saw Males go to 63, Slater Streetâ€”he sat down and talked to Salisburyâ€”I arrested Zubesky on that dayâ€”I was present when he was searchedâ€”I found a letter in an envelope ad
dressed to Mr. H. Morris, 25, Broad Lane, Tottenham, upon him (Read.) I am glad it is all over in good shape and order, will see you soon"â€”the Barmashes lived at 25, Broad Lane.

Cross-examined by MR. DOHERTY. Salisbury, Males, Schmidt, and a stranger were all quarrelling as they walked alongâ€”when I saw Salisbury's little son following Rome and Schmidt I thought the boy was suspicious of themâ€”I think he was trying to see what they were doing.
Cross-examined by MR. SIMPSON. The presence of Schmidt made me suspiciousâ€”I was not present when Schmidt told Davidson that he had given the notes to the prisoners.

JOHN OTTAWAY (Police-Inspector, City). I arrested Rome on October 20th inside the Whitechapel Libraryâ€”I had had him under observation for some time prior to thatâ€”on October 2nd, I saw him tear up a letter cardâ€”I afterwards gathered up the pieces and put them together; it is William Barmash's writing, and is addressed to 114, Harcourt Road, Tottenham "Dear Friend, Very considerably surprised you did not come to my place to-day as arranged; please be at my place not later than 10 o'clock to
morrow morning; don't fail"â€”on his arrest I found on him a telegram, with the post office date of October 18th on itâ€”this is the original, and is in William Barmash's writing: "Rome, 114, Harcourt Road, West Ham; See me at once, at home; waiting, bring"â€”I arrested Salisburyâ€”he did not make any answer to the chargeâ€”he made a motion that he did not understand what was being saidâ€”I also arrested Malesâ€”he made a state
ment, which I wrote down some hours afterwardsâ€”I said to him, "I am a police officer, you will have to accompany me to the police office, Old Jewry, where you will be charged with having in your possession a forged Â£10 and Â£50 Bank of England note with intent to defraud." (MR. SIMPSON contended that the prosecution must prove that the statement was made voluntarily; MR. JUSTICE DARLING suggested that MR. SIMPSON should examine the witness upon the point.)

By MR. SIMPSON. I did not warn him in any wayâ€”I did not (ask him whether he wished to make a statementâ€”the statement was made in a cab, and he made it without any questions being asked of him. (MR. JUSTICE DARLING ruled that the statement was admissible).

By MR. MATHEWS. He said, "I will tell you all I know; the other day a man gave me the notes as samples and asked me to find a buyer for a lot, which is worth Â£13,000; if I found one I should get a lot of moneyâ€”I was afraid to keep them, so I gave them to the shoemaker; I have just left him, we have been talking of sending them to Scotland Yard; if you
come back with me to the shoemaker I can get them for you"â€”by the time I had arrested him it came to my knowledge that one of the notes had been uttered.
Cross-examined by MR. DOHERTY. I searched Salisbury when I arrested him, and I also searched 63, Slater Streetâ€”I found nothing of a suspicious nature thereâ€”he made no statement.

Cross-examined by MR. SIMPSON. I arrested Males soon after 5 p.m., as he left Salisbury's houseâ€”I think we arrived at Old Jewry about 5.30â€”he made another statement to me, saying that he had assisted the police before, and was willing to assist them nowâ€”he said he had given infor
mation to the police on various occasions, and brought people to justiceâ€”I wrote his statement down next morning, about 9 a.m.
Re-examined. I caused inquiries to be made about Males.

By the COURT. I have not been able to ascertain that he has given information to the police beforeâ€”he mentioned a Sergeant Wrightâ€”I cannot find such an officerâ€”I have found an Inspector Whiteâ€”I do not know if that is the man he meansâ€”Males worked as a canvasserâ€”he has not got a shop.

STEPHEN JAMES MARTIN . I am the manager at the Holborn Circus branch of Lloyds Bankâ€”that is our only branch in Holbornâ€”a bank note passing through our bank would have a circular stamp with the date that we received it upon it with the words, "Lloyds Bank, Limited, Holborn Circus Branch"â€”a note with "Lloyds Bank, Holborn Branch" on it would not be stamped by us.

ALEXANDER GOUGE . I have seen the ten notes produced, nine from America and one presented to the bank; they are all forgeriesâ€”the Â£10 note came to the bank for the purposes of examination, and was at once pronounced to be a forgery.

GUILTY . One previous conviction was proved against Obolnich. ROME,
One month's hard labour;
MALES,
Twelve months' hard labour;
ZU
BESKY, OBOLNICH, ZIEKEL, and SALISBURY,â€
Eighteen months' hard labour each.

p.hi: His Lordship commended the police for the manner in which they had conducted the inquiries.

div1.p:
111.
RICHARD REES (16),
PLEADED GUILTY to
carnally knowing
Annie McBay, a girl under the age of sixteen.
Six months' hard labour.

112.
RICHARD GRAND (20)
, Manslaughter of
Henry Wheatley.

CHARLES CLARK . I live at 11, Kimberley Road, Plaistowâ€”on Novem
ber 11th, I was at the Royal Albert Docksâ€”I met the deceased thereâ€”I had known him about a yearâ€”we went on board the barge Fiji about 2.30â€”while we were going down the Royal Albert Dock on the Fiji

the prisoner, who was a stranger to us, came alongside on the barge Queenâ€”the deceased said, "What are you rowing for, the Greenwich Coat?"â€”the prisoner said, "What is that to do with you?"â€”the deceased was in a stooping position to pick up a boat-hook to push the Queen awayâ€”the prisoner stepped aboard the Fiji and struck the deceased a blow in the face, and knocked him down on the deckâ€”the deceased had not picked the boat-hook upâ€”I went to his assistance, and put him in a sitting positionâ€”blood was oozing through my fingers from a cut on his headâ€”the prisoner got on board his barge and commenced rowing awayâ€”I called out, "Are you going to leave me with the man like this, he is bleeding to death?"â€”the prisoner came back with the man on his bargeâ€”he said to the deceased, "I am very sorry for what I have done, here is 1s. to get some brandy"â€”the shilling slipped out of his fingers, and he picked it up and put it into the deceased's pocketâ€”he then went on to his own bargeâ€”I got assistance and took the man ashore and to an hotelâ€”he was in a dazed conditionâ€”he could walk with my helpâ€”I got him some brandy and took his ticket to Canning Town, the nearest station to his addressâ€”he was soberâ€”he was not using bad language.

Cross-examined. When the deceased stooped to pick up the boat-hook the prisoner was within a few feet of himâ€”the boat-hook is 14 or 15 ft. longâ€”I cannot remember if the prisoner helped me to wash the deceased's head.

WILLIAM HENRY GILBERT . I am a lighterman of 23, Yews Fields, Deptfordâ€”I was on board the Queen in the Albert Dock on November 11th about 3 p.m.â€”we were going to the steamship Virginia; we were not going very fastâ€”I remember passing the Fijiâ€”the deceased called out, "What are you rowing for, the Greenwich Coat?"â€”people on the river often pass remarks like that in chaffâ€”the prisoner said he wanted to get by, and he shoved against the Fiji with his feetâ€”the deceased said, "Where are we going to" and the prisoner said, "Where are we going to?"â€”I did not hear either of them say anything else, but the deceased took two or three steps and picked up his boat-hookâ€”the prisoner stepped aboard the barge, and said, "Will you?" and struck the deceased on the jawâ€”he fell down on the deck of the bargeâ€”the prisoner stepped back on to the Queen and shoved the barge away, then he stepped back aboard the Fiji, and I saw him run across the other craft and get a cup of water and help to fetch the man to, and tied a white handkerchief round his headâ€”when the prisoner knocked the deceased down and came back to the Queen, I said to him, "You had better go and see what you can do for the man."

Cross-examined. As far as I could see the prisoner hoped to separate the barges by giving the deceased's barge a shoveâ€”it looked as if the deceased was going to strike the prisoner with the boat-hook; he had it by the middle in his handâ€”it was only a few feet from the prisoner.

Re-examined. The deceased had the pole in both hands and was pointing it towards the prisonerâ€”we punt the barges along with the poles; they have iron shoes on the endsâ€”I did not hear the deceased say anything threateningâ€”he seemed to lose his temper because the prisoner shoved
against his bargeâ€”I did not hear him say anything, I was too far awayâ€”the barge was a good-sized one; the prisoner was at the head of it.

JAMES HERBERT DREW . I live at 30, Muriel Road, Leeâ€”I was on board the Queen on November 11thâ€”about 3 p.m. we came alongside the Fijiâ€”the prisoner had his hands on the Fiji and his feet on the Queen, and was working the barge alongâ€”I saw the deceased make two or three rapid strides towards his boat-hookâ€”the prisoner stepped on to the Fiji and struck him, and he fell downâ€”the deceased had taken hold of the boat-hookâ€”I do not know if he had picked it upâ€”I did not see him do anything with itâ€”the prisoner returned to his own barge, and then returned and helped to bathe the deceased with water; then he came back to his own barge and we went away.

ARTHUR CLIFFORD DORMFORD . I am Divisional Surgeon of Police of 153, Bow Road, Bowâ€”on November 11th, about 6.15 p.m., I saw the deceased at Bow Police Stationâ€”he was lying on the floor with a handker
chief bespattered with blood round his head; he was unconsciousâ€”I re
moved the handkerchief; there was a lot of mud on his head, and a wound nearly two inches long on the right side, just over his earâ€”his breathing was stertorious, his pupils were fixed and unequal in sizeâ€”blood and slime were coming from his mouthâ€”the state of his eyes showed that there was some paralysis to the muscles, due to compressionâ€”he was suffering from concussion of the brain, and compression afterwardsâ€”I do not know what was the cause of the concussionâ€”I do not know if his skull was fracturedâ€”I did not even probe the woundâ€”I thought it best to get him to the hospital at onceâ€”I did not see any injury to the jaw.

CHARLES HEWITT MILLER . I am a bachelor of surgery and receiving officer at the London Hospitalâ€”the deceased was brought in on November 11thâ€”he was unconscious, his breathing was stertorious, and he smelled of alcoholâ€”there was a bruise on his right eye and a scalp wound about two inches long, which did not go down to the bone on the right side of the head and behind the ear; both pupils were fixed; there was dry blood about the nose; his pulse was slowâ€”he died a little after midnightâ€”I was present at the post mortem the same dayâ€”there was a fracture on the right side of his head; one of the arteries had been tornâ€”there was a large blood clot four inches by three inches in size, the blood had apparently come from the torn artery, and it compressed the brainâ€”in my opinion the cause of death was due to pressure on the brain from the blood clot; the fracture of the skull was the primary causeâ€”the fracture was caused by an injury of some kindâ€”it might be caused by falling against something or being hit by something.

p.rs: GUILTY. Recommended to mercy by the Jury.

Discharged on recog
nisances on the understanding that he would give Â£25 to the widow of the deceased.

div1.p:
113.
AMELIA WIELAND (19)
, For the wilful murder of
Albert Gunther Wieland.
MR. MUIR, MR. LEYCESTER, and MR. MURPHY Prosecuted, and MR. GRANTHAM Defended. The evidence was interpreted when necessary.

MAX ANDOS . I keep a restaurant at 85, Charles Street, Fitzroy Squareâ€”on November 15th the prisoner entered my service as kitchen maidâ€”on November 25th and 26th she was illâ€”she said her legs were bad and she went to bedâ€”on November 27th she left, saying she was going into the German Hospital; she took her luggage with herâ€”she came back the same nightâ€”I did not see her then; she slept at my house that night, and left about 8 a.m.â€”I did not see her in the morningâ€”she said she was going to the hospital againâ€”while she was with me she sent everything up wrong and made a lot of mistakes.
Cross-examined. She looked queer.

FREDA BUGENHEIM . I am the wife of Jacob Bugenheimâ€”we live at 139, Wins Terrace, Forest Row, Walthamstowâ€”the prisoner is my sisterâ€”she is not marriedâ€”she lived in Germany until last June, when she came to live with meâ€”my mother had written to me saying that the prisoner was in the family way, and on October 3rd she was delivered of a child at my houseâ€”she was attended by Dr. Hornerâ€”on November 15th she went into the service of Mr. Andos, where she remained till Novem
ber 28th, when she came back to meâ€”she brought a cardboard box with her; there was a cord round itâ€”when she went to her situation she left the child with me; it was healthy, and was still with me when she re
turned from her situationâ€”when she returned she was crying and com
plained about her legs being very painful, and said the work was too hardâ€”she slept at my place that night; the child slept with herâ€”next day, Saturday, my husband came home from work at 2 o'clock, when we all had dinner togetherâ€”the prisoner was very downcast all dayâ€”at 3 o'clock my husband went out to play footballâ€”I went out at 4.20â€”I took my own child, aged 10 months, with meâ€”I left my sister and her child behind in our flat; nobody else was thereâ€”she used a zinc bath for a cot for the child, and when I went out it was lying in the bath in front of the fire in the kitchenâ€”it seemed to me to be asleepâ€”the prisoner was sitting at the table with some needlework in her hand, but she was not properly working; she was staring on the floorâ€”I got back at 6.30 with my husband and child; the prisoner was sitting on a box and crying outâ€”my husband said, "What is the matter?" twice in Germanâ€”she did not reply at firstâ€”we looked at the child, it looked white and strange; it was still lying in the zinc bath in the corner of the kitchenâ€”he prisoner was sitting before the fireâ€”the child was covered with a white napkin, and we could not see its faceâ€”the prisoner watched my husband's move
ments, and when she saw he looked at the child she said the child had fallen from her arms on to the floorâ€”then she picked it up and pressed it to her breast, and it gave-one or two gaspsâ€”my husband then went outâ€”as he was going he said, "Don't touch anything"â€”he was away about 15 minutesâ€”while he was away the prisoner did not say anything at first; she only staredâ€”I went out to the gate to look out for my husbandâ€”I went back again and the prisoner asked me where my husband had goneâ€”I said, "I suppose he has gone to report the case; I fancy he has gone for a doctor"â€”she asked me for a nightgown for the childâ€”I told her the place where they were keptâ€”she got oneâ€”she lifted the bath
from the floor on to the table, and took the child outâ€”then I went out againâ€”then my husband came back with the police.

Cross-examined. The prisoner was very fond and kind to the childâ€”for the first few weeks after the child was born she suckled itâ€”she left off giving it the breast when she went into employmentâ€”she was away nearly a fortnight; when she came back she complained of headacheâ€”she looked very strange and dazed and her face was so redâ€”the child wore a nightshirt (Produced)â€”it was fastened round the neckâ€”it wore a short shirt during the dayâ€”when I came in on the 29th the child was wearing the short oneâ€”when the prisoner bathed the child on the Saturday morning she said, "Oh, look, here is that every day"â€”I said, "Yes, don't trouble, it is every day"â€”we had washed it several timesâ€”she showed me a sore on the child's throat; it was from the milk running out of its mouthâ€”the sore went round both sides of its neckâ€”the child was a very healthy babyâ€”it had a fat neckâ€”there was a table in the room where the prisoner washed the childâ€”there was no lamp on the table when I went out, but when I came back there was a lamp and one or two other things on the tableâ€”before my sister went to her situation she went to a chemist and got some plasters to stop the milk from running from her breastsâ€”it was still running when she left to go to the situation, and also when she re
turnedâ€”she showed it to meâ€”it was quite hardâ€”she said it was painful; she had a plaster on themâ€”I am two years older than my sister; we are ten in familyâ€”I have been in England three yearsâ€”I used to live at home with my sister; she was twelve years old thenâ€”when she was between twelve and thirteen she had brain fever and was away from school for eight monthsâ€”my mother is alive, but she is not always wellâ€”about four years ago she had a kind of stroke and sometimes she does not know what she is doing.
Re-examined. I do not know if this (Produced) was the cord round my sister's box; I did not look very closely at it.
By the COURT. An aunt on my father's side was wrong in her head; she died young, having gone madâ€”I only heard of it; I was quite a little girl then.

JACOB BUGENHEIM . I am the husband of the last witnessâ€”I remember the prisoner coming back from her last situation on November 28thâ€”I saw her box when I got homeâ€”the box was in the kitchen and the cord had been cut off with a knifeâ€”I think this is the cord (Produced)â€”on Saturday, November 29th, I went home with my wife about 6.30 p.m.â€”I saw the prisoner in the kitchen sitting on a box in front of the fireplace cryingâ€”I asked her twice what was the matterâ€”she would not answer meâ€”I looked into the zinc bath where the baby was lyingâ€”its face looked strange to meâ€”I said in English, "What have you been doing with the child"â€”she did not understand; she said in German, "Look here, the child has dropped from the table"â€”she said she was washing the child, and that she took a towel to clean it properly, when it slipped from the table to the floorâ€”I said to my wife, "Don't touch anything, I am going out"â€”I went out and came back with Inspector Rowâ€”I then saw the child on a table in the bathâ€”I saw a mark on its neckâ€”I had not seen it there before.

ARTHUR DAVY , L.R.C.S. I live at 370, Forest Road, Walthamstowâ€”at 6.30 p.m. on November 29th I was called to 39, Wins Terraceâ€”I saw the dead body of a male child thereâ€”I examined itâ€”it had this white cotton garment on (Produced)â€”there was a mark on each side of the neck and on the middle of the right side, but that was only a rubâ€”I should say the child had been dead about an hourâ€”the nightshirt was tied with an ordinary band round the body, and tied loosely round the neck.

Cross-examined. The string on the nightshirt was round the base of the neck, not high upâ€”I do not agree that the child had marks round both sides of the neckâ€”there was a mark on the middle lineâ€”it was not 2 in longâ€”I should not call the marks sores or the skin rubbed; I should call them woundsâ€”the third mark was a rubâ€”I said at the police-court, "The surface of the skin was moist owing to the superficial layer of the skin being rubbed."

Re-examined. I only saw the child at the houseâ€”I was not present at the post mortem; that courtesy was not extended tome; I do not know whyâ€”I think the marks were due to pressure from some band, not by the fingers, but by a rather wide bandâ€”there was nothing about the shirt which the child had on which could have done itâ€”I think this string could have caused the marks, especially one of them.

By the Jury. It is impossible that they were caused by the milk run
ning from the child's mouth.
By MR. GRANTHAM. The third mark might have been caused by the prisoner's fingers.
By MR. LEYCESTER. That is the mark over the right shoulder.

RICHARD ROW (Police-Inspector). On November 29th, about 7.45 p.m., I was called to 39, Wins Terrace, by Jacob Bugenheimâ€”I went to the houseâ€”on the kitchen table I saw this bath (Produced) and the dead body of a child in itâ€”the head and face were lightly covered with a napkinâ€”it was dressed in a nightdressâ€”I saw a red mark in front of the neck, another on the neck above the right shoulder, and another behind the right earâ€”the prisoner was sitting in a chair, cryingâ€”the baby's night
gown was tied loosely with a small stringâ€”I saw a cord there.

By the COURT. The post mortem was on the 1stâ€”the body was brought to the station by the Coroner's officer, and taken then to the mortuaryâ€”the Coroner arranged the post mortem, and the Coroner's officer summoned the witnessesâ€”the police had nothing to do with it.

WILLIAM KNOTT (Detective-Sergeant). On November 29th I went to 39, Wins Terrace, and I found this piece of cord in the sculleryâ€”I arrested the prisoner and took her to the stationâ€”she made no remark to me on the way.

CHARLES JULIAN HORNER , L.R.C.P. and M.R.C.S. I am Divisional-Surgeon of the Police at Walthamstowâ€”on November 29th I was called to 39, Wins Terraceâ€”I got there about 7.55 p.m.â€”I there saw the dead body of a male childâ€”I attended the prisoner in her confinementâ€”I think that was the same child that she had been delivered ofâ€”when I saw it on November 29th it was lying in a zinc bath, undressed, on its right sideâ€”I got there after Dr. Bellâ€”the child's face was quite paleâ€”its tongue

was slightly protruding between the gumsâ€”its lips were congestedâ€”there was a depressed mark 1/4 in at its widest part, and a little less at its narrowest, in front of the neck, just over the larynx, extending posteriorly on each side to a line drawn vertically at the back of the earâ€”the edges of the mark at the middle were slightly abraded and the skin red, the redness tapering off on the left sideâ€”there was a mark going right round the neck, the edges of it were excoriated on the right sideâ€”there was a depressed red markâ€”there was no excoriation except in the middle for 1 1/4 inchâ€”on the right side of the neck there was another pale and somewhat glistening depressed mark, 3/4 inch below the ending of the first, extending upwards and backwards for 1 1/2 inchâ€”there was a semi-circular red abrasion below the right earâ€”it might have been produced by a thumb nailâ€”I afterwards saw the body at the stationâ€”the marks were then more apparent and the face had become deeply congestedâ€”on December 1st, by direction of the Coroner, I made a post-mortem examinationâ€”the question as to who should make the post mortem is a matter entirely for the Coronerâ€”it was made in the presence of Dr. Pepper, of the Home Officeâ€”there was no fracture of any bone, or anything to indicate any injury from a fallâ€”in my opinion the cause of death was asphyxia from strangulation caused by something like a cord being put round the neckâ€”the marks I saw might have been caused by this cordâ€”they could not have been caused simply by the child dribblingâ€”there is a possibility that the front mark might have been caused by this tape in the short shirt if very tightly restricted, but I cannot account for all the marks with itâ€”it would require excessive force to make the marks I saw.
Cross-examined. I do not think the marks could have been caused by the woman clasping the child round the neck with her hands.

By the COURT. I do not know how it was that Dr. Bell was not called to the post mortemâ€”if I had been in his position I should have expected to have been summoned to the post mortem by the Coroner's officerâ€”I should not have had the slightest objection to meeting Dr. Bell.

AUGUSTUS JOSEPH PEPPER , F.R.C.S. I am a Master of Surgery, and a Bachelor of Medicine at the London Universityâ€”I was present on behalf of the Home Office at the post mortem on the deceasedâ€”I agree with the evidence given by Dr. Hornerâ€”the marks on the neck were correctly described by himâ€”the two lower marks might have been caused by that cordâ€”the one below the ear was not caused by it, that could have been caused by the thumb-nailâ€”they could not have been caused by soreness arising from dribblingâ€”the tape in the nightgown could not account for the presence of all the marksâ€”I agree with Dr. Homer as to the cause of death.

RICHARD ROW (Re-examined by the COURT). I gave the name of Dr. Bell and Dr. Horner to the Coroner's officerâ€”I do not know why he did not give notice of the post mortem to Dr. Bellâ€”he always acts under the Coroner's ordersâ€”Dr. Ambrose is the Coroner, and William Hasp is the officerâ€”he is a constable attached to the station.

JAMES SCOTT . I am the medical officer at Brixton Prisonâ€”I ex
amined the prisoner, because she does not speak English, and the
