doctor who had charge of her does not speak Germanâ€”I first examined her on December 15thâ€”I have made this reportâ€”(This stated that the prisoner appeared to be now in fairly good health, that she was rather nervous and depressed when examined; that the witness had not detected any insane delusions; that the prisoner had suffered from frequent headaches during the greater part of her life; that about six years ago she had an attack of what she called "nervous fever," and has had attacks since; that in 1901 she was seduced under promise of marriage; that she became pregnant, and that the man refused to marry her or to help her; that her health was affected by trouble; that she had had swellings and pains in her legs; that her confinement was rather a bad one that her working for long hours in a hot kitchen would not be conducive to good health; that the witness did not consider her now insane; that on November 29th he considered that she was in a very confused state of mind, the result of want of sleep, trouble, and pain, and was probably scarcely in a condition to know what she was doing, but that he considered her fit to plead.)â€”one form of puerperal insanity is sometimes due to lactationâ€”trying to wean the child suddenly would probably cause the prisoner a good deal of local painâ€”she seems to have been of a melancholic dispositionâ€”the mental worry which she had would depress her very muchâ€”women in her condition may have tendencies to homicidal maniaâ€”I agree that one of the degrees of homicidal mania is where the impulse to kill is sudden, unresisting, unreflective, and uncontrollable.
Cross-examined. I did not observe any symptoms of puerpural insanity in the prisonerâ€”she was nervous and depressedâ€”I did not detect any signs of any mental disease.
Re-examined. She has been in hospital for two or three weeks, and I have no doubt that she has much improved in health.

p.rs: GUILTY, but insane at the time.

hi.rs: To be detained during His Majesty's pleasure.

div1.p:
114.
WILLIAM REVELL (57),
PLEADED GUILTY to
obtaining by false pretences from
Gabriella Emma Bradford and others 2s. and other sums with intent to defraud; also to conspiring with

(115)
WILLIAM JAMES RANKIN (57)
, by false pretences, to defraud
Emily Elizabeth Cowland; and obtaining by false pretences from another person 1s., 2s., 3s., and 9s. and 5s, with intent to defraud.
Rankin stated in the hearing of the Jury that he was guilty.

GUILTY.â€”
Six months' hard labour each.

116.
JOHN BRANCH (40),
PLEADED GUILTY to
making a false decla
ration before
Robert Alexander Gillespie, a Magistrate, knowing the same to be false. He received a good character.
Discharged on Recognisances. â€”And

(117)
HENRY CHARLES NICHOLLS (18)
to stealing, whilst employed under the Post Office, a post letter containing an order for 2s. 6d. the property of the
Postmaster-General.
Nine months' hard labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

p.hi: Before J. A. Rentoul, Esq., K.C.

div1.p:
118.
ERNEST IRELAND (44) and
THOMAS MORRIS (32)
, Stealing a set of harness and other articles, the property of
William Smith; and a saddle and a pair of reins, the property of
Edward Baker. Second Count, Receiving the same.

Ireland
PLEADED GUILTY to receiving.
EDWARD BAKER . I live at Francis Road, Leytonâ€”on December 1st, about mid-day, I had this saddle and these reins (Produced) safely in my stableâ€”I missed them about 6.30 the same evening.

WILLIAM SMITH . I am a greengrocer of Leytonâ€”on December 1st, about 5 p.m., I saw this harness (Produced) safe in my stableâ€”I missed it about 7.30 the same evening and gave information to the policeâ€”I value the things I lost at about Â£6 10s.â€”Baker has a stall in my stable.

WILLIAM HYDE (532 J.) On December 2nd I was with P.C. Stiff in Park Road, Leyton, and saw the two prisoners drive up to the Antelope together in a pony cartâ€”both went insideâ€”Morris came out first, and I asked him if it was his pony-cartâ€”he said, "No, I am minding it for a chap inside the pub"â€”Ireland then came out and was spoken to by Stiff.
Cross-examined by MORRIS. I am positive you drove up with Irelandâ€”the following morning you gave me a dart.

ARTHUR STIFF (613 J.) On December 2nd I was with P.C Hyde outside the Antelope public house, and saw the two prisoners drive up togetherâ€”they went into the public, and I had an opportunity of looking round the cartâ€”I saw some sacks at the rear of it, inside them I saw some harnessâ€”when Ireland came out I said to him, "Are you in charge of this pony and cart?"â€”he said, "Yes"â€”I said, "What have you in those sacks?"â€”at first he said, "Nothing"â€”he then said, "Harness"â€”I said, "Where did you get it?"â€”he said, "I bought it about an hour ago from a man I do not know outside the Baker's Arms for 25s."â€”I told him I should take him to the station for enquiriesâ€”Smith identified the harness, and the prisoners were chargedâ€”Morris said, "I know nothing about it"â€”Ireland made no reply.
Cross-examined by Ireland. You told me that you had seen P.C Friend, and that he had' asked you to assist him in recovering the harness.

p.hi: Ireland, in his defence on oath, said that Friend asked him to try and recover the harness, and was taking it to him when he was stopped at the Antelope.
Morris, in his defence on oath, said that he was playing at darts at the Antelope, when Ireland asked him to mind his pony and trap while he had a drink, and that he knew nothing of the robbery.

div1.p: ----FRIEND (Policeman). I saw Ireland on the 2nd instant in Lea Bridge Roadâ€”I spoke to him about the harness that was stolen, and he told me he would try and find out who had itâ€”I gave him no commission to find it for me or to bring it to my house, or to use my name in any respect.
Cross-examined by Ireland. I stood you a whisky before you left.
GUILTY . Ireland then
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony on July 4th, 1900, at Chelmsford, in the name of George Maynard; and Morris to a conviction of felony on November 14th, 1901, at Romford

Six other convictions were proved against IRELAND.
Eighteen months' hard labour.
MORRIS,
Three months' hard labour.

119.
JOHN WESTHEAD (23)
, Forging and uttering notice to with
draw Â£5 from the Post Office Savings Bank with intent to defraud.

SIDNEY HOBBS . I am a driver in the 49th Company of the Army Service Corps, Woolwichâ€”I am a depositor in the Post Office Savings Bankâ€”I signed this form when I opened the accountâ€”on June 18th this year, I was drafted to Londonâ€”the prisoner was in my. Company and I gave him my bank-book to take care of in a little cardboard box with some lettersâ€”it was not lockedâ€”I returned in September and asked the prisoner for itâ€”he said that he had mislaid it in the Company's stores, where everything is kept, but that he would find itâ€”he said nothing then about a box of his having been broken into in Julyâ€”I spoke to him again afterwards, and he made the same replyâ€”I did not give him authority to draw money from my savings bank accountâ€”this receipt for Â£5 is not my writing, or written by my authority.

Cross-examined. I did not give him the book to keep in the Company's stores, but to keep as a friendâ€”he said that it was lost, and advised me to apply at the Post Office, which I did some time afterwardsâ€”he offered to go to the post-office with me, but did not goâ€”I went to Greenwich with him, but we did not go to the post-officeâ€”I did not say to him, I think we will go to the post-office and enquire about my bank-book this night"â€”I filled in a form which the General Post Office sent meâ€”I know nothing about the prisoner's writing.

JOHN ROBERT SCARFE . I am a sorting clerk at the Woolwich Pot Officeâ€”on Monday, August 25th, just before 10 a.m., this notice of with
drawal was brought in, and I sent a telegram to the Savings Bank Depart
mentâ€”I got a reply, and later on a man called dressed in uniform, who signed the receipt, and I handed him the money.
Cross-examined. I will swear positively that he was in uniformâ€”he had to produce a small book with his name in it, but on this occasion I did not require it.
Re-examined. It must have been 2.30 because I got off at 3â€”I got the reply in an hour and a half or three-quarters.

MATHEW TOWER (Police Constable). In consequence of a complaint I made enquiries, and on October 13th I saw the prisoner at Woolwichâ€”I told him I was investigating the loss of Hobbs' book, also the receipt for Â£5 on August 25thâ€”he replied,"I know of it; the box was stolen and I missed some other things, some cigarettes and money, I have not seen them since"â€”he filled in this form in my presence; after that he said, "About the end of July I missed some money and cigarettes and a silver chain from my box; I did not miss the book; I reported the loss to the quartermaster; the things were

taken from the breast pocket of my tunic and were replaced"â€”on November 14th I took him in custody on this chargeâ€”when he was charged he said, "That is correct"â€”I was at the police court when he made a statement about Annie Stanfordâ€”she gave evidence, after which he said, "Well, I will say no more, I saw her at the time"â€”she was called by him for his defence.

Cross-examined. The words he used were not, "If that is the case I will throw up the sponge"â€”I swear he did not say soâ€”when I charged him he said, "Not correct"â€”he denied itâ€”I asked him to fill in a form, he made no objection, and I told him what to write.
Re-examined. If he had said what is suggested I should have heard it.

JOHN COMPTON . I am a clerk in the General Post Office, and have had some experience in the comparison of handwritingâ€”this receipt for Â£5 and the notice of withdrawal are written by the same personâ€”I do not remember all the prisoner said at the police court, but I know he said, "I will throw up the sponge, I am guilty."

Cross-examined. There is a difference in A and B in the word "soldier"â€”that naturally would be in the case of anybody forging another person's nameâ€”the "W" is differently madeâ€”A is the prisoner's writingâ€”there is a slight dissimularity in the writing in "B."
Re-examined. Hobb's signature appears in the bank book.

WILLIAM TATTERSALL . I am quartermaster-sergeant in the 49th Com
pany Army Service Corpsâ€”the prisoner was a driver in that corpsâ€”he went on leave on August 25thâ€”his leave began at 6 a.m., and he was away till the night of September 21stâ€”supposing he left for King's Cross at 12 o'clock on the Sunday night it would have come to the knowledge of the military authoritiesâ€”he could not have passed, some one must see him go out, so he would have been reported absent by the corporal in charge of his messâ€”I should have known if he had been absentâ€”about the end of July he reported to me, he said that somebody had been to his box and taken some money and cigarettes; I asked him how they got at it; he said that he left his key on the shelfâ€”he told me nothing about Hobb's bank book being taken with the other thingsâ€”he may have told me how much money he missed.

Cross-examined. He is a man of good character and a smart manâ€”if he is acquitted he will be taken backâ€”other men in the company would not see his writing, but he would see theirsâ€”he signs his name to docu
ments, but does not give them signatures, that I am aware ofâ€”he would not have to make out listsâ€”he may have made lists of arms.

ARTHUR PAGE . I am a driver in the 45th Company of the Army Service Corpsâ€”I remember the prisoner going on furloughâ€”I do not remember on what day, but I know it was not on a Sundayâ€”I carried his kit down to the station for himâ€”I did not see him get into the train; I left him at the station.
HARRY WILBY . I remember the prisoner going on furlough; it was not on a Sundayâ€”I saw him in Woolwich that morning.
ANNIE STANFORD . I live at Brockleyâ€”on August 25th, about 4 o'clock, I was going homeâ€”I met the prisoner in Brockley, and went
with him to New Cross and then to King's Cross, and we went to St. Neots togetherâ€”it was on a Monday.
Cross-examined. I kept him waiting before I met him.

The prisoner's statement before the magistrate. "I am not guilty of the crime; I was not in Woolwich when it was done; I was away from the 25th, but I waited at King's Cross six hours; I picked up a young lady at St. John's and she is here to witness."

The prisoner, in his defence upon oath, stated that on August 25th he had his dinner in barracks at 12.30, and then went and got his luggage and went by train to St. John's, where he waited for a young lady who he had known some time, and went with her to King's Cross; that when he cleared his box he left his key and the key of the stores in a coat on his bed in a room where eight other men slept, and came back and found them in the same place, but a day or two afterwards he opened the box and found he had been robbed of a cigarette case and other things, but did not miss the bank book till the driver asked him for it, that he then went to the store room and could not find it there, and about two months afterwards he went with the prosecutor to the Government office about it; that he could only write with difficulty; that he never said that he would throw up the sponge, or used the word, but he had no heart to go on after the witness had told a lie against him, and said that he was guilty with a broken heart; and that he was not in Woolwich when the crime was committed.
ANNIE STANFORD (Re-examined.) I think I told the magistrate that I left Brockley at 12 o'clock, but it was 4 o'clock.
â€”WILLOUGHBY. I saw the prisoner in the stores very nearly all the morningâ€”he was not on duty because his leave had commencedâ€”the stores were about three minutes walk from the post office.
NOT GUILTY .

120.
ALFRED POULTON ,
Manslaughter of
Walter Frederick Kimber.
----FRITH (Sergeant P 2.) Produced and proved a plan of Loam Pit Vale, Lewisham.

FREDERICK PIKE (Inspector P.) On November 11th, about 8.30 p.m., I saw the prisoner at Lewisham Police Stationâ€”from what I was told I told him he would be charged with being drunk while in charge of a horse and gig at Loam Pit Vale, and running over the deceased at the same time and placeâ€”he was then drunk, and said, "All right, I ran over him"â€”the gig was then in the station yard.
Cross-examined. He spoke in a peculiar wayâ€”I thought it was through drinkâ€”I have not spoken to him sinceâ€”at the police-court next day he spoke peculiarly.
Re-examined. He had recovered from the effects of drink then.
By the COURT. I have seen hundreds of drunken peopleâ€”in my opinion the prisoner was undoubtedly drunk.
ARTHUR GOODALL . I am a greengrocer, of 38, Horton Street, Lewishamâ€”on November 11th, about 6.30 p.m., I was in Loam Pit Vale, I heard a

cry of "Oh," and I see, a man on his back in the road by the kerbâ€”I saw a wheel go over himâ€”I saw a cart with the prisoner drivingâ€”there was another man in the cartâ€”they drove on and then came backâ€”the other man got down and put the deceased into the cartâ€”the prisoner put his arm round the deceased's neck to keep him up, and then drove offâ€”I did not see any more of itâ€”the deceased had been pushing a truckâ€”the cart was coming down behind him on the near side when he was knocked downâ€”there was room on the near side for the horse and cart to have passedâ€”I did not see any other horse or cart there.

Cross-examined. The man who got down from the cart was soberâ€”I persuaded them to take the deceased to the infirmaryâ€”they went off all right as far as I could seeâ€”I did not see the actual contact between the cart and the truckâ€”when I saw the deceased on the ground his feet were about six feet from the kerbâ€”the truck was also near the kerbâ€”I did not notice where the cart was.

FREDERICK MORGAN . I am a labourerâ€”on November 11th, about 6.30 p.m., I was walking with Goodall in Loam Pii Valeâ€”I saw Poulton's trap knock the deceased downâ€”I ran to pick him up, and called to the trap to stopâ€”it stopped and returned and a man got out and put the deceased into the trap and drove off.
Cross-examined. The man who got out was quite soberâ€”I saw Poulton in the trapâ€”he appeared to be all right.

HENRY SCOTT (108 R.) On November 11th, about 6.30, I was on duty in Pawson Street, and saw a trap driving alongâ€”the prisoner was on the near side of the trapâ€”I did not witness the accident, but was informed of itâ€”I saw the prisoner and asked him how it had occurred, and he said that he had knocked him downâ€”I directed him to drive the man to the infirmary, and I followed on a tramcarâ€”on arriving at the infirmary the prisoner was not there and I went to try and find himâ€”in the Hollingham Road I found him sitting in the trap, the injured man on his off side and Constable 90 P. standing thereâ€”a doctor then appeared and certified the man to be deadâ€”I told the prisoner to get out of the cartâ€”he did so and staggered, and I then saw that he was drunkâ€”I told him I should charge him with being drunk while in charge of the cart, and took him to Lewisham Police Station, where he was charged.

Cross-examined. I did not notice that he was drunk while he was sitting in the cartâ€”he is lame in his right foot and walks with a limpâ€”it came as a shock to me when the doctor certified that the man was deadâ€”he was alive when I saw him first and spoke to him.

BENJAMIN MAY (90 P.) On November 11th, about 6.30 p.m., I was on duty in Loam Pit Yale, Lewishamâ€”I was called to the Railway Arch in Pawson Streetâ€”there was a big crowd and it was very darkâ€”the driver stood leaning on the off-side shaftâ€”I asked what was the matter, and he said he had run over the deceased, who appeared to be dying, and I sent for medical aidâ€”I led the pony in the direction of the doctor's residence, and about 200 yards from the house the doctor came up and pronounced the man deadâ€”Scott then came up and ordered the prisoner out of the gigâ€”when he got down he staggered, and it was then that I was convinced
he was drunkâ€”I took the body of the deceased to the mortuaryâ€”there was a deep cut over his right eyebrowâ€”I did not take the prisoner to the station.
Cross-examined. Until he got out of the trap I did not notice that he was drunkâ€”when the doctor pronounced the man dead the prisoner seemed cool and unconcerned.

ROBERT VINCENT DONNELLAN . I live at 2, Lewisham Park, and am Divisional Surgeonâ€”on November 11th, about 11.20 p.m., I was called to see the prisoner at the police-stationâ€”he seemed to be in a dazed con
ditionâ€”I noticed that his foot was injuredâ€”he smelt strongly of drink, and from his talk I formed the opinion that he was drunkâ€”I saw him the next morning, and he was in an extreme alcoholic tremorâ€”he said that it was the tea they had given him at the station.

Cross-examined. I have not seen him since the morning of November 12thâ€”I have known cases of extreme nervousness arising from tea drinking, but the prisoner told me he never touched teaâ€”one cup of tea could not cause the extreme nervous tremor that I saw in him.
Re-examined. I have no doubt as to the condition he was in.

DR. CEASAR. I was called to the deceased on the night of November 11thâ€”I found him sitting in the bottom of the gig deadâ€”I examined him at the mortuaryâ€”the only external marks of violence were a cut on his right eyebrow and a slight contusion on the noseâ€”death was caused by syncope, due to hemorrhage, from a rupture of the liverâ€”a weight going over the liver would rupture itâ€”I examined his stomach, but found no trace of alcohol.

JEREMIAH HAYLEY . I am a costermonger of 28, Wood's Place, Grange Road, Bermondseyâ€”on the evening of November 11th I was in Lewisham High Road going towards New Cross when I heard a shoutâ€”I looked and saw two men driving along in a gig and a man staggering in the roadway pushing a perambulatorâ€”I cannot say whether he was drunk or notâ€”it was a very muddy night, and the road was very slipperyâ€”when I first saw them I should think there was 20 yards between the gig and the deceasedâ€”he was then in the middle of the roadâ€”the next I saw was the man knocked down and the wheel of the gig went over himâ€”it was not possible for the gig to pass the man on the near sideâ€”he was walking towards the pathwayâ€”after he was knocked down the gig went on about 30 yards, and then turned back, and I helped to put the man into it.
Cross-examined. I am a stranger to all partiesâ€”I cannot say which of the two men in the trap shoutedâ€”in my opinion the deceased had time to get on to the pavement out of the way of the gig.

ARTHUR TRIMMER . I am a carman, of 30, Claremont Street, Greenwichâ€”on November 11th I had been with Mr. Male in the trap to Forest Hill to try and sell itâ€”we reached High Street, Deptford, about 5.30 p.m.â€”in the High Street I saw Poultonâ€”I got out of the trap and he got inâ€”I knew him by sightâ€”Mr. Male remained in the trap and the two men drove offâ€”Poulton was quite sober.
Cross-examined. I did not have a drink with Poulten when we partedâ€”it was a very good pony.

COSTELLA MALE . I am a horse keeper of Fisher's Rents, Deptfordâ€”on the afternoon of November 11th I had been with Trimmer to Forest Hill to try and sell the ponyâ€”we reached High Street, Deptford, about 5.30 p.m.â€”in the High Street I saw the prisonerâ€”Trimmer then got out and the prisoner got inâ€”we then drove away to the Five Bells at New Cross Gate, where we had a glass of ale eachâ€”the prisoner was quite soberâ€”when we left the Five Bells he took the reinsâ€”he was sitting on the off sideâ€”we then went along all right until we saw the man with the perambulator in Loam Pit Valeâ€”he was about three yards from the gutter when I first saw himâ€”he seemed to be rolling about the roadâ€”I shouted to him, but he did not seem to hearâ€”we were going about six miles an hourâ€”there was no room to pass the man on either side, and we pulled up as best we could, but the point of the shaft caught him and knocked him down, and the wheel went over himâ€”we did not deliberately run down the man.

The prisoner, in his defence on oath, said that he was a horse dealer; that he had been at work all day on November 11th, and had only had three glasses of ale, and was quite sober; and that the occurrence was a sheer accident.

p.rs: GUILTY. Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury.

div1.p:
121.
CATHERINE MURRAY (38)
, Feloniously taking away by force
Horace Steel, a child under the age of fourteen years, with intent to deprive the father of its care.

CAROLINE FLORENCE STEEL . I live at 6, Sandringham Buildings, Wal
worth, and am marriedâ€”I have two children, one aged seven years an Horace aged threeâ€”on November 12th, at 1.45 p.m., I sent them both to school at Larcom Street, Walworthâ€”at about 4.30 p.m. the elder one returned home aloneâ€”he said something to me, and I went to the school and afterwards to the police stationâ€”I received Horace back the next day at 7 p.m.â€”this is the child.

SOPHIA SMITH . I am an assistant mistress at St. John's School, Larcom Street, Walworthâ€”the child Horace attends thereâ€”he attended there on November 12th, and left about 4 p.m.â€”I do not know whether he left alone or with his brotherâ€”that is the child which has been here.

GEORGE SIMPSON . I am Assistant Superintendent of the Lambeth Casual Wardâ€”on November 12th, at 5.30 p.m., I was outside the Elephant and Castle and saw the prisoner with the child producedâ€”I know her as Catherine Freeman, and an inmate of the Lambeth Casual Wardâ€”knowing she has no children of her own I followed her down Newington

Causewayâ€”she was leading the child by the handâ€”she went into the Newington Sessions House and spoke to another womanâ€”I went up and asked the other woman if the child was her'sâ€”she said, "No "and that she did not know the prisonerâ€”the prisoner then came outside the Sessions House and the child began to cry, and did not seem inclined to go with herâ€”she then pushed it to the ground and made it screamâ€”at Stones End Police Station I spoke to a constable about her, but he refused to take any actionâ€”I saw no more of her till I was asked to go and identify her at the police station on November 22ndâ€”she was perfectly sober on the 12th.

MARY ANN NEVILLE . I keep a lodging house at 2, Floridine Street, White
chapelâ€”on November 13th, at 9 a.m., I went through the rooms, and in one of them I found the prisoner and a man and the child produced, in bedâ€”I came out then, and went in again soon after, and the prisoner had gone and left the child in bed asleepâ€”the man was then getting upâ€”I got the child up and gave it some breakfast and then took it to the police stationâ€”the following night the prisoner came back drunk and asked for the childâ€”I asked her where she got it fromâ€”she said from the Elephant and Castleâ€”I then turned her outâ€”I identified her the next night.

JAMES HUTCHISON . I am a doctor residing at 44, Rodney Road, Wal
worthâ€”I examined the child Horace Steel on November 14th, and found it suffering from bronchial catarrh, consistent with recent exposureâ€”it is all right now.

FRANCIS MACKAY (Police-Inspector L.) On November 15th I saw the prisoner at Commercial Street Police Station, Whitechapelâ€”I told her I was a Police Inspector and should arrest her for stealing a child named Horace Steel, on November 12thâ€”she said, "Yes, sir, I picked the child up; I know I ought not to have done so, I did not know what I was doing. I picked it up close to some high buildings where there were several post
office vans near"â€”I took her to the police station, when the charge was read over, she made no reply.
The prisoner's statement before the magistrate. "I could not steal it when I picked it up. I was wrong because I did not take it to the police."

p.hi: The prisoner in her defence said that the child produced was not the one she picked up; but that she was wrong in not taking it to the station.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

122.
GEORGE SMITH (21)
, Feloniously drawing the trigger of a loaded revolver and attempting to discharge the same at
Sidney Neville with intent to maim and disable him.

SIDNEY NEVILLE . I am a labourer of 42, Upper Kennington Laneâ€”on November 15th, at 10 p.m., I was in the gallery of the Canterbury Music Hallâ€”I left my seat to go to the urinal, and on coming back the prisoner said to me, "Is your name Sid Neville"â€”I said, "Yes"â€”and he then pointed this revolver (Produced) at my headâ€”a man named Breywood seized him, and while they were struggling I went for a policemanâ€”I had never seen him before.

THOMAS BREYWOOD I am a bricklayers labourer of 48, Walk Lane, Lambeth Walkâ€”I was in the gallery of the Canterbury Music Hall on this nightâ€”the prisoner was behind me with about ten othersâ€”I heard someone say to the prisoner, "I will show him when I come back"â€”I then saw Neville coming back along the gangway, and the prisoner asked him if his name was Sidney Nevilleâ€”Neville said, "Yes"â€”and the prisoner then drew the revolver, produced from his right-hand jacket pocket and pointed it at Neville's foreheadâ€”he had his finger on the triggerâ€”I seized his wrist and pointed it to the floorâ€”a policeman arrived and he dropped the revolverâ€”it did not go offâ€”while I was struggling with him to get the revolver away I got one finger broken and another fractured.

CLEMENT EVANS (276 L.) On November 15th I was on duty in the gallery of the Canterbury Music Hallâ€”between 9 and 10 p.m. my attention was called to a disturbanceâ€”when I arrived the prosecutor was struggling with the prisoner, and Breywood picked up the revolver produced and handed it to meâ€”Neville said he would charge the prisoner with attempting to shoot him, and I took him into custodyâ€”he said, "It is not my revolver, some of those other chaps put it in my pocket."

Cross-examined. The prosecutor did not come for meâ€”I saw the dis
turbance and went thereâ€”there was a disturbance before this occurrence, but I did not notice whether they were the same partiesâ€”I cannot say where Breywood or Neville were at that timeâ€”Breywood did not hand the pistol to the attendantâ€”he gave it to me.

HENRY BAULCH (28 L.) Evans handed the six-chambered revolver to meâ€”I examined itâ€”it contained four loaded cartridges and one which had been dischargedâ€”I searched the prisoner and found on him a box containing thirty-three full cartridges like those in the pistolâ€”the prisoner said they must have been put there by someone else, as he did not know they were there.

The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate. "I did not commit the assault. The prosecutor and the witness and four or five more started on me, and said they were the champion fighters of Lambeth. I do not know who handed the revolver to me."

p.hi:
The jury, being unable to agree, were discharged without giving a verdict. The prisoner was again given in charge to the same jury on an indict
ment for a common assault upon the said Sidney Neville. The
read over the evidence in the former case.
The prisoner said in his defence, that the weapon was given to him by somebody in the Cantrebury Music Hall but he could not recollect by whom.

div1.p:
GUILTY . Four previous convictions were proved against him.
Nine months' hard labour. The COURT awarded Â£5 to Breywood.

123.
CECIL WILFRID FRANK WALLIS (31),
PLEADED GUILTY to
marrying
Annie Clutterbuck, his wife being then alive.
Also to obtaining Â£62 from the same person by false pretences with intent to defraud.
Five years' penal servitude on the first indictment , and
twelve months' hard labour on the second, to run concurrently.
Before Mr. Common Serjeant. '"

124.
FRANCIS HALL (36)
, Feloniously forging and uttering an order for the payment of Â£4 with intent to defraud.

WILLIAM PENDLE . I am manager to Meek, Jones and Co., brass shop front manufacturers, 47, Blackfriars Roadâ€”the prisoner was employed there from about September 12th to November 12thâ€”about eighteen months ago I had an account with the City and Midland Bank, when it was closed, and I banked with the London and County Bankâ€”I had forty-nine or fifty cheques left overâ€”on November 7th the prisoner brought me a form to fill in from Somerset Houseâ€”on November 12th he absconded after we had attached his accountâ€”the cheque, dated November 15th, is drawn on one of the forms I gave him to take to Somerset House and is his writing, including the endorsement "F. H. Hall," with the exception of "Ac
count closed."

FREDERICK HOOPER . I keep the Marlborough Arms, Old Kent Roadâ€”I knew the prisoner as being in Meek, Jones and Co.'s serviceâ€”on November 15th he brought this cheque and said that he had been at the office and that the firm had left him his salary, but it was too late to get it cashed, and would I let him have Â£2 till Monday and he would repay me; he asked me not to pay it inâ€”believing his statement I gave him the Â£2â€”he came back in an hour's time and had another sovereignâ€”I did not pay the cheque in on the Saturdayâ€”he came on the Monday morning and wanted another sovereign and I would not let him have itâ€”I paid the cheque in on Monday, 17thâ€”it was returned marked "account closed"â€”I gave infor
mation to the policeâ€”I saw no more of him till he was in custodyâ€”I had two wires, and I waited ten days or a fortnight before I took the matter up.

BENJAMIN GULLY (Police-Sergeant L.) At 3.30 a.m. on November 29th I saw the prisoner detained at Bow Street Police Stationâ€”I said, "I have reason to believe your name is Frank Hall. I am a sergeant of police. I hold a warrant for your arrest for forgery, and shall take you to Kenning
ton Road Police Station"â€”on the way there he said, "Who took the warrant out against me?"â€”I said, "Meek and Jones"â€”he said, "They had Â£5 of that. Suppose I paid it?"â€”that referred to another charge.
The Prisoner's defence. I only did it for a temporary accommodation till I should have money.

GUILTY .
Twelve months' hard labour.

125.
WILLIAM JENKINS (16),
PLEADED GUILTY to
attempting to have carnal knowledge of
Esther Jenkins, a girl under the age of thirteen.
Six months' hard labour.

126.
MATTHEW LEWIS (27), Was indicted
for and charged on the Coroner's inquisition with the manslaughter of
Rhoda Eleanor Gare.

ELIZABETH GARE . I am singleâ€”for some years I have been living with the prisoner as his wife at 29, Abbey Road, Mertonâ€”we have had two childrenâ€”the eldest was three years old, and the youngest, Rhoda, was

10 1/2 months in Novemberâ€”the prisoner is a general dealerâ€”he used to go out every day and return early in the afternoonâ€”on Monday, November 10th, he came in about 4.30â€”I was at the front door with my two children, the baby on my left arm and the little boy at my sideâ€”I could see that the prisoner had had drinkâ€”I went indoorsâ€”he went into the kitchenâ€”I followed with the babyâ€”I said, "Holloa, mate, you have been on the booze to-day"â€”he struck me with his fistâ€”I snatched up this broom in my right hand to prevent the blow, holding the baby on my left armâ€”he snatched the broom from me from the bottom part and began to strike me with itâ€”it glanced off my head on to the baby'sâ€”it screamedâ€”I ran into the streetâ€”I spoke to a neighbour, Mrs. Biggs, and ran for Dr. Randall, who examined the childâ€”it died the following morning.

Cross-examined. I went over to the mantelpieceâ€”the prisoner stood by the passage doorâ€”he raised his right handâ€”his other hand looked as if it was by his sideâ€”he caught the broom with his left hand.
By the COURT. He bears a good characterâ€”his business is too bad to marryâ€”he has kept me three yearsâ€”he is a good husband to meâ€”I do not mind marrying him.

MARTIN RANDALL . I am a medical practitioner at Worple Road, Wimble
donâ€”I was called to see the child Rhoda Gare on November 10th, about 5.15 p.m.â€”the mother spoke to meâ€”she took the child to the Cottage Hospitalâ€”I examined itâ€”I treated it all throughâ€”it was partially con
sciousâ€”there was a large bruise on the right temple, another large bruise above the left ear, the skull was fractured behind the left ear, the child was suffering from convulsions and the right side of the body became partially paralysedâ€”I imagine there was only one blowâ€”this broom stick would cause the injuriesâ€”the child died of shock, a fractured skull, and laceration of the brain.

Cross-examined. At eleven months the child's head would be softâ€”it would take considerable violence to cause the fractureâ€”pulling the lower part of the-broom stick from the woman's hold would not have caused it to strike such a blowâ€”I would not say that was impossible, but in my opinion it was improbableâ€”the child was very well nourished. The prisoner received a good character.

p.rs: GUILTY. Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury.

hi.rs: To enter into recognizances. On the understanding that he would marry Elizabeth Gore.

div1.p:
127.
GEORGE MARTIN (21)
PLEADED GUILTY to the
manslaughter of
Henry Charles Drew.
Discharged on recognizances â€”And

(128)
EDWARD JAMES BENNETT (36)
, to committing an abominable crime with
Frederick Hart;
also to another indictment for a like offence with him.
Ten years' penal servitude.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

129.
JAMES DEAL (44)
, Carnally knowing
Ellen Deal, a girl under the age of thirteen.

hi.rs: Upon the evidence of Dr. James Scott, the Medical Officer at Brixton Prison, the Jury found the prisoner was insane and unfit to plead.
To be detained during His Majesty's pleasure.

div1.p:
130.
ADA KIRK (25), Was indicted
for and charged on the Coroner's inquisition with the wilful murder of
Nellie Violet Kirk.

CHARLES KIRK . I live at 1, Stewart Road, Battersea Parkâ€”the prisoner is my sisterâ€”she is unmarried, and up to November 1st was a laundress at Spiers and Pond's at Batterseaâ€”she received 10s. a weekâ€”she lived in a room at 32, Austin Street, for which she paid 2s. 6d. a weekâ€”she had a child last Marchâ€”she was confined at her mother's houseâ€”some months afterwards her mother told her to clear out of the house and go to the work-houseâ€”I lived with my mother and my other brothers thenâ€”I do not live there nowâ€”I am married nowâ€”my sister said to my mother, "You have no pity for the child, but never mind, I will go"â€”she went first to Park Road and then to Austin Roadâ€”while at Austin Road she paid 4s. to a neighbour for the keep of the childâ€”on Saturday, November 1st, it was arranged that I and my wife should meet the prisonerâ€”I and an uncle of mine met my wife and the prisonerâ€”we were together the whole eveningâ€”I and my uncle then left the women and went to a public houseâ€”after that I heard something and went to Austin Road.
Cross-examined. It was just after the child was born that the prisoner was turned out of my mother's houseâ€”the prisoner was very much upset about itâ€”she has always been a very hardworking woman.

ELIZABETH MARY KIRK . I am the wife of the last witnessâ€”I met the prisoner on November 1stâ€”I called upon her about 5.45 p.m.â€”I knocked at her door, and went into her roomâ€”she was there with the baby, which was awake, and she went out to get the baby's bottle and some milkâ€”I half-filled the bottle, and handed it to the prisoner, who gave it to the child"â€”she then suggested that I should go and tell my husband at the top of the street that she would not be long, but would see the baby to sleep and then join usâ€”I did so, and about five minutes afterwards she joined usâ€”she was asked if she had seen the baby to sleepâ€”she said, "I have tucked my baby in, bless her heart"â€”we all went as far as Vauxhallâ€”we met an uncle of my husband's, Frederick Kirkâ€”we were all together till about 9.45â€”I went back with the prisoner to her roomâ€”she went in firstâ€”as she went in, she said, "Good God, someone has been in my room"â€”she nearly pushed me downstairs in her excitementâ€”I do not know if she fainted, because I tore downstairs and fetched my husband and uncle from the top of the streetâ€”I did not look into the room before I wentâ€”I had only got as far as the top stepâ€”I did not go upstairs when I got back.

Cross-examined. I played with the child at 5.45, when I went into the prisoner's roomâ€”the prisoner always seemed very fond of itâ€”there was nothing in her manner during the evening which struck me as strangeâ€”when we went into her room she appeared to be absolutely terrified at what she saw.

DAVID VOICE (451 V.) About 10.30 p.m. on November 1st I went to 32, Austin Roadâ€”in a first-floor room I saw the body of a female child about twenty months old lying on the bed apparently deadâ€”I found this ordinary tableknife (Produced) lying between its legsâ€”I sent for Dr.
Kempsterâ€”the room was somewhat disarrangedâ€”there were some torn letters lying about and some clothes lying outside a box.
By the JURY. The room was upstairsâ€”nobody could have got in at the window even if it had been open.

FELIX CHARLES KEMPSTER . I am divisional Surgeon of Police, and practise at Batterseaâ€”I went to see this child at 32, Austin Roadâ€”it was then deadâ€”it had a cut across its throat, which had only gone through the small vessels of the neckâ€”the windpipe was cutâ€”I afterwards found that the cause of death was asphyxiation, from a clot of blood having formed in the windpipeâ€”the blood had fallen backwards and there coagulatedâ€”the child was well nourished and very clean.
Cross-examined. There were no signs of blood in the washstand, or traces of the blood having been washed up.
Re-examined. There was some blood on the prisoner's skirtâ€”I came to the conclusion that it was arterial blood, which had spurted out.
By the JURY. The child had been dead about five hours when I saw itâ€”I reckoned that the wound had been inflicted about 6 o'clock or a little later.

FRANCES WILLIMOT . I am the matron at the South-West London Police-Courtâ€”on November 3rd the prisoner was given into my charge before she went before the magistrateâ€”she was cryingâ€”I said to her, "Don't cry, I am very sorry for you"â€”she said, "I should not have done it if Fred had not laughed at me when I told him I was three months gone again; I cut her throat with a table-knife at five minutes to six, and left her; I then went out to meet my friends; God knows I loved my baby, and I hope they will allow me to see her once more."

FREDERICK JAMES KIRK . I am a labourer of 23, Wraughton Road, Batterseaâ€”I was at work the whole of last year and this, and I am the prisoner's uncle, and am thirty-four years old next weekâ€”I am not marriedâ€”I was not the father of the deceased childâ€”I did not say before the Coroner that I was the father of the dead childâ€”the prisoner told me she was in the family wayâ€”I said before the Coroner, "She told me about five or six weeks ago that she was in the family way; I did not laugh at her; I suppose she told me because she thought I was the father of it; I have had relations with her, but I am not the father of the deceased child 'â€”she told me of her conditionâ€”I did not laugh at herâ€”I told her to let it take its courseâ€”she was earning her living as a laundressâ€”I have never given her anything towards her supportâ€”she never asked me for anythingâ€”she spoke to me in September, and said she was about a month goneâ€”I saw her once or twice a week after thatâ€”I met her on November 1st in Lam
beth Walk, and spent the evening with herâ€”we went shoppingâ€”we went home about 9.45â€”she came downstairs screamingâ€”I went up and found the baby smothered with blood on the bedâ€”I did not know what she paid for her lodgingsâ€”she told me she had to pay is a week for the keep of the child.

Cross-examined. I have only bought the baby a pound of biscuits now and againâ€”that was not my own babyâ€”she did not consult me the first time she was pregnantâ€”I was not having intercourse with her at the time

â€”she asked me for a few halfpence now and again, and I gave them to herâ€”I first had connection with her about two years agoâ€”I believe the first child was born in March, 1901â€”I still say I was not its fatherâ€”I have known the prisoner since I came home form the Army in 1895â€”I have not been living with herâ€”I lived near herâ€”she was not turned out of her house because I visited her, as far as I knowâ€”I only called at her mother's house onceâ€”I was walking out with herâ€”I did not know she was turned outâ€”when she was in her own room she sent for meâ€”I had not made any allowance for her yetâ€”she said she had great difficulty in making both ends meetâ€”I was going to help herâ€”I did not laugh at herâ€”we were all out together, and we were laughing and talking, but not over this affairâ€”she seemed jolly.
By the COURT. I have no idea who was the father of the first childâ€”she summoned one man for it, and she lost the day as she could not prove it.

JOHN JAMES PITCAIRN . I am medical officer at Holloway, where the prisoner has been under my care since November 1stâ€”I have informed myself of the facts of the case, as well as of her family historyâ€”her uncle and her grandfather committed suicideâ€”her cousin has been more than once detained in a lunatic asylumâ€”the prisoner is, I think, strongly pre
disposed to insanityâ€”I have formed the conclusion that, in my opinion, at 6.30 on November 1st she was suffering from insanity, which took the form of melancholia and which prevented her from knowing the difference between right or wrong, or else that she did not know at all what she was doingâ€”she had a miscarriage about November 14th, which prevented her being tried at the last Sessionsâ€”the foetus was about two or three months old.

Cross-examined. Her general health has been very indifferentâ€”she told me that she had been dosing herself with some purgative medicine for the purpose of producing a miscarriageâ€”she is pretty well nourished her
self, but she gave me the impression of having been living very badlyâ€”she was physically and mentally reducedâ€”I consider her act was a homicidal impulse, and arose in the course of an attack of acute melancholiaâ€”she has been much in the condition that she is in now since I have had anything to do with herâ€”in my opinion she is now suffering from melancholia, and has been for some timeâ€”everything in the case predisposes to melancholia.

p.rs: GUILTY. But insane at the time, and not responsible for her actions.

hi.rs: To be detained during His Majesty's pleasure.

div1.p: ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, JANUARY 12TH,1903.
